Description: An ancient breed of Sanga cattle. Sanga are descended from indigenous African cattle that had infusions of Bos taurus, and to a lesser extent, Bos indicus, over a timeline that is uncertain at present. The now extinct long horned Egyptian Hamitic cattle are thought to be an early strain. Most Sanga cattle developed in the Ethiopia-Somalia area and migrated with herds taken by people to southern Africa; the time frame for this is uncertain but cattle remains have been found in eastern Africa dating back 7,000 years.
Additional information: There's a small cervio-thoratic hump, usually on the males of Sanga breeds and large lyre shaped horns are intrinsic to them - vital for temperature control and defence from lion. The Watusi type of Sanga cattle are all similar, with local breed names - Ankole, Bahima, Bashi, Kigezi, Kivu, Inkuku and Watusi - in central and eastern Africa. The Bahima have lovely black tipped horns that are the tallest. In Africa these breeds are also known as the Cattle of Kings and the Royal Ox. The variety with the largest horns were called Inyambo, owned by Royalty of the Tutsi people of Rwanda, but are believed extinct.  Watusi are an ancient breed, seen in the Nile Valley 4,000 years ago and in Egyptian paintings. In Africa they're rarely killed for meat, rather they are bled, this is mixed with their milk for a staple diet. Wealth is measured by the number of cattle kept, and gifted as bride dowry.  Sanga cattle of the Watusi type were sent to European zoos, but the breed not noted, so they got interbred. Two bulls were taken to America from Sweden in 1960, followed by a cow in 1963 from an English zoo. A careful grading up program started in America adding Bos taurus, usually from the Texas Longhorn. It required several generations of breeding back to the Watusi to be considered pure. The breed is now popular there, mainly for hunting and the sport of lasoo-ing, and the curiosity of their horns which is a good market for decor after slaughter, and alive, as camera herds. More recently, studies have proved the value of their excellent beef.  Reasonably safe in their homelands of Uganda, Rwanda and Burundi, their main threat is civil war, poverty and cross breeding to other breeds, often through government cattle improvement programs. It is in the conditions of their homeland they will continue to keep all their traits - but they are under direct threat - the population is shrinking fast. In 2010, Carlos Sere, a livestock expert in Africa told SciDevNet the Ankole would be gone from Africa within 50 years, due to the proliferation of Holstein-Friesians.  There's now a small population in Australia, popular as camera herds for their striking colours and horns, and for their beef. They are derived from American genetics.  Breed traits: Large horns, growing to the largest in the world. As the beast ages the horns grow thicker until they become heavy. The reason given for the horns is to dissipate heat - cooling the blood as it travels through the horns - hence this breed does not need the massive droopy ears and flopping dewlaps of other hot climate breeds. The horns are very warm to the touch due to the amount of blood in them. There have been no studies (I can find) on this temperature control, however it is stated on the Oklahoma State Uni website, Dept. of Animal Science.  Straight backline apart from a small hump. Good well covered frame, narrow through. Most hot climate breeds are deep but narrow through, naturally standing to expose less of their body to the heat, while having more surface area to dissipate it. All part of the cooling system. Most are a red colour, some mottled, patched, spotted and speckled. In Africa pure white ones are popular. Black, brindle, yellow and grey are also seen.  Long legs, they are also very agile, able to run and jump well as they are naturally flighty due to predators in their homelands; for this reason they are handled from very young to gain trust and tractability. Long thick tail to swat insects. Ears are smaller and go outward, unlike most pendulous zebu ears.  Horn shapes vary, some arching up like a lyre, others circular, others more rarely go straight out sideways and grow to ludicrous weights. In Africa straight sidewards horns are culled, lyre shaped ones going upward are preferred. The straight sidewards ones are more common in America, thought to be the result of Bos taurus blood such as Texas Longhorn - these make life difficult for the beast, being more strain on their muscles and making it impossible to lie down properly.  The most horn growth is in the first 5 or 6 years, by age 10 the horns start to thicken instead of lengthen - signs horns are still growing are red patches on them, usually at the base. The cattle are used to their horns and can mingle easily without getting tangled or hurting each other.  Udders are small and high, probably to avoid thorn damage or predator strike, however have ample milk for a calf, milk is very high in butterfat - an astounding 10%. Crosses to dairy cattle to boost butterfat have been successful in America.  Although milked in the African home countries they also need to provide for a calf and don't have enough for both purposes often, not being a strong milking strain; this resulted in calves dying as they were separated from the mothers and only allowed to drink after milking was over, when times were hard. Breeding to improve milk and beef production is underway, however it is hoped outside blood will not take over, rather a process of selection used.  Low birthweight calves mean ease of calving. Protective social groups sleep with adults on the outside with horns facing out, calves inside the circle. Mothers are very protective.  A very intelligent breed. Like many old breeds they can't be mustered like commercial cattle, rather domesticated animals are easily coaxed into following by offering feed, opening gates etc. Following rather than being chased is the method, that way the herd stays together as they prefer. A strong herd instinct means they panic if separated. Staying together and sleeping with horns out, protects them from lions. It is instinctive not to run from those chasing them, rather to fight back, or if they do run, to keep running a long time despite obstacles. Attempts in the late 20th century to keep these cattle in Australia were a failure due to not understanding their herd behaviour. They must be quietened from young, and will then work easily with those who understand them. They have a rolling gait when walking, as their heads nod with the weight of horns, however this is a natural gait as even calves who have not yet grown horns walk the same way.  Able to thrive in very hot conditions, and thrive on basic roughage. Being able to cover big distances, very heat tolerant, thrifty, and easy calvers, they offer a good cross for hot climate cattle, calves growing fast. The beef is lean. The cattle are meatier than other Bos indicus breeds, their muscles good and frame covered, and on good feed they grow good amounts of meat. Studies have proved the meat to be lowest in fat and cholesterol of other commercial breeds (Oklahoma State Uni) - thus healthy for consumers a good reason to maintain the breed, and an excellent trait for crossbreeding. The beef has less cholesterol than fish or skinned chicken.  Organisation: None found in Australia. The North American ones are the World Watusi Association http://www.watusi.org/2012/05/17/a-short-history-of-watusi-cattle/ and the Ankole-Watusi International Registry http://www.awir.org/.  Ankole are also bred in South Africa and registered, as a breed, with the Afrikaner Cattle Breeders Society of South Africa, ACBSSA, These are quality cattle. Leahton Park, also known as Texas Wagon Tours - 10k from Chartres Towers in Queensland - has started a breeding program, crossing some with Texas Longhorns by AI. The straws were from the USA. They started in 2015. By 2020 they had F2's and in 2022 are seeing F3's. An excellent place that fosters rare breeds that are horned and which pay their way through tourism.

Specific resistance or tolerance: A mild temperament.  A low birth weight and easy calving process.  A low incidence of abortions.  An exceptional mother instinct and self-protection.  Resistance against diseases, especially tick-borne diseases, due to (amongst others) a thick skin.  Fairly good resistance against internal parasites.  Good pigmentation, with resistance to ultraviolet radiation, photo-sensitivity and eye problems.  Heat resistance (which can be attributed to a loose skin as well as short and shiny blue-black hair colour which reflects sunlight). Refer to a study of Ms. Liesel Foster (2008) under guidance of Prof. Frikkie Neser (UOFS).  Resistance against ticks (reference: Ms. Liesl Foster's study and tick counts.  Strong legs and a bone structure with hard buffalo hooves, which improves walking comfort, even on rough terrain.  A good capacity for feed intake during grazing

Description of origin: The origins of the Drakensberger can be related back to the indigenous cattle of the Khoi and other indigenous groups of the Cape and adjacent areas. As early as 2 December 1497, Vasco da Gama mentioned the “fat, black ox” that he obtained in a trade. Only after the arrival of Jan van Riebeeck in 1652, specifically under governor Willem Adriaan van der Stel (around 1700), cattle farming caught on quickly. The influence of the local residents’ cattle certainly also deserves to be mentioned. After the battle of Vegkop in 1837 under guidance of Sarel Celliers, the Voortrekkers lost almost all of their cattle. Neighbouring trekkers of Thaba Nchu provided them with oxen but most animals were obtained by trading with king Mosjesj of the Basotho’s (in the current Lesotho). During the battle of Umfolozi on 26 December 1838, the Trekkers recovered most of their cattle, together with a number of the local Ngunis. The influence of the local black population’s cattle can therefore never be excluded from the history.

Other special qualities: The breed was initially developed in North Queensland to perform in a tropical environment subject to seasonal variation and to low protein in natural pastures during the dry season (Oct-Dec) and to counter the tick invasion that arrived in that part of Australia at the turn of the century. More recently it has been found useful in temperate climates because of its easy management, low fat and red meat, good temperament and value as cross-breeding stock.

Description: The Tarentaise originated in the rugged Savoie region of France, in the Tarentaise Valley in the French Alpine mountains (in 1859). This breed is considered to have experienced less mixing with other breeds in the last 100 years than with most French breeds.  Originally they were selected primarily for milk production when making their breeding decisions. Due to the habitat of this breed, it was naturally selected for muscling, hardiness and adaptability in order for them to live under range conditions in the French Alps, the result is a dual purpose breed.  Today, the french use the breed solely for milk production and for the making of Beaufort, a Gruyere-type cheese. The average production is 5,500 kilos (12,199 lbs) of milk in a 305 day lactation with no feed concentrates in the summer.  This breed is distinctive for its abundant muscling in the hip region, and they are exceptionally long from hooks to pins. Climbing at high altitudes is what makes their remarkable natural muscling and marbling, as well as endowing the breed with a very robust cardiovascular system. Characteristics  The Tarentaise coat is a tan colour with darkening around the eyes and sometimes on the neck of the bulls, they also have a black nose, udder and hooves. They are of a medium build and well muscled.  A Tarentaise cow is universally recognized for her moderate size, early maturity, large volume of milk and ease of calving. The dark pigmentation of the eyes, feet, and udders guard against pinkeye, cancer eye and sunburn.
Description of origin: The Tarentaise originated in the rugged Savoie region of France, in the Tarentaise Valley in the French Alpine mountains (in 1859). This breed is considered to have experienced less mixing with other breeds in the last 100 years than with most French breeds.
Location within country: Only herd in Australia is on the mid north coast of NSW

Description: Aberdeen Angus (Aberdeen Angus) is a breed of large horned cattle. Created in Scotland.
Description Of Specific Uses: Crossed to grade up the quality of meat.
Color comments: uni coloured: black
Additional performance parameters: The body of the Aberdeen-Angus cattle is covered with a weak layer of fat. Living mass of cows 500-700 kg, bulls - 750-1000 kg. Newborn calves weigh 22-25 kg (calves), 25-28 kg (bulls). Fertility of the breed is 95%. Murder output - 62-65%. The average annual yield is about 2000 kg of milk.

Description: It is milk-meat cattle breed. It is received as a result of Crossing of local Caucasian cattle with Swedish manufactured breed. It is authorized in 1960. During Crossing the blood of Azerbaijan zebu is also used. At present the breeding of this strain is being carried out in the direction of further improvement of the exteriors and increase of productivity qualities.
Other name: Caucasian Brown, Caucasus Brown, Azerbaijan Brown
Additional information: Data before independence refer to Former USSR. The breed is not homogenous and local variants do exist.
Adaptability to specific environment: The body structure and productivity quality have improved and its abili- ty to adaptation to the local condi- tions is kept. It is brown.
Color comments: multi coloured: brown with dark patchings
Description of origin: composite of Lesser Caucasus breed, Swiss Brown, Kastroma, Lebedin
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 5-6 months per year and fed on grazing and concentrates.
Additional performance parameters: The live weight of cows is 400-450 kg, Net meat weight is about 50-55 percent. it gives approximately 2000-2500 lt milk a year the fatness of which is 3,8-3,9 percent.

Description: Swiss breed: dairy-meat cattle breed. Homeland is Switzerland.
Additional performance parameters: Live weight of bulls is 800-950 kg (up to 1200 kg), and cows weigh 500-600 kg (up to 800 kg). Gives 900 grams of live weight gain per day under feeding conditions at 17-18 months. Swiss cattle have been used as breeding cattle for 600 years. Each cow produces an average of 4,500 liters of milk (3.7-3.8 percent fat). There are many Swiss cows in the United States that produce more than 10,000-11,000 lt of milk.

Description Of Specific Uses: Crossed to grade up the quality of milk and meat.
Location within country: Crossed in the foothill regions of Azerbaijan

Description: This is a French breed of taurine beef cattle.
Additional performance parameters: Weight of adult cows - 650-1100 kg, bulls - 950-1400 kg. The breed is large, often meets double hotels (4%). The weight of newborns is 42-50 kg, in 6 months - 220-250 kg, in 1.5 years - 390-460 kg. Growth - 800-1600 gr. in days. Murder output - 60-71%. Meat of high quality, yielding about 80%. Milk productivity - 1800-2700 kg of milk, fat content - 4.0%.

Description: The Galloway breed is a breed of large horned cattle of the meat direction. One of the oldest breeds, bred in the 17th century in Galloway, Scotland. The Galloway breed is one of the oldest specialized beef breeds. It was bred in Scotland in the county of Galloway in the 19th century. Initially, the cattle was meat and dairy direction, as a result of selection it became only meat.
Description Of Specific Uses: Crossed to grade up the quality of meat.
Adaptability to specific environment: high adaptability to any climatic conditions - from harsh to tropical. high disease resistance. / the ability to graze all year round, even in winter, in the absence of heavy snow.
Color comments: uni coloured: black
Additional performance parameters: The live weight of cows is 450-500 kg, bulls - 700-800 kg. The average annual milk yield is 1500 kg. The fat content in milk is 4.0%. Calves are born small, in the first months they grow slowly, then intensively. Galloway cows have the highest calf survival rate of 95.2%. Slaughter yield - 60-65%. The average annual milk yield is 1500 kg. The fat content in milk is 4.0%. The coat is hard, with a wavy thin undercoat. The length of the hairs reaches 20 cm.

Description of origin: variety of Caucasian, subvariety of Lesser Caucasian

Description: The Hereford is a beef cattle originating from the British county of Herefordshire.
Additional performance parameters: Living mass of cows 550-650 kg, mass of bulls 850-1000 kg. Medium-sized udoy is 1000-1200 kg. The fat content of milk is 3.9-4%. At birth calves weigh 25-28 kg, bulls 28-34 kg. With intensive growth of bulls for 1 year reach a mass of 400 kg. Meat is tender, juicy, high-calorie, "marble". The specific weight of soft flesh is 82-84%. Murder output is 58-70%. But milk, the fat content of which does not exceed 4%, cows give no more than 1200 liters per year. In winter, a cow can give a maximum of 12-14 liters of milk, the number of milk yields in the summer is about 15-20 liters of milk per day. If you choose the right feed, you can increase the number of milk yields.

Description: Although native to the Frisian region of the Netherlands, the German state of Holstein gave its name to this genus.
Description Of Specific Uses: Deeply freezing sperm is used for increasing milk productivity and milk fatness.
Adaptability to specific environment: Well adapted to the local environment.
Additional performance parameters: Live weight in males: 1200 kg. In females: 1st lactation (birth) - 650 kg; 2nd lactation (childbirth) - 750 kg. Live weight of calves: 33-38 kg. Daily weight gain: 1000-1300 grams. Meat yield: 50-55%. Milk yield during lactation: 8000-8500 liters. Percentage of fat in milk: 3.9 - 4.1%, percentage of protein: 3.45%.

Description: The Jersey breed was bred in England on the island of Jersey by improving the local Norman and British cattle and selecting them for their fat milk content.
Additional performance parameters: Bulls 600-700 kg, cows 360-400 kg; meat cutting yield 55-60%; On average 5,000-5,500 lt. of milk is produced per cow; fat content of milk 5.0-6.0% (sometimes up to 7%); protein is 4.0 percent.

Description: Kalmyk (cow breed) Kalmyk is a breed of large horned cattle meat production. Created through the improvement of local cattle, which arrived in Kalmykia from Western Mongolia in the XVII century.
Additional performance parameters: The live weight of an adult cow is 420-480 kg, a sire is 750-950 kg. Lactation 8-9 months. The fertility of the breed is 85-95%. Newborn calves weigh 20-25 kg. Carcasses contain up to 70% muscle tissue, 10% fat. Slaughter yield - 57% -60%. The average annual milk yield is 650-1500 kg, milk fat content is 4.2-4.4%.

Description: Kostroma breed-milk-meat breed or meat-milk direction. The Kostroma breed was bred at the Karavaevo farm in the Kostroma region and is considered one of the best in Russia. In the 19th century, local cows were crossed with Kholmogory bulls, and later with Wilstermarsh, Simmental, Ayrshire and Brown Swiss breeds. As a result of such crossing, Miskovsky and Babaevsky cattle appeared. In 1911-1918. Swiss bulls were crossed several times with crossbreeds of the first generations. In 1918-1940. at the state farm, work was underway to improve the Kostroma breed. Since 1940, cattle began to be distributed outside the region. The Kostroma breed of the dairy-meat type of productivity was approved as an independent breed in 1944.
Additional performance parameters: The weight of an adult cow of the Kostroma breed is 500-650 kg, some reach 800 kg; weight of bulls - 800-950 (sometimes up to 1000-1200) kg. The weight of newborn calves is about 40 kg, the weight of one-year-old calves is 260 kg, and in a year and a half - 350-400 kg. The growth of calves is 1300 gr. per day. Slaughter yield - 61-65%. Meat yield - 83%. Meat quality is good. Milk productivity - 3900-5000 kg on average, fat content 3.5-3.9%, the best cows give up to 7000 kg of milk, fat content 4.18-4.19%. They have fat milk content and unique taste qualities of meat products.

Description Of Specific Uses: Crossed to grade up the quality of milk.
Location within country: Crossed in the cotton-grain-sowing, irrigated areas

Description: It came from Schwitsky cattle, has good dairy and meat indicators, is famous for high growths of live weight. Lebedinskaya Breed is bred in the Sumy region of Ukraine when crossing local late -ripening steppe breeds with Schwitsky cattle, followed by breeding “in itself”. The selection of this cattle began back in 1902, when the bulls of the Schwitsky breed began to be imported to the lands of the Kharkov province. The Lebedinsky breed was approved in 1950
Additional performance parameters: This breed is characterized by a high growth rate, the live weight of heifers at birth is 34-38 kg, in half a year 190-205 kg, in a year 300-330 kg. The weight of cows is 600-650 kg, bulls 950-1000 kg. Cattle have good meat qualities. The slaughter yield is 53-62%. The milk productivity of cows of the Lebedinsky breed is 3200-5000 kg per year with a fat content of 3.7-3.9%. There are cases of more than 12,600 kg of milk per lactation with a fat content of 4.2% and a protein level of 3.0-3.5%.

Description: Limousine is a French breed of meat cattle from the regions of Limousine and Marche in France.
Additional performance parameters: Living mass of cows reaches 580-600 kg, bulls 1000-1100 kg. Fertility of cattle is 90-95%. Calves are born large, but not broad-shouldered, with a mass of 34-42 kg. Living mass of the body, grown in the pod, reaches 240-300 kg for 6-8 months. Murder output 63-65%. The average annual yield is 1500-1800 kg. The fat content of milk is 4.8-5%.

Description: The red Gazakh cattle are kept in small amount in farms of the people of Ağstafa, Gazakh, Tovuz and Gedebey regions.
Provision Uses: Hair or feathers for fishing lures, Meat, Milk
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Vegetation management
Adaptability to specific environment: also has the ability to withstand heavy local conditions and high output of feathers.
Additional performance parameters: The average live weight of cows is 380-400kg, and the live weight of bulls is 450- 500 kg. Net meat weight of young cattle exceeds 50 percent. . Milk productivity of cows during lactation period makes up 1900- 2000 lt, milk fatness is 4,2-4,6 percent on average.

Description: Widespread in many European countries.
Adaptability to specific environment: Tolerant of hot and cold climates.
Additional performance parameters: The live weight of bulls is 800-1000 kg, and that of cows is 550-650 kg. An average of 3,500-4,000 kg of milk is produced per cow per year, and meat production is 55-60%. . Milk contains 3.8-4.0 percent fat.

Description: Azerbaijan zebu are reared in Lenkoran-Astara zones of the republic.
Other name: Azerbaidzhanskii Zebu, Caucasian Zebu, Talysh, Talyshinskii, Azerbaijan Zebu
Additional information: Data before independence refer to Former USSR. The breed is being extensively crossed to upgrade other breeds of cattle. However, a number of pure-bred animals are being kept for this purpose.
Adaptability to specific environment: It is black and dark-brown colors with a clear hump on a back. Azerbaijan zebu and its hybrids are resistant to the local conditions and diseases. /
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is reported to be tick resistant.
Special characteristic of product: High quality of milk. Milk protein is 3,7-4,2
Color comments: uni coloured: usually red, black multi coloured: pied
Other specific visible traits: Zebu, large dewlap
Location within country: found in Lenkoran-Astara region and Ganja-Khazax region
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data was collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 5 months per year and fed on concentrates.
Additional performance parameters: Along with being early fast- ripening, the average weight of Azerbaijan zebu is 300-310 kg, net meat output is about 58,8-60 percent. On average it gives more than 500 lt of milk a year. Fatness of its milk is 5-6 percent.

Description: Cuban zebu was brought to Azerbaijan during the USSR. It spread rapidly to Latin America, Cuba, Australia, and New Zealand, and dominated European cattle, laying the foundation for the creation of new breeds and types. Meat and meat-dairy direction.
Description Of Specific Uses: Crossed with local cattle breeds to grade up the quality of meat and milk.
Additional performance parameters: The live weight of Cuban zebu cows is 300-350 kg, bulls 500-600 kg. The yield of pure meat reaches 55-58%. The lactation period is 5-6 months. Gives an average of 400-600 liters of milk per year. The fat content of milk is 5-5.5%.

Color comments: uni coloured: brown/dark red
Other specific visible traits: moderate size hump
Description of origin: indigenous breed zebu X taurine type

Color comments: multi coloured: black, blue, white
Other specific visible traits: double muscling
Description of origin: local Breed of Middle and Upper Belgium

Other name: Race de la Moyenne et Haute Belgique, White Blue Dual Purpose, Witblauw mixte

Breed/Most common name: Pie rouge de l`Est de la Belgique
Other name: Pie rouge Ardennes-Liège, Pie rouge du Pays de Herve, Eastern Red Pied
Additional information: 2006: extinct due to Holsteinization - Holstein gene infusion with no will to conserve the native breed;
Description of origin: former name for Red Pied (Meuse-Rhine-Yssel) in Eupen and Malmédy. Included in Belgian Red Pied

Other name: Eastern Black Pied, Pie-noire de l`Est de la Belgique, Zwartbont ras van Oost-België, Zwartbont ras van het Land van Herve, Herve Black Pied
Additional information: 2006: extinct due to Holsteinization - Holstein gene infusion with no will to conserve the native breed.
Description of origin: originated from Dutch Friesian x local red pied since 1860. Herd-book 1919. Fused with Polders Black Pied 1966 to form Belgian Black Pied

Description: The Red breed type dubbeldoel is a dual-purpose breed, whose animals are able to obtain the majority of production (milk and meat) from extensive conditions. In 2019 "Vlees van het rood ras van West-Vlaanderen" (fresh meat and offal obtained from the ‘Red’ breed of cattle bred and reared in the province of West Flanders) was registered as a Protected Designation of Origin.
Additional information: 1994: These figures include a high number of cross-breds.
Color comments: uni coloured: red multi coloured: red and white

Description: The animals are used purely for meat production, known for its excellent quality. These red cattle is characterized by a very gentle nature. In 2019 "Vlees van het rood ras van West-Vlaanderen" (fresh meat and offal obtained from the ‘Red’ breed of cattle bred and reared in the province of West Flanders) was registered as a Protected Designation of Origin.

Color comments: multi coloured: red, white
Import: from Pie-Rouge (Netherlands), Rotbunte (Germany) and Red Holstein Friesian (USA)

Color comments: multi coloured: red, white

Other name: Pie-noire des Polders, Polders Black Pied
Additional information: 2006: extinct due to Holsteinization - Holstein gene infusion with no will to conserve the native breed;
Description of origin: joined with Hervé Black Pied 1966 to form Belgian Black Pied

Color comments: multi coloured: black, white

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to a harsh climate.
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is reported to be trypanotolerant.
Color comments: uni coloured: white often with black points, occasionally black spots or brown and white
Other specific visible traits: small hump or humpless
Description of origin: composite of Zebu (mainly White Fulani) and West African Shorthorn (Somba or Lagune)
Performance data reference: F20(1) -109 F20(2) 190-191 A13-46 FAO Breed Survey Auer C. & Auer T (1983) Traditionelle Rinderhaltung in Zentral Benin. Entwickhung + Landlicher Raum, 17 Jahrgang, heft 3, 1983.
Comments management conditions: In Benin two management systems are practiced: a) transhumant: involving 80% of the cattle in the northern part; b) stationary: mainly in the peri-village areas. The carcass weight in this report refers to the mean of 24 males.
Additional performance parameters: - age at weaning 5-7 months; Weight at one year (mean of 5 females) : 79 kg

Location within country: Breeding farms of Kpinnou and Okpara
Cities of Mallanville and Karimama in extreme north of Benin.

Other name: Mayombe, Mayumbe, Race des lagunes, Lagunaires
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is reported to be trypanotolerant.
Color comments: multi coloured: black, white
Other specific visible traits: very small cattle, short legged
Description of origin: variety of West African Dwarf Shorthorn: Lagune is the name used for Dwarf Shorthorn cattle in French-speaking West and Central Africa.

Other name: Boyenca, Fouta Jallon, Fouta Longhorn, Futa, Malinke, Mandingo, N'dama Peti, Outa Malinke, Boenca
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer
Adaptability to specific environment: The animals can survive under very humid conditions.
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is reported to be trypanotolerant.
Other special qualities: The animals are well known for their hardiness and rusticity.
Color comments: uni coloured: usually fawn, red or brown, occasionally or black multi coloured: occasionally pied
Other specific visible traits: small animals

Color comments: uni coloured: red
Other specific visible traits: Similar to Somba
Description of origin: variety of West African Savannah Shorthorn, absorbed by Borgou

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to live under the difficult climatic conditions of Atacora.
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is reported to be trypanotolerant. Somba breed comprises of the following biochemical characterisation: Haemoglobin: Type AA, Albumin: Type FF, Transférine: Type AD, DD, or AA.
Color comments: uni coloured: black multi coloured: black and red pied
Other specific visible traits: humpless, small, stocky body
Description of origin: variety of West African Savannah Shorthorn
Location within country: Natitingou, Tanguieta in the Atakora Highlands, north-western Benin
Comments management conditions: There is a lack of water in the dry season. Somba cattle are raised in two kind of systems. Both are sedentary. The 'troupeau familial' or tata-based herd is the traditional form: three to ten animals are supervised on pasture by children and returned at night to the tata. The 'troupeau confie' or Fulani-supervised herd characterized by fourty to one hundred heads of cattle owned by five to thirty proprietors entrusted to a Fulani herdsman, who has the right to milk the cows.

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is known for hardiness towards living conditions in the hot, humid tropics.
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is reported to be tolerant to trypanosomiasis and tick-borne diseases.
Reference for special qualities: Reviewed by G.S.Aboagye et al.; World Animal Review, n.78, 1994/1
Color comments: uni coloured: black multi coloured: black with white patches
Horn shape size and comments: males: crown, half-moon or hook shaped females: smaller horns than in males
Description of origin: variety of West African Savannah Shorthorn
Performance data reference: F20(2) -120 FAO Breed Survey W78 F78-33, 48
Management conditions performance measur: Available information on production characteristics of this breed have been compiled and reviewed for animals kept under different management conditions.

Description: Gourounsi cattle

Color comments: uni coloured: black multi coloured: pied
Description of origin: variety of West African Savannah Shorthorn: Although the name Lobi is widely used for the Savanna Shorthorn cattle in Burkina Faso, these cattle are quite similar to the Baoule of Côte d'Ivoire.

Other name: Bambara, Djakoré, Taurin du Kaarta, Mande
Color comments: uni coloured: yellow-brown to red
Description of origin: composite of N'Dama and Sudanese Fulani (zebu): The population is almost stabilized with respect to its composition of Zebu and N'Dama.

Other name: Boyenca, Fouta Jallon, Fouta Longhorn, Futa, Malinke, Mandingo, N'dama Peti, Outa Malinke, Boenca
Adaptability to specific environment: The animals can survive under very humid conditions.
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is reported to be trypanotolerant.
Other special qualities: The animals are well known for their hardiness.
Color comments: uni coloured: usually fawn, red or brown, occasionally or black multi coloured: occasionally pied
Other specific visible traits: small animals

Comments management conditions: well adapted to production system and environment

Other specific visible traits: Zebu, small to dwarf
Performance data reference: FAO Breed Survey Ahmed, Z.; Islam, T.S (1987) Cattle breeding prgramme through artificial insemination in Bangladesh. AI extension project report. Namikawa, T.; Tsubota, Y.; Amano, T.; Hasnath, M.A.; Mostafa, K.G.; Farugue, M.O.; Mazid, M.A. (1984) Coat colour variations, body conformation, blood groups and blood protein polymorphisms in the local cattle population in Bangladesh. In: Genetic studies on breed differentiation of the native domestic animals in Bangladesh. Tokyo University of Agriculture, Japan. 11-24.
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were measured on a sample of 197 animals at the Savar Dairy Farm in Bangladesh under stationary conditions with housing all year round and grazing and concentrate as feeding base.

Adaptability to specific environment: The animals have high adaptation efficiency without much health problems under low input system.
Other special qualities: This is a very hardy breed.
Color comments: uni coloured: red
Other specific visible traits: Zebu, smaller variety of Bengal
Location within country: common in Greater Chittagong District and Chittagong Hill Tract Region
Performance data reference: FAO Breed Survey Hasnath, M.A. (1974) Studies on crossbred cattle. Research Bulletin 1. Department of Animal Breeding and Genetics. Mymensingh, B.A.U. (1982) 2. Government Report of the Standing Committee for Breeding and Improvement. Cattle Breeding and improvement policy of Bangldesh. Dls, Khamarbari Road, Farmgate, Dhaka-1215.
Management conditions performance measur: Performance was measured on a sample of 20 animals on station. The animals were housed and fed based on grazing and concentrate.
Comments management conditions: Roadside grazing & stall fed mainly with straw diets

Other specific visible traits: Zebu
Description of origin: similar to the Hariana breed, distinctiveness disappeared after cross-breeding with Sahiwal, Sindhi & Friesian
imported from Australia; semen continually imported from Pakistan, Australia, New Zealand and Germany

Description Of Specific Uses: used as sacrifice animals. Gayal is also a zoo animal.
Adaptability to specific environment: The animals are reported to be very hardy and capable of thriving well on the natural habitat in the hilly forest.
Color comments: multi coloured: dark slate in coloured with white stockings below the knees comment: Calves are born dark red in coloured which turns into the characteristic coloured by 6 months of age. They have a dorsal ridge on the crest of the shoulder
Other specific visible traits: short tail, big dewlap, flat forehead
Description of origin: domesticated Gaur (Bos bibos frontalis). feral animal of Bovidae family.
Location within country: feral animal of Bovidae family found only in the forest of Bandarban district located in the south-eastern part of Bangladesh.
Management conditions performance measur: Performance has been recorded on 5 animals recorded on a station with all year round housing and grazing and concentrate feeding.
Comments management conditions: In Bangladesh most Gayal are wild and a few are reared by tribal people. The animals browse on forest forages under wild conditions.

Description of origin: imported from Australia; exotic; discarded from crossbreeding programme after 1982

Other specific visible traits: Zebu

Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is reported to have a good disease resistance.
Color comments: uni coloured: reddish, whiteish
Other specific visible traits: Zebu
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were measured under stationary conditions with housing 8 months per year and grazing and forage available.

Color comments: comments: light reddish coloured
Other specific visible traits: Zebus With A Broad Forehead
Description of origin: probably originated from local Bengali x Red Sindhi: disappeared after crossing with Sahiwal and Friesian
Comments management conditions: Winter fodder (Nov to Feb) + Stall fed/Roadside grazing & stall fed mainly with straw diets

Color comments: uni coloured: red, grey multi coloured: mixture red and grey
Other specific visible traits: Zebu
Description of origin: This variety evolved by breeding indigenous Bengali cows with bulls (Hariana and Sahiwal) introduced by the Bengal Governor Lord Linglithgow in early 1900.
Performance data reference: FAO Breed Survey Hussain, S.M.I., M.N. Islam, A.K.M.A. Mannan and A. Wadud. 1984. Effect of feeding urea streated and centreated rice straw on fat, solids not fat and total solids content of milk of Pabna cows. Bay. J. Anim. Sci. Vol 13 (1 and 2).
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from 34 animals kept 7 months housed per year and fed on grazing and concentrates.
Comments management conditions: Winter fodder (Nov to May)

Other name: Lola, Montgomery, Multani, Teli, Lambi Bar
Specific resistance or tolerance: The animals are reported to show resistance to tick borne diseases.
Special characteristic of product: This is an excellent dairy breed.
Color comments: uni coloured: rarely white multi coloured: usually reddish-dun usually with white markings
Other specific visible traits: Zebu
Performance data reference: N2-56 N3-60 F66-49 FAO Breed Survey
Management conditions performance measur: Performance was measured on animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 12 months per year and fed on fodder and concentrates. Performance data were taken from Government farms/research institutes where records are kept as a routine practice and therefore considered good.
Comments management conditions: The breed is usually found in the irrigated regions where there is a good supply of water.
Additional performance parameters: There is a progeny testing programme underway to produce high potential bulls.

Description of origin: imported from Pakistan; exotic; discarded from crossbreeding programme after 1972

Description Of Specific Uses: For meat; industrial-scale crossbreeding with milk breeds, mainly in the Rhodope mountains
Adaptability to specific environment: The animals efficiently assimilate the voluminous forages and are excellent pasture animals.
Special characteristic of product: The animals produce qualitative marbled meat.
Other specific visible traits: The animals are short, stumpy with deep and broad chests, barrel-shaped, with a prominent forechest. The body is well-rounded with well-developed muscles, harmonious, compact, with a good rectangular shape. The head is small, with a slightly concaved profile, a protruding sharp occipital crest. The neck is short with well-developed muscles. The thighs are deep, roomy and protruding. They reach the hocks.
Description of origin: imported; Pure-breed breeding of the local primitive Black Hornless Cattle through inbreeding. The region of the breed development is characterized by a humid climate and pasture-breeding on hilly terrains.

Description: The name means Bulgarian red cattle
Other specific visible traits: The Bulgarian Red belongs to the medium sized dairy breeds. The head is medium sized and long, with thin and long neck. The withers are narrow and high, the back is long, the loin is long and semi-wide. The croup is long, broad and flat. The chest is deep, but relatively narrow. The abdomen is large, but not pendulous. The limbs are normally attached, but animals with sickle-hocked rear limbs are also found. The bones are thin and the muscles are not well-developed, resulting in angular body shape. The skin is thin, elastic, easy to lift.
Description of origin: Developed by complex reproductive crossing. Initially, the Red Sadovo Cattle breed was developed, which was then used along with Danish red and Angler bulls in the development of the Bulgarian Red Cattle, a breed intended for the South and Northeastern Bulgaria. The Red Danish cattle was mainly used for improvement of the new breed

Description: The name means Bulgarian Brown Cattle
Other name: Bulgarian Brown Cattle, Българско кафяво говедо
Description of origin: Developed by reproductive and backcrossing of the local gray cattle with brown swiss bulls.

Description: named after Rhodope mountain
Other name: Българско родопско говедо, Bulgarian Rhodope Cattle
Description Of Specific Uses: The Bulgarian Rhodope Cattle is the breed of the highest relative milk yield, the highest milk concentration, the highest fertility and the most continuous use in the country. It has an excellent adaptive capacity and extremely high ecological plasticity.
Efabis main colour: Non-typized, basically light redbrown (deer-like) and gray. Individuals of white spots on various parts of the body and even red-pied animals are often found.
Other specific visible traits: A typical representative of the small cattle breeds for milk. The animals have gentle, compact, strong construction and graceful, fine, light body forms. The head is light, comparatively broad-foreheaded, finely cut, with big vivid eyes and widely open nostrils. The body is deep, elongated and slightly built. The chest is comparatively long and deep but narrow. The bones are well developed; the legs are strong, with well-developed tendons and a strong hoof horn.
Description of origin: Initially, by reproductive crossing between the Rhodope shorthorn cattle with the local Gray cattle, Sofia Brown cattle, Oberinntal cattle, etc., and, later on, with Jersey as the most often used breed in the improvement programmes
Location within country: The Rhodopes. Isolated herds throughout the country.
Management system: Extensive (non back yard), Intensive, Semi Intensive

Description of origin: The breed was developed by continuous (40-50 years) random crossing of the local gray cattle from Northwest Bulgaria with Simmental bulls of Swiss and Yugoslavian origin. Thus, the Kulsko Cattle was developed. At a later stage the Bulgarian Simmental Cattle breed was developed by reproductive crossing of the Kulsko and Gray Iskar Cattle breeds, and systematic and purposeful breeding improvement work.
Location within country: Northwest, North central Bulgaria and some regions in South Bulgaria

Description: Balgarsko sivo govedo means Bulgarian Gray Cattle
Other name: Bulgarian Gray Cattle, Gray cattle, Българско сиво говедо
Adaptability to specific environment: The millennia-long breeding of those animals under the same conditions explains their incredible resistance to the unfavorable environmental factors.
Other special qualities: The Bulgarian Gray Cattle individuals are low-productive, late-maturing animals of limited possibilities of growth.
Efabis main colour: Gray, with shades of dark to light gray, rarely yellowish; in the bulls the forepart of the body is coloured darker, reaching to
Other specific visible traits: The size of animals is medium. They have compact and tough bones, powerful muscles fit for work and strong tendons. The animals of the breed have a tough body construction, high adaptability to environmental conditions, good fertility and they are famous for their long life.
Location within country: In the mountains Strandzha, Sakar, the Central Balkan, Sashtinska Sredna Gora, Rila, the Rhodopes and in the regions of Shumen and Varna.

Description: The largest size breed for milk production, with a fine and compact construction. The head is elongated, dry and gentle. The muzzle is broad with widely open nostrils. The horns are medium long. The body shapes are elongated, angular, with under-developed muscles. The neck is medium long to long, shallow and thin, with numerous clearly outlined skin folders. The back is straight, long and medium broad. The croup is well-developed, medium long to long, broad and straight. The ribs are slantwise positioned towards the dorsal line, with wellexpressed and wide intercostal zones. The limbs are thin and dry. The hooves have a regular shape and size. The dairy features are expressed very well. The udder is voluminous, trough- or goblet-shaped, widely attached high at the rear part. The teats are of optimal length, usually cylindrical in shape. Normally their tips are dark coloured. The tail is medium long to long, ending in a welloutlined white tuft. The animals demonstrate very good adaptive and acclimatization capacities, but they have high food requirements.
Description Of Specific Uses: Breed specialized for milk production.
Efabis main colour: Black-and-white or red-and-white (rr). The black and the red are not dominant body colours. Variants with prevailing pigmented or white coloration are also to be found.
Description of origin: Assimilative crossing of cows of the breeds Bulgarian Brown Cattle, Bulgarian Red Cattle and Simmental with European Holstein Frisien (until 1970) and American Holstein Frisien bulls (after 1970), as well as by extended reproduction of introduced pure-blood Black and White cows from different European countries.
Location within country: All over the country, except the Rhodope region.

Description: The animals are large, having typical exterior traits and construction of the combined dairy and beef breeds. The head is medium. The body structure is proportional. The limbs are normally attached with tough bones, good musculature and a firm hoof horn. The udder is well developed, usually gobletshaped. The hair coat is short. The calves are gray-white at birth. At the age of 2-3-months they become gray-black and latter on they become graybrown. The female animals have an excellent shape of the udder and teats for machine milking. The fat and protein contents are extremely favorable. The male calves are very good for fattening; they have good daily gain and high slaughter output. The breed adapts quickly to various breeding systems and climatic conditions. The animals demonstrate long lifespan and continuous productivity that are very important traits in the evaluation of the breed efficiency.
Description Of Specific Uses: The milk is of high quality, with the highest content of kappa casein В, which makes it very suitable for cheese-production. The meat is tender, pink-red, marbled, of good taste qualities.
Description of origin: Reproductive and assimilation crossing of local gray cows with bulls of Brown Alpine cattle breed imported from Switzerland, Germany and Austria. Later on, bulls of Brown American cattle breed were used in the breed formation.
Location within country: Throughout the country, mainly in Sevlievo, Veliko Tarnovo and Yambol regions

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed has good adaptability, calm temperament and it is suitable to be bred under the conditions of different breeding technologies.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The ease of calving is 92%.
Other specific visible traits: The animals are large with a comparatively small and short head. The forehead and the muzzle are wide. The head profile is comparatively straight. The neck is short, and the chest is broad and deep. The withers are low, bifurcated and well-muscled. The back line is straight. The loin is wide and the croup and the hips are well-developed, wide and muscled. The back is often soft. The skin is medium-thin but elastic. The bones are thick, tough and rough. The body structure is large and clumsy with a well-developed rear part. Good gain in weight until adulthood. The breed does not accumulate fats, but the muscles are rougher. Milk characteristics are underrepresented.
Description of origin: imported; In the valley of the Arconce river, region of Charolais-Brion, from local large cattle, used as draught animals. Later on, it was crossbred with Shorthorns with the aim of using the new breed for meat production. The breed prefers a mild climate and good pastures.

Location within country: Sliven, Burgas, Vidin, Smolian and Blagoevgrad regions.

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is unpretentious and easily adaptable.
Special characteristic of product: High-quality meat is produced when pasture-bred.
Efabis main colour: Dark red; the head, the lower part of the neck, the forechest, the abdomen, the legs and the tail tuft are white.
Horn shape size and comments: Short, thick and curved down on both sides of the head or hornless
Other specific visible traits: A medium-sized breed. The body is proportional, deep and broad, with strong muscles over the back, the loin, the croup and the hips. The head is broad and light with medium long and thick horns. The neck is short with well-developed muscles. The breasts are deep, broad and barrel-shaped, with well-developed and prominent forechest. The limbs are short, widely attached and tough. The skin is thick and loose, covered with long, rough hairs. The construction is firm.
Description of origin: imported; In Herefordshire, by crossbreeding of a local small red cattle with a large Welsh cattle in a hilly region of rich grasslands

Location within country: Regions of Plovdiv, Haskovo, Burgas, Smoljan, and Stara Zagora

Special characteristic of product: The meat is juicy, poor in fat, with thin layers of fat and optimal ratio between red meat ant fat.
Horn shape size and comments: The horns are fine, slightly curved forward.
Other specific visible traits: The bred is characterized by a large, strong muscular body, a short head, broad forehead and muzzle. The neck is short. The chest is broad and rounded. The croup is wide and the rear part of the body is muscular and rounded. The abdomen, the inner side of the thighs and the legs, the udder and the eye orbits are lighter in colour. The bones are thin, the legs are short and the musculature is evenly developed along the whole body. Black and hornless forms of the breed were also established.
Description of origin: imported; Purposeful breeding of the local Aquitaine cattle in the unproductive poor pastures on the broken terrains in the region of the western woodland areas of Central France, characterized by great temperature fluctuations.
Location within country: Single herds are kept in Bulgaria in the lowland parts of the country

Specific resistance or tolerance: The breed is highly resistant to mastitis. It displays an excellent meat performance.
Special characteristic of product: The milk has an optimal fat to protein ratio for cheese production.
Other special qualities: The good adaptability is an advantage of the breed. It is an alternative of the specialized dairy breeds.
Efabis main colour: Red-and-white, the white colour covering the lower part of the body and the periphery (head, legs and tail). The red colour dominates on the upper part of the body. It is intensive, even closer to dark-red. The white head and the red spots around the eyes and jaws are generally tolerated.
Other specific visible traits: The breed has a typical exterior of the combined milk and beef breeds. Animals have a large, deep and wide body. The head is relatively small, wider at the eye orbits. It has a straight profile line, a wide muzzle, a fine neck and throat, well-developed wide shoulder-blades, a broad thorax and a straight dorsal line. The croup is broad and the tail is medium long. The legs are well-constructed, the thighs are wide and compact. The shanks are slightly slanted. The udder is trough-shaped, widely attached high at the rear, having well-developed quarters. The teats are medium-sized, cylindrical and positioned in the middle of the quarters. They are proportional, slightly pointing inward.

Description: Rodopsko kasorogo govedo means Rhodope Shorthorn Cattle
Other name: Rhodope Shorthorn Cattle, Родопско късорого говедо
Efabis adaptability to marginal land: Very well adapted to the steep slopes of the mountains.
Efabis main colour: Non-typized – brown-black, brown, black, gray, yellow
Horn shape size and comments: The horns are thin, fragile, of small circumference at the base and even thickness along the length.
Other specific visible traits: A typical representative of the breeds for milk production. A small, elongated and well-constructed body. A fine compact construction; wedge-shaped; gentle, dry and slightly muscular angular body forms. The head is medium big, proportional to body, elongated, narrow and dry, with a slightly concave profile line. The forehead is long and comparatively broad, narrowing between the horns, resembling a pyramid truncated almost at the base. The dorsal line parts are medium long, thin and slightly muscular. The croup is well-developed. The chest is comparatively long and narrow. The limbs are thin with well-developed joints and tendons, a strong hoof horn.
Description of origin: Folk breeding of the primitive brachyceros cattle, under highland conditions, poor pastures, changeable climatic conditions and broken terrains
Location within country: Eastern Rhodopes, mainly in the municipalities of Krumovgrad, Momchilgrad, Zlatograd and Madzharovo

Adaptability to specific environment: It adapts very well under various environmental, climatic and breeding conditions.
Specific resistance or tolerance: highly resistant to diseases
Specific reproductive characteristic: excellently developed mother instinct
Special characteristic of product: soft meat
Other special qualities: The breed is characterized by the rapid growth, high milk performance and calm temperament.
Efabis main colour: The colour varies from golden-yellow to red, with white spots on different parts of the body. The head is white. Often white stripes pass along the forequarter
Other specific visible traits: The animals have a classical large-sized body construction typical of a combined breed for meat and milk production, with well-developed lactation features and rich musculature. The head is relatively big and broad. Most of the animals have pigmentation around the eyes. The neck is medium long with a well-developed dewlap. The chest is deep and wide, the abdomen is barrel-shaped, the ribs are roundarched, wide and long, the limbs have strong bones and they are correctly positioned. The udder is well-developed, widely attached high at the rear part, reaching well forward to the abdomen. The teats are long and thick.
Description of origin: imported; Simmental cattle are a Swiss breed, which originated under the conditions of the lush Alpine pastures. The extinct Kula Cattle was the first simmentalized breed in our country. It was developed in North-Western Bulgaria by random crossing of the local gray cattle with Simmental bulls, mainly of Serbian and Swiss origin. At a later stage, the Bulgarian Simmental Cattle breed was created by reproductive and assimilative crossing.
Location within country: North-Western and North Central Bulgaria, in some regions of South Bulgaria.

Description of origin: imported from Hungary, Austria, Germany and the Netherlands
Location within country: Alpine Brown and its crosses with Busha cattle have been well accepted by farmers in hilly regions of the Central and South West Bosnia. and its crosses with Busha cattle have been well accepted by farmers in hilly regions of the Central and South West Bosnia.

Additional information: 2003: The local Busha breed has been almost extinct. During the war, a nucleus herd of the purebred Busha, established by the UPI combine near Sarajevo, has been destroyed together with the entire documentation.
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to karst regions and hilly regions.
Other special qualities: These are hardy animals.
Color comments: uni coloured: blue, brown
Horn shape size and comments: fine horns curved upwards and forward
Description of origin: indigenous breed. Belongs to the family of the European short horn cattle (Bos brachyceros europeus, Ruetimeyer). Today's Busa was probably created by crossbreeding the indigenous breed brachiceros cattle and shorthorn cattle brought by migrating peoples from the Northeast (Alpine brown, Tyrolean grey and Pinzgau cattle).
Location within country: mountains of Bosnia, Herzegovina, Serbia, Montenegro

Additional information: 2003: Number of these animals, as well as their location and production and breeding data are not available today.
Description of origin: imported mainly for large state farms; In 1997, 650 Frisian and Holstein types were imported, financed from an IFAD loan and was coordinated by the Project Implementation Unit of the Federal Ministry of Agriculture.

Additional information: 2003: The Gatacko breed, pure Tyrolean Grey and crossbreed of this type represent some 10 to 15 percent of the total cattle population.
Adaptability to specific environment: well adapted to local conditions and local production systems.
Color comments: uni coloured : grey
Other specific visible traits: Gatacko is slightly heavier than Busa. Body length is 115 cm.
Description of origin: Tyrolean Grey x local cows of the Busa type
Location within country: areas of Gacko, Stolac, Nevesinje, Trnovo, Sarajevo and Mostar

Additional information: 2003: Number of these animals, as well as their location and production and breeding data are not available today.
Description of origin: imported mainly for large state farms; In 1997, 650 Frisian and Holstein types were imported, financed from an IFAD loan and was coordinated by the Project Implementation Unit of the Federal Ministry of Agriculture.

Additional information: 2003: The breed was gradually abandoned and replaced by Simmental during recent decades. In 1950, research on the breed composition of herds in Sava valley (the northern part of Bosnia) showed that 23,8 percent of the total cows belonged to Posavsko cattle and 7,0 percent to crosses between Posavsko and Simmental.
Description of origin: small variety of Serbian Steppe. Posavsko (a dual-purpose breed) was developed, in the northeastern part of the country, by farmers and by the breeding station at Modrica based on the traditional Podolic population (Bos europeus primigenius, Ruetimeyer).

Description Of Specific Uses: The importation of the Simmental breeds, resulted in the creation of new, locally adapted strains of breeds.
Additional information: In 1950, research on the breed composition of herds in Sava valley (the northern part of Bosnia) showed that 7,0 percent of cows belonged to crosses between Posavsko and Simmental and 32,0 percent to Simmental type of cattle. Before the war, the Simmental breed and its crosses with Busa and other breeds represented over sixty percent of the total number of cattle in the country.
Description of origin: imported from Croatia, Germany and Austria; exotic; The Simmental breed has replaced the local Posavsko cattle. In 1997, 4875 Simmental breeds were imported.
Location within country: northern part of Bosnia and Herzegovina

Description Of Specific Uses: The crossing of Tyrolean Grey with local cows of the Busa type resulted in the creation of a new local breed (Gatacko cattle).
Additional information: 2003: The Gatacko breed, pure Tyrolean Grey and crossbreed of this type represent some 10 to 15 percent of the total cattle population.
Description of origin: heifers imported from Hungary, Austria, Germany and The Netherlands
Location within country: areas of Gacko, Stolac, Nevesinje, Trnovo, Sarajevo and Mostar

Additional performance parameters: The crossing of Swiss Brown with indigenous breeds throughout the former USSR has led to the development of many regional breeds including Ala-Tau, Lebedin, Caucausian Brown and Carpathian Brown.

Description of origin: imported from USA; composite of Brahman x Angus

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to the harsh environment conditions in the semi-arid thorn forest of the Chaco. The environment of the Chaco differs in Bolivia, Paraguay and Argentina due to soils and rainfall though winters are dry and cold in all three countries.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The animals are able to withstand the harsh environment and remain very fertile.
Color comments: comment: various colours
Location within country: semi-arid thorn forest of the Chaco
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were measured under very extensive stationary conditions with no housing and browsing in the semi-arid Chaco.
Comments management conditions: There is an acute lack of water during cold and dry winters.
Additional performance parameters: The breed has been selected for fertility and growth. The main selection goal is beef production. Cows are milked in the wet season for cheese production.

Comments management conditions: Commercial sector.

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to highland conditions in altitudes above 3 500 m asl.
Other specific visible traits: Creole type

Description Of Specific Uses: The Criollo provides draught power in the Andean agricultural systems.
Adaptability to specific environment: Adapted to high altitude areas (>4000 mtrs. above sea level), heat, humidity and drought.
Description of origin: imported; locally adapted; Four centuries ago the Spanish colonizers introduced European cattle breeds that have adapted perfectly to the different ecological regions of Bolivia. Presentday Criollo decendend from these cattle breeds first introduced by the Spanish colonizers.
imported; first introduced on the Pairumani property in Cochabamba;

Comments management conditions: Commercial sector.
Mainly kept in big ranches under low input conditions.

Description of origin: The name of the breed comes from the Saavedra experimental station where the breed has been selected primarily for milk yield corrected for fertility in a humid tropical environment. Criollo cows of the area were purchased with a small number of bulls thought to be above average in their performance (no milk records existed). Semen was imported from Criollo herds selected for milk yield in a similar environment in Cuba, Nicaragua, Costa Rica and Brazil. Although the herd is surely highly heterozygous it is physically uniform (colour ranges from Guernsey colour without the white patches to Jersey colour).
Management conditions performance measur: Performance was measured under stationary conditions with no housing and with grazing and concentrate feeding. Lactation yield reported does not include the amount of milk suckled by the calf during lactation.
Comments management conditions: Bulls of this breed are used for: a) cross-breeding with Holsteins or Brown Swiss for intensive milk production in those areas close to a market and with the possibility of concentrate supplementation (the cross-breds regularily produce more than 20 litres per day at calving); b) purebreeding in those areas where supplementary feeding is impossible and uneconomic and cattle must graze pastures or browse. In these cases, the cross-bred gives no more than the Criollo, which is however healthier, more fertile and more resistant to parasites.

Adaptability to specific environment: The animals are well adapted to seasonally flooded plains.
Color comments: uni coloured: light brown, similar to Jersey
Description of origin: selected from the almost extinct Beni Criollo
Location within country: one ranch near Yacuma river in Beni, eastern Bolivia
Comments management conditions: The animals are managed extensively on seasonally flooded plains. For about six months of the year they graze in up to 50 cm of water.
Additional performance parameters: Cows are never milked. They have been selected for over 25 years for beef production and uniformity.

Color comments: multi coloured: black and white or red and white
Other specific visible traits: Holsteins are large and stylish animals.
Description of origin: imported; locally adapted; The Holstein cow originated in Europe. The major historical development of this breed occurred in what is now the Netherlands and more specifically in the two northern provinces of North Holland and Friesland, which lay on either side of the Zuider Zee. The original stock was the black animals and white animals of the Batavians and Friesians, migrant European tribes who settled in the Rhine Delta region about 2,000 years ago.
Management conditions performance measur: Average production for all Holsteins is enrolled in official U.S. production-testing programs in 1987.

Adaptability to specific environment: Adaptable to a wide range of climatic and geographical conditions. They are more tolerant of heat than the larger breeds.
Other special qualities: They are excellent grazers and perform well in intensive grazing programs. Most Jerseys produce far in excess of 13 times their bodyweight in milk each lactation.
Description of origin: imported; locally adapted; The Jersey breed originated on the Island of Jersey, a small British island in the English Channel off the coast of France. The Jersey is one of the oldest dairy breeds, having been reported by authorities as being purebred for nearly six centuries.

Other specific visible traits: some are dwarf

Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer
Additional information: In the western Bhutan the breed is called Bajo while in eastern Bhutan it is called Goleng. The Goleng / Bajo look alike and are historically from the same origin. Real breed studies are lacking and they are not specified in the census data.
Other specific visible traits: humpless and very small and compact animal. Average body length is 114 (m) and 115.3 (f).Average heart girth is 132 (m) and 132.8 (f).
Description of origin: The origin of goleng is from the place of domestication along the silk road to Tibet and Mongolia.They came in ancient times over the highiest himalayan ridges to the southern slopes of Bhutan but remained at high altitude areas of Bhutan.
Location within country: particularly found at high altitude in the dzongkhags of Thimphu,Wangdue , Gasa and Bumthang.
Management conditions performance measur: free range system
Comments management conditions: They are well adapted to cold and harsh climate,high altitude,high radiation and big day and night temperature differences.their fodder requirements are very modest.
Additional performance parameters: Performance Lactation yield (ltrs) 521.1 Lactation length (days) 308.8 Life expectancy 15.2

Provision Uses: Draught power, General crossbreeding, Interspecies crossing, Milk
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer
Color comments: multi coloured: dark slate in coloured with white stockings below the knees comment: Calves are born dark red in coloured which turns into the characteristic coloured by 6 months of age. They have a dorsal ridge on the crest of the shoulder
Other specific visible traits: short tail, big dewlap, flat forehead
Description of origin: Mithun Bos frontalis is the decendant of Gaur, which originated in the Northeast India but has been breed in Bhutan since at least the 17th century. Mithun (male) are often crossbred with Thrabam (female of Nublang) to reproduce Jatsa and Jatsham, which are productively superior compared to either of the parent breeds ( Biodiversith Action Plan 2009)
Location within country: All regions except far north and far south of Bhutan.
Comments management conditions: These cattle feed mainly on browsing.

Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer
Adaptability to specific environment: well adapted to temperate climatic conditions

Location within country: high altitude areas of the country

Comments management conditions: free grazing system
Additional performance parameters: Average gestation period 285 days. average lactation length 305 days.

Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer
Additional information: In the western Bhutan the breed is called Bajo while in eastern Bhutan it is called Goleng. The Goleng / Bajo look alike and are historically from the same origin.Real breed studies are lacking and they are not specified in the census data.
Adaptability to specific environment: Extremely well adapted to a cold and harsh climate,high altitude,high radiation and big night and day temperature difference. Their fodder requirements are very modest.
Color comments: The colour is predominently black and dark brown,but there are some red and yellow animals as well.Some animals are all white.
Horn shape size and comments: The horns are shorty and fine and are sometimes even missing.The horn colour is black.The average length of the horn is 21.3 cm in male and 13.4 cm in female. horn circumference is 15.8 in male and 9.9 in female.
Other specific visible traits: humpless and very small and compact animal. The head is big, long and wide compared to rest of the body. Average body length is 119.65 cm and Heart girth is 136.2cm.
Description of origin: Bos taurus short horn, humpless, small breed of Tibetan and Mongolia.The origin of goleng is from the place of domestication along the silk road to Tibet and Mongolia.They came in ancient times over the highest Himalayan ridges to the southern slopes of Bhutan but remained at high altitude areas particularly found in Merak sakten dungkhags.
Year of origin: Before 1950ies when there was occasional trades of cattle with Tibet.
Management conditions performance measur: open free range system
Comments management conditions: Farmers usually keep 1 to 2 goleng cattle in their herds of cattle and cattle -yak crosses.They are well adapted to cold and harsh climate,high altitude,high radiation and big day and night temperature differences.their fodder requirements are very modest.
Additional performance parameters: Lactation yield 521.1,lactation length 308.8, calves per year 0.7 and calves in life time 9.0 and life expectancy 15.2

Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer
Color comments: All colours are found but yellow /red are dominent followed by black ,brown and grey.
Horn shape size and comments: Horns are often reduced to a stub and ssome animals are even polled.the horn circumference is average10.8 cm in female while for male average is 14.3 cm.
Description of origin: Jaba is an Indian breed from Assam.It is trans boundary breed found in India and border areas of Southern Bhutan.
Additional performance parameters: Lactation yield (litres) 532.76,lactation length (days)308.62, calves in life time (no)9.64 and life expectancy (years)14.86.

Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer
Description Of Specific Uses: Used for cross breeding with native cattle.
Color comments: light red brown
Other specific visible traits: Average body length 134.58cm (m) and 162.6cm (f), average heart girth 146.58cm(m) and 164.11cm(f), average tail length 50.77cm (m) and 70.59cm (f).
Management conditions performance measur: out door and indoor management system.

Description: Nublang is the traditional cattle breed of Bhutan since its presence dates back to time immemorial. It is a priority breed for conservation as its existence is threatened by introduction of high yielding exotic breeds in the country and restriction of forest grazing in the country.
Provision Uses: Draught power, Interspecies crossing, Meat, Milk, Sire line
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer
Additional information: # Nublang is genetically unique and distinct from any other cattle in the neighboring countries # Nublang in the eastern part of the country is genetically different from the Nublangs in the west and centre region
Additional information comments: # Age old tradition # Time-tested draught power # Affordable # Easily manageable; zero management required # Robust and very adaptive # Contribution to the genepool
Adaptability to specific environment: * Requires minimal or no management * Grazes freely in the forest during the day and is tethered at night * The animal is highly adapted to a wide range of agroclimatic conditions * Relatively more resistant to diseases than exotic breeds * Good foraging abilities * High adaptability can endure adverse nutritional and climatic conditions
Specific resistance or tolerance: resistance to many diseases and parasites..
Color comments: multi coloured: usually black-and-white or red-and-white
Horn shape size and comments: Big Horn directed sidewards, backward head, thinner posterior part
Description of origin: The origin of Nublang is linked to the legendary lake NubTshonopata, located on the western mountain ranges of Haa and above Nakha village in Sangbay geog. The legend resonates over many generations that the first breeding bull was gifted by the *Tshomoen of Nub Tshonapata to a cow herder who generously provided food and shelter to the Tshomoen. According to the elders of Sangbeykha, the gifted bull actually appeared, heading towards the herd of the herder, after a fewdays of the departure of the Tshomoen. The herder took good care of the bull and crossbred it with his herd. Soon the Nublang breed became popular and spread widely in the region. Thus Sangbey geog came to be known for the best Nublang breed in the kingdom. They are considered as a stabilized breed from crossing of humpless cattle (Bos taurus) from Tibet and humped cattle from India
Location within country: They are found throughout the country with higher concentration in Chukha, Haa and Samtse districts.
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were measured under stationary conditions with all year round housing and grazing and fodder.
Comments management conditions: # Requires minimal or no management # Grazes freely in the forest during the day and is tethered at night # The animal is highly adapted to a wide range of agroclimatic conditions # Relatively more resistant to diseases than exotic breeds # Good foraging abilities # High adaptability can endure adverse nutritional and climatic conditions
Additional performance parameters: Average age at 1st mating (month) 43 Average gestation period (days) 279

Description: Botswana beef synthetic breed. Musi cattle are predominately red in colour but show some differing shades of fawn and brown. They have Small cervico-thoracic hump and medium sized dewlap. The hair is short and shiny.
Color comments: Musi cattle are predominately red in colour but also show some differing shades of Fawn and Brown.
Other specific visible traits: Musi is a composite beef breed, Medium to large frame beef animal with bone structure heavier than Tswana breed and lighter than Simmental, Red in colour (with shades ranging from light yellowish brown to red), Short shiny hair, Small cervico thoracic hump, medium sized dewlap, strong legs, straight backline and large barrel, long tail
Description of origin: Musi cattle breed was developed in Musi ranches of the Department of Agricultural Research.
Year of origin: The breed was developed in 1982 at Musi ranch which is located in the Southern District part of Botswana
Location within country: The Musi breed is currently found in government ranches which are as follows: Morapedi ranch in the Southern District, Xanagas ranch located in the Gantsi District, Morale ranch located just outside Mahalapye village in Central District and Matlolakgang ranch in Kweneng District, Ramatlabama in Southern District. In addition, Musi cattle are found in private farms which are also used as multiplication sites, Two farms in Central District (Kobogoo ranch located in Central sanveld ranches, Mmabahumi farm located among Sherwood ranches near Lerala village).
Management conditions performance measur: Standard Performance test

Description: The breed is indigenous to Tswana speaking groups of southern Africa who have kept this breed for a long time, hence the name Tswana cattle.
Provision Uses: Dam line, Draught power, Fuel (manure), General crossbreeding, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Sire line, Skin/hides, Surrogate milk provision for suckling
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Pollination and seed dispersal, Waste recycling of non-human edible feed
Specific resistance or tolerance: low mortality
Specific reproductive characteristic: high reproductive performance
Color comments: uni coloured: black multi coloured: usually red pied, also black pied
Other specific visible traits: Sanga type, similar to Barotse and Tuli
Performance data reference: N2-83, 84, 85 F20(1) -104 FAO Breed Survey Ministry of Agriculture (1980) Livestock and Range Research in Botswana, 1990. Ministry of Agriculture (1980) Beef cattle breeding and reproductive physiology. Ten years of animal production and range research in Botswana. Ntombizakhe Mpofu. 1996. Conservation of the Tswana cattle breed in Botswana. Animal Production and Range Research, Gaborone, Botswana,AGRI 1996 20:17-26.
Management conditions performance measur: Milk performance data have been measured on cattle fed on grazing and supplementary sorghum stover (60%), Dolichos hay (30%) and sorghum bran (10%). Daily Milk Yield record was obtained under Ranch management condition (Sunnyside ranch)
Comments management conditions: The animals receive additional rations of sorgum stover and sorgum bran. Found in the traditional sector; some farmers still milk their Tswana cows and sell the milk fresh or as sour milk
Additional performance parameters: - calving % 80; - mortality rate 0-2 years 9.4; - weaning weight (7 months) 179; - 18-month weight kg 287.2; Parturition percentage (%): Min. 70.6, Avg. 77.15, Max. 82.

Provision Uses: Dam line, Fuel (manure), General crossbreeding, Meat, Saving security, Sire line, Skin/hides, Surrogate milk provision for suckling

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is well adapted to live under the local semi-arid conditions.
Specific resistance or tolerance: low mortality
Specific reproductive characteristic: This breed is known for above average fertility. The females are known for calving ease and good maternal traits.
Other special qualities: The animals are known for their good survivability.
Reference for special qualities: Mrs. S, Moyo; ILCA Report December 1990. Head, Matopos Research Station, Zimababwe
Color comments: uni coloured: yellow, golden-brown or red
Other specific visible traits: small thoracic-cervico hump
Description of origin: selected from Mangwato, a variety of Tswana
Performance data reference: FAO Breed Survey Ministry of Agriculture (1980) Ten years of Animal production and Range Research in Botswana.
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were measured from animals reared under stationary conditions and fed on total grazing
Additional performance parameters: - calving % 86.6; - mortality % (0-2 years) 7.2; - weaning weight (kg) (7 months) 175.8; - 8 month-weight (kg) 287.2;

uni coloured: white or black
