The effort also includes the registration of the populations of this breed. 2012: Information based on number of living animals per 22nd of November. 2013: Information based on number of living animals per 1st of October. 2014: Information based on number of living animals per 18th of February. 2015: Information based on number of living animals per 1st of March. 2016: Information based on number of living animals per 3rd of February.
Efabis cultural role comment: indigenous cattle from Jutland
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is very robust and hardy.
Color comments: multi coloured: mainly black and white, also grey and white
Description of origin: Jutland Cattle derive from indigenous breed cattle in Jutland. In 1881 the first herd-book was published. It distinguished between animals of dairy type and animals of beef type. During the first part of the 20th century the breed was selected for milk production and it was called Black and White Dairy Breed from Jutland. In 1950 this breed was joined with black and white cattle from Holland and Germany to form the SDM breed. A few breeders did however continue to breed the original Danish type. In the 1980s it was almost extinct, when a programme to save this old Danish breed was launched.

Description: Conservation programme for part of the Danish Shorthorn cattle, a line of dairy Shorthorn, referred to as "Lyngestammen".
Additional information: Common for Shorthorn cattle is a high growth rate and high-quality meat with a good marbeling. The milk yield is relatively high with a low lipid content in the milk. The cattle is long-lived and well-tempered. Calvings are uncomplicated and the cows are good parents. Very good health. The Danish Ministry of Food, Agriculture and Fishery supports breeders of Dansk Korthorn. All 7 breeders received support in 2005. The population data are base on 100% pure-bred individuals. In addition, a number of individuals are between 75% and almost 100% pure-bred.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Uncomplicated calvings, good parenting by cows.
Special characteristic of product: QUite low lipid content of milk. High quality meat with good marbeling.
Color comments: multi coloured: red and white or roan
Description of origin: Originates from Dairy Shorthorn imported from United Kingdom. The Korthorn had its great period in from 1900 to 1950 after which the breed did not meet increased production demands. Today, breeding has separated it into the old dairy (dual-purpose) line and the more modern Beefshorthorn. The old line was never crossed with Beefshorthorn.
Import: First imported form the UK in 1848

Description: Red coloured Danish breed of milking cattle as bred until year 1970.
Other name: Danish Red Cattle, Red Danish Dairy Cattle
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer
Description Of Specific Uses: The breed is a dairy breed with relative high production capacity, and high fat- and protein content in the milk. Male calves are traditionally used for bullock production.
Additional information: Conservation Programme: The Danish Ministry of Environment and Food supports breeders of RDM-1970. 27 breeders received support in 2005. The population data include the RDM-1930 line of RDM. There are 3 breeding males and 75 breeding female sin this line. They are 7 breeders attending this line - they have approx. 14 animals each.
Efabis cultural role comment: > 100 Years of pure breeding with a national danish breed
Special characteristic of product: The fat and protein content of the milk is high. The high content of capaprotein makes the milk suitable for cheese production.
Color comments: uni coloured: red with dark muzzle and hooves
Horn shape size and comments: Mid-sized, arched horns that point upwards or forwards. The horns may be white or grey-yellow, often with black tips.
Description of origin: In the 1840s, original cattle on the Eastern Danish islands were crossed with red cattle from the Southern part of Denmark. Three groups of cattle were used: Angler Cattle, Northern Slesviger Cattle and Ballum Cattle. The resulting cattle was the foundation for the Red Danish Dairy Cattle, RDM, officially formed in 1878. The RDM was most popular in the 1950s but it has decreased a lot since then. From the late 1970s the breed association introduced breeding material from other breeds, e.g. Brown-Swiss, Red Holstein and Swedish Red, into the RDM. Only a small fraction of the breeders continued pure-breeding after this, and they formed "RDM-1970". Subsequently, a small group of breeders formed the "RDM-1930" - a slightly different line. Both lines represent the original Red Danish Dairy Cattle.

Description of origin: A herd book for the local black and white cattle of Jutland (The Jutland cattle) was first established in 1881. In 1949 this breed was pooled with an increasing population of Dutch and German black and white cattle, and this new synthetic breed was called SDM or Sortbroget dansk Malkerace. Since 1965 imports of semen from other black and white populations, mainly from USA and Canada, but lately also from Holland and France, has taken place. To date (1998) the Danish Friesian is a strain of the international HF-breed, with only 25% of its genes originating from the original Danish dual purpose breed from 1965 (SDM-1965).
Import: since 1965 from Holstein-Friesian from USA, Canada, The Netherlands, Germany and France
Management conditions performance measur: Intensive dairy production systems. The majority of cows is housed in tie barns during winter. Heifers are reared in loose holdings, and summer grazing. Male calves are used for production of bullocs in intensive production indoor systems, and slaughtered at approximately 11 months of age at a liveweight of approximately 440 kg.

Zebu type, with marked pigmentation of the mucous and black extremities, short hair and abundant hump.
Description of origin: This breed was created in the cattle ranch of the Central Romana Corporation, through crossbreeding and selection for more than 50 years. Its genetic base makes reference to the Criollo cattle that originally came from Spain starting from 1492. This breed was crossed with varieties of Zebu, mainly the Guzerat and Missouri. These were bulls of red colour, presumably of African origin that gave red offspring. The Nelore breed coming from Louisiana and kept by cattle breeders in the eastern region of the country were also used as sire line.

Provision Uses: Meat, Milk, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Skin/hides
Adaptability to specific environment: The Cheurfa is well adapted to harsh climate conditions and has a walking ability in difficult grounds.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The Cheurfa is able to valorize forages and coarse food and is well adapted to restricted food resources. It is also resistant to disease, parasites and insects.
Color comments: The Cheurfa presents a whitish color with a white muzzle and dark eyelids.
Horn shape size and comments: The Cheurfa has long horns curving upwards.
Description of origin: The Cheurfa belongs to the Atlas Brown branch. The distribution area of the Atlas Brown covers all of North Africa and whose ancestor would be the Bos primigenius mauritanicus.
Location within country: The Cheurfa lives on the edge of forests and in the lakeside and coastal areas of El-Tarf and Annaba, where the majority of the population is located. It is also present in the regions of Guelma, Skikda, Jijel and Sétif.
Feeding of adults: Agro-Industrial By-Products, Concentrate, Farm-Household By-products, Fodder, Grazing, Uncontrolled Feeding

Adaptability to specific environment: The Chélifienne is well adapted to harsh climate conditions and has a walking ability in difficult grounds.

Feeding of adults: Agro-Industrial By-Products, Concentrate, Farm-Household By-products, Fodder, Grazing, Uncontrolled Feeding

Feeding of adults: Agro-Industrial By-Products, Concentrate, Farm-Household By-products, Fodder, Grazing, Uncontrolled Feeding

Adaptability to specific environment: The Sétifienne is well adapted to harsh climate conditions and has a walking ability in difficult grounds.

Description of origin: The Sétifienne belongs to the Atlas Brown branch. The distribution area of the Atlas Brown covers all of North Africa and whose ancestor would be the Bos primigenius mauritanicus.
Location within country: The Sétifienne lives in the mountainous areas of the Sétif region, it would also be present in Jijel.
Feeding of adults: Agro-Industrial By-Products, Concentrate, Farm-Household By-products, Fodder, Grazing, Uncontrolled Feeding

Management conditions performance measur: Performance was measured under intensive conditions.
Comments management conditions: Under extensive regime; only given fodder when environmental conditions do not permit grazing. The average annual temperature is 9ºC and the annual rainfall oscillating around 1200 to 1300 cc/m2.
Additional performance parameters: The calf has an average weight of 139 kg. at weaning. Average slaughter weight: 354.98 kg.

Other specific visible traits: very well footed, very strong, good udder and rustic subhypermetric
Description of origin: indigenous breed Rubia Gallega and other Spanish breeds

Provision Uses: General crossbreeding, Hair, Horns, Milk, Sire line, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Fire protection, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Waste recycling of non-human edible feed, Weed control and biomass residue management
Additional information comments: For more information on the breeding program and other regulations: https://www.mapa.gob.es/es/ganaderia/temas/zootecnia/razas-ganaderas/razas/catalogo-razas/bovino/parda/datos_reglamentacion.aspx

Other name: Pyrenean Brown, Bruna de los Pirineos, Parda Leonesa, Parda Pirenaica
Provision Uses: Dam line, Hair, Horns, Meat, Sire line, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Fire protection, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Waste recycling of non-human edible feed, Weed control and biomass residue management
Additional information: 1998: census conducted; 9 000-10 000 heads were considered purebred, and another 10 000 heads were considered to have a high phenotypical resemblance with the breed;
Additional information comments: For more information on the breeding program and other regulations: https://www.mapa.gob.es/es/ganaderia/temas/zootecnia/razas-ganaderas/razas/catalogo-razas/bovino/parda-montana/datos_reglamentacion.aspx
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is known for its rusticity and good adaptation to highlands.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The breed shows good maternal abilities.
Color comments: multi coloured: brown with shades around eyes, muzzle comment: pinkish mucous membranes and black muzzle
Horn shape size and comments: white low-lyred horns with black points
Other specific visible traits: eumetric animals with harmonic proportions and longilineous tendencies Has a meat body format.
Location within country: Catalonian part of north-western Pyrenees (the zones of Pallars Sobirà, Pallars Jussà, and Alta Ribagorça with highest census, and also the zones of Cerdanya, Ripollès, Berguedà and Osona)
Comments management conditions: Animals are only provided with fooder under extreme weather conditions when grazing is not possible.

Provision Uses: Dam line, Hair, Horns, Milk, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Fire protection, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Waste recycling of non-human edible feed, Weed control and biomass residue management
Additional information comments: For more information on the breeding program and other regulations: https://www.mapa.gob.es/es/ganaderia/temas/zootecnia/razas-ganaderas/razas/catalogo-razas/bovino/pasiega/datos_reglamentacion.aspx
Description of origin: upland variety of Santander. Absorbed or displaced by Swiss Brown in 1940s.

Provision Uses: Dam line, Hair, Horns, Meat, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Fire protection, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Waste recycling of non-human edible feed, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: High quality meat.
Additional information comments: For more information on the breeding program and other regulations: https://www.mapa.gob.es/es/ganaderia/temas/zootecnia/razas-ganaderas/razas/catalogo-razas/bovino/pirenaica/datos_reglamentacion.aspx
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is well adapted for grazing under extreme climatic conditions.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Animals of this breed show a low incidence of genital illnesses.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The animals calve once per year even under harsh conditions. Calvings are easy in both pure breed animals and in commercial crossings. One calve per year.
Special characteristic of product: These meat animals develop 350-360 kg carcass at 12 months, with a dressing percentage of 63%.
Other special qualities: Well adapted to local conditions. Play a role in the conservation of natural resources. Well suited to graze in high mountain areas where no other cattle coud graze. Hardiness. Cultural value. Maternal ability.
Color comments: uni coloured: from white to very light brown comments: some have a light coloured patch around eyes, muzzle and axilae
Horn shape size and comments: lyre-shaped horns in males and spiral-shaped horns in females with yellow tips
Other specific visible traits: mucous membranes are pink to red in colour the hoofs are white to yellow in colour.
Description of origin: indigenous breed believed to come from the same branch as the french breeds named ""blondes"": different opinions regarding the origin of the breed exist, the breed may origin from Bos taurus europaeus, Bos taurus primigenius or Bos taurus brachyceros.
Year of origin: Herdbook opend in 1925 in Guipuzcoa Province and in 1988 at national level.
Management conditions performance measur: Performance was measured under intesive conditions. Animals are housed in winter, graze near the villages in spring and in the mountains in summer. After weaning (4 - 6 months), calves are fattening in fetlocks with concentrates and dried forrage.
Additional performance parameters: Carcass weigh data at 12 months.

Provision Uses: Carting, Dam line, Hair, Horns, Meat, Skin/hides, Transport
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Fire protection, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Waste recycling of non-human edible feed, Weed control and biomass residue management
Additional information comments: For more information on the breeding program and other regulations: https://www.mapa.gob.es/es/ganaderia/temas/zootecnia/razas-ganaderas/razas/catalogo-razas/bovino/retinta/datos_reglamentacion.aspx
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is well adapted to a hot climate.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The animals are reported to show resistance to certain parasites.
Color comments: uni coloured: brown
Description of origin: composite of Red Convex Branch and indigenous breed South Iberian
Comments management conditions: The animals endure poor nutrition.
Additional performance parameters: - weaning weight at 189 days: 205 kg;

Provision Uses: General crossbreeding, Hair, Horns, Meat, Sire line, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Fire protection, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Waste recycling of non-human edible feed, Weed control and biomass residue management
Additional information comments: The breed can be recomended for industrial crossing. For more information on the breeding program and other regulations: https://www.mapa.gob.es/es/ganaderia/temas/zootecnia/razas-ganaderas/razas/catalogo-razas/bovino/rubia-gallega/datos_reglamentacion.aspx
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is rustic, hardy and docile.
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is known for its longevity ( up to 21 years).
Special characteristic of product: The breed is known for its excellent growth, very good meat structure and good muscling.
Other special qualities: The breed is rustic, hardy and docile.
Color comments: uni coloured: blond with pink membranes
Other specific visible traits: and extraordinary beauty and harmony
Description of origin: indigenous breed, Bos taurus primigenius: Since 1969 when the latest breed standard was established and 1975 when actions were strengthened and the Spanish Ministry for Agriculture, Fishing and Food subrogated the preparation of the Genealogical Book to the National Association of Selected Cattle Breeders dedicated to this breed of cattle (ACRUGA), Rubia Gallega cattle have been mainly selected for meat production. During this time, a phenotypical selection pressure has been applied on strong inheritable characteristics in order to establish a greater format, to increase the growth rate, to a better conversion rate. The result was very satisfactory and the market of pure breed reproducers and industrial reproducers was created. This programme is mainly based on AI. and cow and bull assessment. Each test is made in accordance with the protocol for capacity control and genetic value determination, in relation to Resolution 94/515/EEC.
Additional performance parameters: Animals are slaughtered with 205 days of age. The carcass weight is 210 kg. The meat is very tender. The carcass has a composition of 78.21% meat, 11.37% bones, the remainder consists of fat.

Description: Name originated after the region of origin.
Other name: Zamorana, Moles de Sayago, Castellana variedad Sayaguesa, Sayaguesa
Provision Uses: Dam line, Hair, Horns, Meat, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Fire protection, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Waste recycling of non-human edible feed, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: Meat: milkfet veal. Work. Traded as a Spanish quality label. "Ternera de Aliste"
Additional information: The census was conducted in 1998. The population is decreasing due to crossbreeding.
Additional information comments: For more information on the breeding program and other regulations: https://www.mapa.gob.es/es/ganaderia/temas/zootecnia/razas-ganaderas/razas/catalogo-razas/bovino/sayaguesa/datos_reglamentacion.aspx
Adaptability to specific environment: Highly adapted to their environment - very rustic animals.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Very resistant to local diseases and especially to foot rot.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Easy calving, one parturition per year, good maternal ability. Decreasing population due to crossbreeding with other breeds ( Frisona, Parda Alpina, Charoles, Limusín, Rubia Gallega and Pirenaica)
Special characteristic of product: Typical products: weaning calves, yearlings. Good meat quality.
Other special qualities: Tame. Good roughage converters. Cultural role.
Color comments: uni-coloured: black: with a tendency to bleach giving lighter tonalities; bulls tend to have a darker coloured line running throughout the dorsal-lumbar line, with silver halo surrounding the muzzle
Horn shape size and comments: hooked shape in males and lyra shape in females with black tips.
Other specific visible traits: These are thin animals with a good locomotive aptitude and agile movements. Very visible all oseous marks, long neck, great dewlap and long legs.
Description of origin: descends from the Bos taurus ibericus or Bos primigenius estrepsiceros
Location within country: In the northwestern territory, in the region of Sayago.
Management conditions performance measur: Semi-extensive
Comments management conditions: housed during the night. Only given fodder when climatic conditions impede normal grazing.
Additional performance parameters: Low dressing percentage, but very good meat quality.

Description: Named after local geographical contitions and the colour coat.
Other name: Negra Serrana, Serrana Soriana, Serrana Ibérica, Negra Burgalesa
Provision Uses: Dam line, Draught power, Hair, Horns, Meat, Skin/hides, Transport
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Fire protection, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Waste recycling of non-human edible feed, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: High quality meat. In the past was used as to draugt and pack. Some animals produced milk with a high level of fat.
Additional information: Currently, with the aim of increse the population, there is a growing trade of purebred heifers.
Additional information comments: For more information on the breeding program and other regulations: https://www.mapa.gob.es/es/ganaderia/temas/zootecnia/razas-ganaderas/razas/catalogo-razas/bovino/serrana-negra/datos_reglamentacion.aspx
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is well adapted to the local environment (extreme continental climate with few rain, semi desert, steep zones).
Specific resistance or tolerance: Hardiness. Resistence to extreme climate conditions and diseases.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Maternal ability. Natural breeding difficults pure breed conservation.
Special characteristic of product: Typical products: Ternero Pastenco (a crossed, 6-7 months calf).
Other special qualities: Strong, robust. Cultural role
Color comments: uni coloured: black, sometimes oscillations from bleached black to dark brown
Horn shape size and comments: well developed, lyred-shaped horns, sometimes open hook-shaped horns
Other specific visible traits: rustic appearance, frequently with grey halo around mouth and nose area. Poorly developed udder with abundant hairs. Straight or sub-concave profile. Big dewlap. Strong back.
Description of origin: The breed descended from the European Bos Brachiceros and was mainly influenced by Negra Avileña and to a smaller degree by other mountain type breeds of northern Spain.
Location within country: Teruel (Sierra de Albarracín, Gúdar and Maestrazgo)
Comments management conditions: The animals are only provided with fodder when grazing is not possible due to bad weather conditions.

Provision Uses: Dam line, Hair, Horns, Meat, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Fire protection, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Waste recycling of non-human edible feed, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: Slaughtered at 14- 16 months.
Additional information comments: For more information on the breeding program and other regulations: https://www.mapa.gob.es/es/ganaderia/temas/zootecnia/razas-ganaderas/razas/catalogo-razas/bovino/serrana-teruel/datos_reglamentacion.aspx
Adaptability to specific environment: Adapted to high mountains and extreme temperatures
Specific resistance or tolerance: Hardiness.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Easy calving and maternal ability.
Special characteristic of product: High quality product
Other special qualities: Well suited to marginal areas. Contributes to preserve the landscape and the rural population in remote rural areas.
Color comments: Main colours: black, brown. Calves born with redish coat.
Other specific visible traits: A silver halo around nose and mouth. Straight or sub-concave profile. Short and strong neck. Long and high set tail with big tussels. Well difined withers and saddled back. Not well developed feet.

Provision Uses: Dam line, Draught power, Hair, Horns, Meat, Skin/hides, Transport
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Fire protection, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Waste recycling of non-human edible feed, Weed control and biomass residue management
Additional information comments: For more information on the breeding program and other regulations: https://www.mapa.gob.es/es/ganaderia/temas/zootecnia/razas-ganaderas/razas/catalogo-razas/bovino/terrena/datos_reglamentacion.aspx
Other special qualities: This breed is known for longevity, females are used for crossing.
Color comments: uni coloured: brown
Other specific visible traits: many hairs on udder and ears, rustic

Provision Uses: Carting, Dam line, Hair, Horns, Meat, Skin/hides, Transport
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Fire protection, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Waste recycling of non-human edible feed, Weed control and biomass residue management
Additional information: Decreasing because of the crossbreeding.
Additional information comments: For more information on the breeding program and other regulations: https://www.mapa.gob.es/es/ganaderia/temas/zootecnia/razas-ganaderas/razas/catalogo-razas/bovino/tudanca/datos_reglamentacion.aspx
Color comments: multi coloured: three different coat types due to the presence of three types of hair: ""hosca"", black coloured hair with white distal end: ""tasuga"", hair is black in the proximal end and white in the distal end, giving a blue-greyish tonality: and a hazel-blonde coat
Other specific visible traits: This is a small sized breed with great sexual dimorphysm. It has a subconcave head profile.
Description of origin: Bos taurus ibericus or Bos taurus primigenius estrepsiceros
Location within country: northwestern territory; in Cantabria (Reinosa, Pesquera, Cabezón de Liébana, Cabuérniga and Campoo). Also reaching the regions of Palencia, León and in some places of Catalunya
Comments management conditions: Only given fodder under adverse climatic conditions.

Provision Uses: Dam line, Hair, Horns, Meat, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Fire protection, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Waste recycling of non-human edible feed, Weed control and biomass residue management
Additional information comments: For more information on the breeding program and other regulations: https://www.mapa.gob.es/es/ganaderia/temas/zootecnia/razas-ganaderas/razas/catalogo-razas/bovino/vianesa/datos_reglamentacion.aspx
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is well adapted to continental climate (cold winter, hot summer). The animals show a great rusticity (perfectly adapted to mountain conditions).
Other special qualities: These animals are reported to have a docile character and great tractive power.
Color comments: uni coloured: chestnut comment: sires are darker and calves are lighter
Horn shape size and comments: males: hook shaped or half moon shaped, females: longer and spiral shaped
Other specific visible traits: small head, large ears with long hairs, long fringe
Description of origin: indigenous breed local breed, Bos primigenius strepsicerus
Import: since 1960 from Frieiresa (Spain) and for a few years from Rubia Gallega (Spain) and Limousin (France)

Other name: Estonian Black and White, Estonian Holstein
Additional information: Data before independence refer to Former USSR. The cattle number in Estonia is decreasing for economic reasons, transition to the market economy and loss of the Russian market. The total number of breeding females was stable over the period 1988-91 at about 125 000. In the sperm bank there is semen from 300 bulls which is partly used. The share of Estonian Holstein has increased from 32 to 73% in 2002.
Additional information comments: The Estonian Black-and-White breed was renamed to Estonian Holstein in 1998.
Other special qualities: The animals are known for their strong constitution.
Color comments: multi coloured: black and white pied
Other specific visible traits: The breed is characterised by large size, compact conformation and strong skeleton.
Description of origin: composite of Dutch Friesian, East Friesian and Estonian Native Cattle. First called Estonian Black and White, in 1998 the breed was renamed Estonian Holstein.
Import: 1961-1997, <5% from Holstein-Friesian (Netherlands): 1983-1997, <5% from Holstein-Friesian (Germany): 1975-1997, <5% from Holstein (USA): 1987-1997, <5% from Holstein (Canada)
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for seven months per year and fed on grazing, fodder and concentrates.

Description Of Specific Uses: longevity, low food consumption per unit of produc.
Additional information: Data before independence refer to Former USSR. Most of the pure animals were maintained on 3 farms in 1980: Pyarivere state farm and Vakhenurme collective farm in Pyarnu District and Lekhtse collective farm in Paides district. In 2004, the breed is considered endangered.
Adaptability to specific environment: Resistance to the local hard conditions is reported for this breed.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The animals are reported to show high resistance to diseases.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The females are known for calving ease.
Special characteristic of product: Animals of this breed produce milk with high milk fat and protein content.
Other special qualities: This breed is known for its hardiness, longevity as well as very strong legs and hoofs. It has a low food consumption per unit of production and is considered a valuable base for crossing with other breeds. Utilization of feeds and their energy and protein in the experiment with Estonian Native Cattle.
Color comments: uni coloured: yellow multi coloured: combinations of red, brown and white: sometimes with white spots
Other specific visible traits: chest medium wide
Description of origin: northern European Polled type with West Finnish, Jersey, Swiss and Red Holstein blood
Import: in 1910 from West Finncattle (Finnland): 1965-1997, >20% from West Finncattle (Finland): 1961-1990, >20% from Jersey (Denmark): since 1985, <5% from Swiss (USA): since 1987, 5-20% from Red Holstein (Germany)
Location within country: Pärnumaa, Raplamaa, Saaremaa, Lääne-Virumaa, Läänemaa, Harjumaa
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 7 months per year and fed on grazing, fodder and concentrates.
Comments management conditions: feeding of adults: mixed
Additional performance parameters: Compared with other Estonian breeds this breed has a high milk fat and protein content.

Additional information: Data before independence refer to Former USSR. The breed accounted for over 63% of all cattle in 1980 and for over 33% of all cattle in Estonia in 1998. The overall number of cattle of this breed has been decreasing, especially after the state and collective farms were liquidated. The principal reasons for the decrease are economic, i.e. loss of markets due, especially the Russian one. Improvement of the breed is still on-going by pure-breeding and cross-breeding with Danish Red and Angeln. This breed is principally found in the hilly area of southern Estonia where the agricultural production has decreased most rapidly. During 40 years the share of this breed has diminished from 68 to 27%.
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is well adapted to the local conditions (hilly areas).
Specific reproductive characteristic: The animals are known for good reproduction.
Efabis adaptability to marginal land: well adapted to local conditions(hilly areas)
Color comments: uni coloured: pale to dark red, brown, often with darker belt along the back multi coloured: red and white
Other specific visible traits: medium size, strong legs and feet
Description of origin: composite of Angeln, Danish Red and Estonian Native created in the early 19th century: was more recently crossed with Red-and-White Holstein and Swedish Red-and-White Cattle
Import: Some Danish Red, Angeln, Red Holstein and Swedish Red-and-White have been imported to improve this breed.
Location within country: Mainly southern, also central and eastern Estonia and on Estonian islands
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 7 months per year and fed on grazing, fodder and concentrates.
Comments management conditions: feeding of adults: mixed

Description: The breed derives its name from the Abergelle which is a district in the northern region Tigray, Ethiopia
Provision Uses: Draught power, Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed has adaptive advantages to the hotter and drier lowlands, and ability to cope with feed shortages during the long dry periods.
Specific resistance or tolerance: tolerance to disease and parasites
Color comments: Colour varies considerably with black, black and white spotted. But chestnut, gray and light red are also common.
Horn shape size and comments: Various horn shapes. Males have thicker and shorter horns. Females have thin and medium sized horns mostly upward with pointed ends.
Location within country: Distributed in Tanqua Abergelle, Samriseharti, KollaTembien, parts of Selemti of Tigray region and adjacent districts of Amhara region of North Ethiopia
Management system: Back Yard or Farm Yard Production

Description: The breed is Small East African Zebu type.
Provision Uses: Draught power, Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Color comments: It has red, chestnut, black, roan and white coat colour
Horn shape size and comments: Males have thicker and shorter horns.Females have thin and medium sized horns mostly upward with pointed ends.
Location within country: Distributed in the central zone of the Tigray region in and around Adwa.

Description: Afar cattle breed is a Sanga type breed. They are very similar to the Raya cattle in Ethiopia that inhabit the adjacent agricultural highlands to the west and south.
Provision Uses: Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is very resistant and adapted to the extremely harsh conditions of the area.
Color comments: The breed has Ash-grey, cream or light chestnut, grey/white smooth, red and shiny coat colour.
Horn shape size and comments: Various horn shapes : with long lyre-shaped horns; horns can form almost a complete circle.
Other specific visible traits: It is characterized by large and slender body, small humps and moderate dewlap.
Location within country: Breed maintained by the Afar people in eastern and north-eastern Ethiopia (Afar, Tigray and Wollo), particularly in the lower Awash river valley, and parts of Djibouti and Eritrea.

Description: Are grouped in Small East African Zebu type breed
Provision Uses: Draught power, Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Other special qualities: Distinct from cattle of the large East African Zebu, the small Abyssinian Short horned Zebu inhabits the higher altitude, wetter agricultural areas, and hence they are also referred to as Ethiopian Highland Zebu mainly used for draught.
Other specific visible traits: The breed is characterized by compact conformation, larger than the adjacent Guraghe breed because of better pasture.
Location within country: Distributed in western Shewa of central Ethiopia around Ambo, Addis Alem and Holetta in Ethiopia

Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management

Description: Zenga type breed
Provision Uses: Draught power, Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is characterised as small and hardy .
Other special qualities: The breed is docile; very good work animal, and also used for meat; milk yield is low.
Color comments: Coat colour is variable between plain and patchy pattern; usually red with light to dark shades; red pied and black-pied are common; plain black, brown, grey and white coats also occur.
Horn shape size and comments: Females have medium, thin horns while males have thicker and shorter horns.
Other specific visible traits: The breed is characterized by thoracic to cervico-thoracic hump, large in bulls, less developed in oxen, and it is composed of muscular tissue with variable deposits of fat; body has good depth and length; well developed dewlap.
Description of origin: Indigenous breed. But, The origin of this breed is less well known.
Location within country: It inhabits the highlands of northern Ethiopia, including northern Shire, Adwa and Easter parts of Tigray.

Description: Arsi breed is grouped under large East African Zebu type
Provision Uses: Draught power, Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Other special qualities: The breed is docile; very good work animal, and also used for meat; milk yield is low.
Color comments: colour varies: red, black, roan, white and combinations
Other specific visible traits: This breed is characterized by having a thin prominent dewlap.
Description of origin: descended from Abyssinian Shorthorned Zebu or from the recently importeds of zebu
Location within country: Distributed in the central highlands of Ethiopia;Arsi, Shewa, Bale, Sidama and Harar.
Performance data reference: W42-32 W67-53 N7-13 FAO Breed Survey
Management conditions performance measur: Performance was measured under intensive management system or on government farm.
Comments management conditions: The breed is kept under sedentary conditions.

Description: The breed is small East African Zebu type breed
Provision Uses: Draught power, Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Other special qualities: distinct from cattle of the large East African zebu type, the small Abyssinian Short horned Zebu inhabits the higher altitude, wetter agricultural areas, and used for draught.
Color comments: They have black, chestnut, white and roan color.
Horn shape size and comments: characterized by having short to medium horns
Other specific visible traits: Characterized by prominent hump.
Location within country: Distributed in the high plateau of the Bale zone, in areas adjacent to the habitat of the Jem-Jem

Description: Grouped under large East African Zebu type breed
Provision Uses: Draught power, Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Special characteristic of product: Special attributes of the breed includes large, docile with well-developed udder, long teats and higher milk production.
Color comments: Has overall white with black spots colour, and usually red or black pied.
Other specific visible traits: The breed is characterized by active disposition, long legs and large humps that tend to be cervico-thoracic due to the Sanga influence, moderately developed dewlap.
Location within country: It is distributed in the North West Ethiopia. Mainly it is found in the Tahtayadiabo, Kaftahumera, Welqait,Asgedetsimbla districts.

Description: White, white with dark and red shade colour. Short slightly lateral and forward horn, medium body size.
Provision Uses: Draught power, Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Color comments: The breed has uniform coat colour pattern, and near to half breed population has white and grey body colour. Pigmentations are common on the muzzle, eyelid and hoof of the cattle.
Horn shape size and comments: The majority of the breed are characterized by having narrow horn spacing (<30 cm)
Other specific visible traits: Flat facial profile and straight-edged ears with lateral orientation plus erect cervico-thoracically positioned hump predominantly consisting of small humps.
Location within country: The breed is distributed in Guba district, Metekel Zone Benishangul Gumz Regional State of Ethiopia.

Description: Grouped under large East African Zebu type breed
Provision Uses: Draught power, Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Adaptability to specific environment: drought resistance, heat tolerance
Specific resistance or tolerance: tick-borne and other diseases resistance
Specific reproductive characteristic: reasonable conception rate under severe environmental condition, excellent mothering ability, well developed herd instinct
Special characteristic of product: The breed special merits include long distance walking ability, more docile and tractable than other zebu, longevity
Color comments: The breed has mainly white, fawn or brown with darker shading color on the head, neck and shoulders.
Horn shape size and comments: This breed is also characterized by thick horn, 80% straight and 17% curved in a lateral orientation for 70% of the cases. However in the case of typical Borana the horn is predominantly short,
Location within country: Distributed in the southern rangelands of Ethiopia, around Liben, Mega and Arero plains kept by Borana pastoralists and bordering area of northern kenya. Especially,Yabelo areain the Southern Ethiopia is the natural environment.

Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity
Habitat provision and biodiversity

Description: Fogera breed is Zenga type breed
Provision Uses: Draught power, Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is popular for its adaptation to seasonal flooding and the swampy conditions of the area.
Other special qualities: It is docile.
Color comments: The breed has Black-and-white or black and grey coat color.
Horn shape size and comments: This breed is characterized by Short stumpy, pointed horns
Other specific visible traits: hump ranges from thoracic to cervico-thoracic; a well-developed dewlap and naval flap
Location within country: Distributed in Fogera plains around Lake Tana, Southern Gonder and adjoining areas of Gojam.
Performance data reference: W41-9 N7-14 FAO Breed Survey Tesfaye Cherinet et al. (?) Livestock breeds/types and improvment programs in Ethiopia.

Description: The breed is grouped under small East African Zebu type breed.
Provision Uses: Draught power, Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Color comments: The breed is characterized mainly by red coat colour
Other specific visible traits: small hump
Location within country: Distributed in Goffa area, principally around Sawla in South Omo.

Description: The breed is Zebu type breed
Provision Uses: Draught power, Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Color comments: The dominant coat colour pattern is plain, red and black being the most frequent colour types.
Horn shape size and comments: All animals are horned signifying zebu characteristics. The breed is characterized by a curved horn shapes.
Other specific visible traits: The hump is mainly positioned thoracically, is well developed in males and ranges from small to medium in females. The facial profile is predominantly straight.
Location within country: Distributed in Awi, East and West Gojjam zones of the Amhara region, specifically in Gozamen, Ankasha and Enemay districts.

Description: Grouped under small East African Zebu type breed
Provision Uses: Draught power, Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Color comments: They are characterized mainly by red, chestnut and roan color.
Location within country: Distributed in the Guraghe and Hadiya areas in close proximity to the tsetse-infested valleys of the Ghibe tributaries

Description: The breed is grouped in small East African Zebu type breed
Provision Uses: Draught power, Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Location within country: Distributed in Hammer area in South Omo of the Southern Nation, Nationality and Peoples Regional State,maintained by the Hammer and neighboring pastoralist tribes.

Description: The breed is grouped in Small East African Zebu
Provision Uses: Draught power, Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Color comments: The common coat colors are black, roan and red.
Horn shape size and comments: They have short and thick horns
Other specific visible traits: well-developed dewlaps
Location within country: Distributed in eastern and western Hararghe plateau.

Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity
Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal

Description: The breed is Zenga type breed
Provision Uses: Draught power, Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Color comments: It has mainly brown or reddish brown color.
Horn shape size and comments: horns moderate but larger than the common zebu
Other specific visible traits: The breed height at withers ranges100-126 cm. This breed is characterized by small to medium cervico-thoracic hump; dewlap moderate and thin skin; deep chest and barrel‟ well-sprung ribs; udder small but well proportioned, good teat placement; calm disposition.
Location within country: Distributed in Horro Gudru of Eastern Welega; also in Western Shewa, and adjoining areas of Illubabora and Shewa.
Performance data reference: W41-8 N7-14 FAO Breed Survey Tesfaye Cherinet et al. (?) Livestock breeds/types and improvment programs in Ethiopia.
Comments management conditions: The breed is kept under mixed farming conditions.

Description: The breed is Zenga type breed
Provision Uses: Draught power, Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to a mountainous production environment and has the capacity to thrive on difficult terrain and its utilization of cactus (Opantiaficusindica) as a major source of nutrition.
Color comments: Has dominantly light red with white spots color on the face.
Horn shape size and comments: horns moderate but larger than the common zebu
Location within country: Distributed in Irob and GuloMekeda districts of the Tigray region.

Description: grouped under small East African Zebu
Provision Uses: Draught power, Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is well adapted to the wet and cold climate of the highlands at altitudes as high as 2500 m.
Color comments: They are solid black, black with a white face or white patches overall on a mainly black background. The white patches are mostly found on the faces and underneath their stomach.
Horn shape size and comments: Most of the animals have short horns, which are curved upwards. Some animals also have laterally erect or forward-curved orientation of horns.
Other specific visible traits: The breed is characterized by Small body size with slender legs; their ears are short (16 cm) and erect. Most of these animals have small humps and some bulls as well as a few cows have medium to large humps.
Location within country: Distributed in the highlands of Jem-Jem, Sidamo and Bale in southern Ethiopia. Specifically, found in the northern parts of Sidamo, in the Bale highlands and surrounding locations including Yirgalem in Sidamo.

Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity

Description: Grouped under small East African Zebu type breed
Provision Uses: Draught power, Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Color comments: majority coat colors are chestnut, black, white or red
Horn shape size and comments: It has short horns, the majority of which points sideways or downwards
Other specific visible traits: Hump is small but prominent.
Location within country: Distributed in the Jijiga area of Somali region of Ethiopia in an area adjoining (on the Somali side) of the border. The Jijiga Zebu occupies the mid-altitude zone between the Ogaden rangelands and the Hararghe highlands.

Description: The breed is Sanga type breed
Provision Uses: Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is resistant and well adapted to the extremely harsh condition of the area.
Special characteristic of product: The breed is resistant and well adapted to the extremely harsh condition of the area.
Color comments: Their coat color patterns were plain (grey, light brown, red, white and light yellow), patchy (brown grey, yellow brown, red brown, red white and white yellow) and spotty (brown grey, brown white, black white, white black, yellow brown, red white and red brown).
Other specific visible traits: The breed can be characterized by having a straight profile and long thin legs. Most of them have straight back with sloppy rump. Dewlap is moderately developed in males and fairly developed in females. They have long ears, long thin tail (but not touching the ground) with bushy ends, their skin is thick.
Location within country: Distributed in the Kereyu area of Eastern Shewa.The breed is dominantly found in Fentalle district of east Shewazone of Oromia Regional State. It also reported to be found in neighboring district of Boset and West Hararghe zone.

Description: Medenesbreed is cross of the Begait and Arado breeds
Provision Uses: Draught power, Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is adapted to extreme feed shortage.
Color comments: Has mostly black and white colour in varying patterns
Other specific visible traits: They are medium sized with large ears.
Location within country: Distributed in the hot to warm semi-arid low lands of Tahtayadiabo, Asgedetsimbla, Selemti, Welqite and Tsegede districts of western Tigray.

Description: Grouped under small East African Zebu type breeds.
Provision Uses: Draught power, Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Color comments: Coat colour is highly variable, and solid colors are rare. The colour combination overall include grey, white, black, chestnut, roan, pied with spots and striped.
Horn shape size and comments: horns are mainly large, usually curved inwards
Other specific visible traits: The breed body size is relatively larger as compared to other small East African Zebu type breeds; hump is prominent and well-developed.
Location within country: Maintained by the Musri and neighboring pastoral tribes of South Omo Zone of the Southern Nation, Nationality and Peoples Regional State.

Description: Sanga type breed
Provision Uses: Draught power, Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Color comments: It has light in shade colour, white with red or black patches being common.
Other specific visible traits: The breed is characterized by 24 - 30cm long and 20cm depth dewlap. Average adult live weight 550kg.
Location within country: Maintained by the Nuer and Anuak people of Gambela as well as adjoining eastern areas in south-western Ethiopia

Description: It is grouped under small East African Zebu type. The breed is similar to the Borana breed.
Provision Uses: Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Color comments: The breed has uniform plain white. However, some animals have shades of black around the face, hump and rump.
Horn shape size and comments: Most of them have short horns dominantly vertical, straight in shape, firm and not thick at base like the Borana.
Other specific visible traits: The position of the hump is thoracic. It has well-developed hump and large dewlap. They had level head, flat forehead and straight facial profile.
Location within country: Distributed in the Ogaden area of the Somali region and bordering Eastern Hararge.

Description: Sanga type breed.
Provision Uses: Draught power, Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Adaptability to specific environment: Has a trait of adaptive importance for the production system where the breed exists.
Color comments: Coat colour is mainly chestnut or ash-grey.
Horn shape size and comments: Long lyre-shaped horns, Horns can form almost a complete circle.
Other specific visible traits: The breed has large and slender body, small hump and moderate dewlap.
Location within country: Distributed in the east of lake Ashange of Tigray region and the bordering areas of Wello in north-eastern Ethiopia, specifically in Raya-Azebo, Alamata, Wajerat, and other districts of Tigray region.

Description: The only hump less short-horned taurine breed in east Africa.
Other name: Goda, Mizan,Tunt, Tunibey, Mulge, Mogul, Gombel, Semo and Dobe (all of them literally describe as the breed is either polled or has floating type of horn) are common names of the breed
Provision Uses: Draught power, Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is presumed to be trypanotolerant.
Color comments: They are glossy-red hair coat and blocky appearance. Has brown or black and white colour.
Horn shape size and comments: Majority of them are polled while the rest have stumpy or curved type of floating horn. Sheko cattle are predominantly polled with 84.8% and 89.9% in male and female population, respectively.
Other specific visible traits: The distinguishing features of Sheko cattle are prominent eye, folded type of eyelid. Humpless or with tiny hump.The overall adult wither height (cm) is 104.5 and over all adult live weights 194.4kg. The breed developed small hump due the introgression of Zebu from the surrounding area.
Location within country: Distributed in the humid parts of south-western Ethiopia with the Sheko tribe around Bench-Maji zone. More specifically, the breed is found in the Southern Nation, Nationality and Peoples Regional State especially of Bench Maji administrative zone in the district of Sheko, South Bench, North Bench, SheiBench,MenitGoldia, MenitShasha and GuraFerda and in the adjoining Kafa Zone (Chena, Beta districts); in the Shaka administrative Zone (Yeki district).

Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity

Description: Grouped under small East African Zebu type breed
Provision Uses: Draught power, Fuel (manure), Horns, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pollination and seed dispersal, Weed control and biomass residue management
Color comments: They are mainly black, but other colors are in combinations of red, black and white are also common.
Horn shape size and comments: The breed has short to moderate horn size
Other specific visible traits: The breed has small to medium sized hump.
Location within country: Distributed in Lay Gayint, TachGayint and Smada in south Gondar of north western Ethiopia in an area lying roughly between the blend of Abayriver to the south and mount Guna to the north.

Additional information: In 2004, there are 4500 breeding females of this breed.

Color comments: multi coloured: black and white
Description of origin: imported from Sweden and Denmark in 1960s and later from USA and the Netherlands.

Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Vegetation management
Additional information: In 2004: the cattle population of this breed increased in recent years. The culling programme carried out a rescue programme for breeds at risk, like the Eastern Finncattle.
Adaptability to specific environment: Adapted to the local habitat and production purposes.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The breed is known for its high twinning rate.
Special characteristic of product: The frequency of K-casein B is over 50%. Unique MHC polymorphism.
Other special qualities: Animals of this breed are mainly polled. The cows had to walk long distances during the war (1939-44) when Karelia was evacuated.

Other specific visible traits: Typically polled

Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Vegetation management

Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Vegetation management
Additional information: 2004: the cattle population of this breed increased in recent years. The culling programme carried out a rescue programme for breeds at risk, like the Northern Finncattle.
Adaptability to specific environment: Adapted to the local habitat and production purposes.
Special characteristic of product: The frequency of K-casein B is around 70%.
Other special qualities: Animals of this breed are mainly polled. They are extremely tame. The cows had to walk long distances during the war, especially in 1944-45 when Lapland was evacuated.

Description of origin: indigenous breed; White cattle of north Finland

Description Of Specific Uses: Yes

Other specific visible traits: bigger than Ghana Shorthorn
Description of origin: composite of Ghana Shorthorn and Zebu (White Fulani, sometimes Sokoto Gudali): Ghana Sanga is a more recent and specific cross compared to the general cattle group called Sanga and which comprises long term established zebu x humpless derivatives represented by several breeds in eastern Africa and southern Africa. The Ghana Sanga resembles the Shorthorn type more closely than does the zebu, but like the Zebu, it is found in drier areas of the country, towards the northern border and on the Accra plains extending into Volta Region.
Location within country: on the Accra plains extending into Volta Region, northern Ghana
Performance data reference: F20(2) -150 FAO Breed Survey Okantah S.A. (1991) Experiences in milk recording in small holder cattle herds in Ghana and Ethiopia; Unpublished results.

Description Of Specific Uses: Yes
Additional information: It constitutes 47% of national cattle population, Resistant to trypanosomiasis, Resistant to dermatophilosis Adapted to traditional husbandry systems.
Additional information comments: Numbers currently decreasing due to factors like outbreak of diseases like anthrax and brucelosis and the general decline in veterinary services.
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to the harsh conditions in the hot humid tropics.
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is reported to be tolerant to trypanosomiasis and tick borne diseases.
Other special qualities: The animals have a very good temperament.
Reference for special qualities: FAO Breed Survey Ngere et al., 1975. J.Agr.Sci (Ghana): Milking potential of the West African Shorthorn cow.
Color comments: multi coloured: black and white, solid black, mottled black and white
Other specific visible traits: Compact conformation with good muscling, Head is heavy as compared with the rest of the body, Wide forehead, Straight facial profile, Short horns, circular in cross section and thick at the base, Horns are thicker on bulls but firmer and pointed in cows, Ears are small and lateral, Small dewlap, Back is straight with a short loin, Neck and withers are short, thin in cows and thick in bulls, Chest is wide and rounded but constricted behind the fore legs, sloping slightly from the rump to the withers, Tail is long with a conspicuous terminal tufts, Udder is small and retracted with poorly developed teats, In more wooded areas, black or white and black coat colour predominates but brown, red or fawn animals are also found.
Description of origin: variety of West African Savannah Shorthorn with some Zebu influence
Location within country: Bole, Wa, Lawra, Tumu, northern Ghana
Performance data reference: F20(2) -148 FAO Breed Survey W78 F78-33, 48 Ngere et al (1975) Rege et al (1994) Anim Prod 59 (1) in press. Ngere et al (1975) Ghana J Agri Sci 8; 31-35. Vohdrasky, F. and Sada, I. , 1984.A contribution to the characteristics of the West African Shorthorn breed of Bos taurus cattle type 2. Some physical studies. Agric Tropica et Subtropica 17: 143-153 Otchere, E.O, Zuri, M.B. T, Karbo, N., Dei, H. K. and Djan-Fordjour, K. T., 2007. Ghana Journal of Animal Science, Vol 2 & 3. No.1 Pp 145-155.                                         Vohradsky, F. and Sada, I, 1984. A contribution to the characteristics of the West African Shorthorn breed of the Bos taurus cattle type. 2. Some physical studies. Agric Tropica et Subtropica 17: 191- 192.
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from the Agricultural Research Station, Lagon. The animals were raised on free range and were fed on grazing and fodder.

Additional performance parameters: The lactation data were collected from cows that were hand milked. The milking potential is much higher than that reported. Weighing calves before and after milk yield was estimated to be 774 kg and lactation length 295 days. overall mortality of 14.0% (4.40% occured before 3months of age and 9.60% thereafter).

Description: The N'dama is a breed of cattle from West and Central Africa. It has its cradle in Fouta-Djalon (in Guinea). It is the only breed that can be bred without too many problems in equatorial Africa because of its trypano-tolerance and its resistance to piroplasmosis transmitted by ticks. The N'dama is a hump , long -horned breed . The weight of the bulls varies from 280 to 320 kg, that of the cows from 219 to 237 kg. The age at first calving is 3.5 years. The interval between calving is 16 to 20 months with 80 % of calving.  The Ndama is compact, short on legs with a fine frame. The neckline is thick and deep. The back is horizontal from the withers to the implantation of the tail. The head is short and broad, in profile and broad snout . The rear is wide and well muscled. The horns are about 60 cm long and are shape a lyre upwards. The typical coat is fawn with the ends possibly darker. The breed is of medium size , i.e. 100 cm at the withers for cows and 120 cm for bulls.
Other name: Boyenca, Fouta Jallon, Fouta Longhorn, Futa, Malinke, Mandingo, N'dama Peti, Outa Malinke, Boenca

Other special qualities: The animals are well known for their hardiness.
Color comments: uni coloured: usually fawn, red or brown, occasionally black multi coloured: occasionally pied
Other specific visible traits: small animals; The phenotype is not very homogeneous and especially the body size may vary by regions within the country ranging from 1.0m to 1.25m.
Description of origin: introduced to Africa somewhere between 5.000 and 2.350 years B.C. from the Middle-East; local breed; West African Small Humpless Longhorn;
Location within country: 40% found in Fouta Djallon, 34% in high Guinea, 18 % in maritime Guinea and 8% in forest area
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data was measured on animals are kept under stationary or transhumant conditions and fed on grazing and crop by-products.
Comments management conditions: As a whole 66% of the stockbreeders keep 1-10 animals; 25 % of the stockbreeders have 11 to 30 animals; 8% of the stockbreeders hold 31 to 100 animals and 1,3% have 100 animals and more.
Additional performance parameters: The adult males weigh between 248 and 312,8 kg, while the females weigh between 173 and 200 kg within village herds. In traditional systems dairy production varies from one area to another; consumption of calf excluded, it is estimated between 0,4 and 0,5 liters per day in the lowland zones of Guinea, on the central plate of Fouta-Djalon 0,4 liter per day, in the pre-forest zone 0,6 to 0,8 liter per day. The fat content of milk is high (47,5 ± 1,5 G per liter). Parturation interval in on-station conditions range from 420-534 days and within traditional systems parturation interval ranges between 750-1080 days (25-36 months). Under good conditions N'dama cows can produce calves up to the age of 14-15 years.

Jersey is crossed with N'Dama breeds are used with the objective to produce F1 milking cows for peri-urban dairy production.

Description: 1. HEAD. It has a very wide front with a convex to ultra convex profile, making it unmistakable. The horns are dropped and directed downwards, and then backwards ending in an upward curvature 1.1. Ears Long, typical earrings, beginning in the shape of a tube with the upper portion rolled up on itself, then gradually opening outwards, curving inwards and tapering again at the tip with a broken end and tucked towards the face. 3.3. Back. Long and horizontal with little obvious musculature. 3.4. Loin Long and with a horizontal tendency harmoniously connected with the rump. 3.5. Haunch. Square in shape with slight narrowing between the sit bones, wide, long and slightly uneven and with little obvious musculature. 3.6. Tail Of medium length with harmonious insertion, tapering from the base towards the tassel, which must be entirely of black hairs . 4. MEMBERS 4.1. Former members. Mobility: The heels and hooves are evaluated taking into account the movement of the joints, the length and direction of the step. They must be functional, long with fine bones. 4.1.1. Front legs Its position seen from the front and from the side must be taken into account. The hands and hooves should be parallel to the shoulders allowing maximum support and stability during movement. 4.2. Hindquarters. Mobility: Legs and hooves are evaluated, taking into account the movement of the joints, the length and direction of the step, these must be firm, long, fluid and natural without evidence of pain or cramps. 4.2.1. Rear Legs. Viewed from the side, the legs are moderately inclined (Angle) with respect to the hock and seen from behind, straight well separated with hooves placed symmetrically. The hock must have adequate flexibility without swelling. 4.3. Anterior and posterior pasterns Strong, flexible and of medium length with no evidence of weakness. 4.4. Black hooves , closed.
Description Of Specific Uses: They are mainly used as breeders with purebred females with Genealogical Record and commercial herds, according to their milk or meat trend, as is the demand of farmers. Lately it has had a boom in our country, so new breeders of the breed in reference have been joining.

Import: At present they are adapted to the Guatemalan subtropical climate.
Location within country: Breed that is located in the Departments of Jutiapa, Santa Rosa, Escuintla, Genova Costa Cuca Quetzaltenango, Petén, Izabal

Color comments: uni coloured: yellowish-brown, brown, dark brown
Efabis main colour: Always uniform in colour, light brown, red to black colour with a stripe on the back in contrast with the main colour. Smaller frequency of Buša of "prutasta" colour (narrow tiger like stripes along the body). Buša typically has a brown muzzle (dark pigmented mucosa with a white border line). Horns and hooves are always dark coloured. On short horns, white covering is frequent around the root of the horn, and tips are regularly black. Bone structure of the head is gentle, forehead regularly broad, horns short, more or less curved, in basis horizontally directed. The neck is dry, tight skinned with no dewlap expressed. Back are narrow, short and straight, croup pointed and struck down.
Horn shape size and comments: Horns and hooves are always dark coloured. On short horns, white covering is frequent around the root of the horn, and tips are regularly black.
Other specific visible traits: Brachyceros type, small stature
Description of origin: indigenous breed indigenous breed of Brachyceros type; Busa is surely phylogenetically strongly related with Busa populations in neighbouring states.

Color comments: uni coloured: grey
Other specific visible traits: strong hooves
Description of origin: indigenous breed Busa improved with Tyrol Grey (Austria)

Additional information: 2003: Holstein cattle account for 7 % of the total cattle population. Participation of particular breeds has not changed much in the last years, but it is estimated that the introduction of Holstein-Friesian breeds will increase.
Color comments: multi coloured: black pied
Description of origin: imported from The Netherlands, USA and Canada

Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fire protection, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Vegetation management
Cultural Uses: Cultural and religious ceremonies, Research, Tourist attraction / touristic potential
Description Of Specific Uses: This breeds has a very little significance in food and agriculture sector because more than 95% of milk and meat are produced from continually imported breeds.
Adaptability to specific environment: High heat tolerance and adaptation to the local karst region are reported for this breed.
Other special qualities: This breed is known for longevity and being moderate in nutrition (karst pasture land, browsing, straw).
Color comments: In its roots greyish to yellowish, and from centre upwards dark grey to black. Calves are mostly red upon birth, but can also be white to grey.
Efabis main colour: Most common are uni coloured light grey to white colour with transitions in darker grey shades. Bulls are commonly darker then cows and heifers. One of the specificities (more often in bulls) is the darker pigment of the neck, shoulder blade, lower ribs and belly, nose ridge, falangue, part of the face, around the eyes, borders and inside of earlobes and lower inner part of the tail. Mucosa on eye lids and eyelashes is dark grey to black, same as mucosa of the anal opening, female sex organ and skin of strong epidermis. Tongue is led grey, while palate is almost black.
Horn shape size and comments: Horns are proportionally long with a span of 70 cm and more, and shaped like a lyre.
Other specific visible traits: Istrian cattle is late mature, longevity breed of moderate size of frame (ridge height 135 to 150 cm), shank girth 20-22 cm, horn length 40-55 cm). Bulls reach 140 to 155 withers height.
Description of origin: Istrian cattle in its phenotype is similar to podolian cattle whose ancient homeland is the area of Podolia and Volhinia from where it spread to the larger part of Panonia, and along the Adriatic Coast to South Europe and North Africa. At the end of the 18th century a targeted introduction of podolian primigen Italian breeds from Romagna, Puglia, Marcha and Polesina was made.
Import: since 1950, > 30% from Austrian Brown (Austria), German Brown (Germany), Brown-Swiss (USA)

Description Of Specific Uses: Beef production depends on the change in the number of Simmental cows.
Additional information: 2003: Simmental is a dominant cattle breed in Croatia, about 84% of the total cattle population is Simmental breed.
Special characteristic of product: This breed is producing marbled meat.
Color comments: multi coloured: red and yellow pied with white head
Description of origin: imported from Switzerland, Germany and Austria
Import: since 1950 from Red Holstein (USA, Canada) and they are still continually imported

Other name: Slavonsko srijemski podolac, Slavonski podolac, Slavonian Podolian cattle
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention
Additional information: 2003: Syrmian Podolian Cattle have only a dozen or so heads and belong to the category of critically endangered breeds.
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is known for its adaptation to the locally extreme climatic conditions.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The females are known for calving ease.
Other special qualities: This breed is known for longevity.
Color comments: uni coloured: grey
Other specific visible traits: very long horn
Description of origin: indigenous breed indigenous breed of Podolic origin

Hungarian Simmental is registered as an endangered variety. There are approximately about 100,000 of the Hungarian Simmental with dual purpose. Hungarian Simmental for dual purpose accounts for 17.7% of the total cattle stock.
