Description: Burlina is an autochthonous dual purpose breed from the mountains of Veneto region in North-East Italy. It is mainly distributed in the provinces of Treviso, Verona and Vicenza. Burlina cattle are small, with a pied black-and-white coat. The breed is well adapted to graze on poor or marginal mountain pasture, and is small-sized, hardy, rugged and resistant to diseases. The milk is traditionally used in the production of the local "Morlacco del Grappa" cheese. It is a relic breed and a preservation program is ongoing.
Other name: Binda, Boccarda, Pezzata degli altipiani, Bassanese
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: No
Efabis cultural role comment: rediscovery of ancient traditions of farming and processing as part of our cultural heritage, of our memory
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is known for its adaptation to the local marginal conditions.
Special characteristic of product: As for the quality of milk, understood as a function of the basic parameters of quality merchandise, it was found that the milk produced at the farm has a higher average content in milk fat compared to the plain, which, however, is characterized by higher concentrations of lactose and fat dry matter, the latter influenced by the protein content Il Morlacco del Grappa; La Caciotta; Allevo di breve maturazione, vecchio e stravecchio; Allevo di Altissimo
Other special qualities: This breed has good production qualities.
Reference for special qualities: The attitude of the milk produced by dairy cows of this breed has been the subject of extensive studies which have reflected in their exalted qualities and specificity equal to other
Efabis genetic features: An experimental work has estimated genetic parameters of production traits and somatic cell of the breed Burlina. The heritability and 18.8% for the production of milk, 27.5% for the content of fat, 35.8% for the content of protein and 6.7% for SCS (somatic cells). Genetic correlations between all characters are tend to low, with the exception of that between fat and protein (0.629). The results are in line with the values ​​reported in the literature for the races cosmopolitan. The reproductive values ​​showed the presence of genetic variability in the population, exploited for the genetic improvement of production traits, and especially for indirect selection against mastitis through the use of SCS.
Efabis adaptability to marginal land: is a rustic cow, grazer an excellent, long-lived, resistant to the rigors of the climate, self-sufficient in the management of childbirth and sober in power.
Color comments: multi coloured: black, white, blond, red with light rim around black muzzle
Efabis main colour: Shiny black coat dappled with prevalence of black on white, white coloration of the lower limbs, tails and white bow
Horn shape size and comments: Reading, curved slightly forward in bulls and cows in the high, rounded cross-section and thickness accentuated in males, much lighter in girls and elliptical cross-section in the horizontal part.
Other specific visible traits: Coat: black brindle; skin: thin, elastic and easily detachable from the underlying tissues; stature and size: size; Head: light, tend to be elongated profile straight or slightly concave; bright eyes on edge of head, large ears, long nose, muzzle wide, wide jaws, horns read, curved directed forward and upward Front: harmonious and well-shaped, with a slight dewlap developed neck, withers not open and not overly sharp; members and little muscular shoulders, broad chest, with ribs not too flat , not too long but slightly arched; little muscular limbs, claws well developed and solids; Dorsal line: straight, spine is not very pronounced, wide loins; Croup: basically square, slightly sloping, well set tail, long and thin with bow abundant , Breast: globular; quarters uniforms, nipples relatively long veins developed
Description of origin: first hypothesis: the Burlina has a common origin with other breeds spotted in Northern Europe and would come to our lands brought by the Cimbri, the original population of the peninsula of Jutland (Denmark); second hypothesis: A second way, still under occurs, consider this breed as native to Asia and argues that through the Russian plains and the mountains of the Caucasus cows have been brought, with the movement of nomadic populations, in part of the Carpathian mountains and partly on the Balkans. The animals would then come in Veneto with the Most Serene Republic of Venice, which for many centuries entertained trade with those areas. One certainty is that in 1800 there were in the territory of Vicenza bred animals Burlina with all the features of alpine dairy breeds, for instance, the small head, protruding eyes, extreme hardiness and a remarkable ability to adapt to the roughest pastures and "lean ", while still maintaining a good lactiferous capacity.
Location within country: Regione Veneto, Campania, Province: Belluni,Treviso, Vicenza, Monte Grappa, Altopiano di Asiago, Benevento, Castel di Sangro (AQ)

Description: Cabannina is a local dual purpose breed from the Liguria region in Italy. The breed originates from Val d’Aveto (Genova), from crosses between Bruna bulls and an iberian-podolica cross-bred population. Milk is of high quality, influenced by the forage essences available in local pasture. It is used to make the local cheese "U Cabanin". It is a relic breed and a preservation program is ongoing.
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: No
Efabis cultural role comment: we can say that the Cabannina, for the province of Genoa, is the testimony of the indissoluble bond between a territory and its products, and expresses in the most happy the process of encounter and fit between the characteristics of a race and the environment where it has evolved and maintained over time.
Adaptability to specific environment: Excellent grazer, know how to use effectively the resources of the Ligurian vegetable, even in areas with steep slopes
Specific resistance or tolerance: Rustic and resistant to various pathogens
Special characteristic of product: 'U Cabannin' is the unique and valuable derived from raw milk Cabannina: has a cylindrical shape with flat sides from 17-19 cm and height of 7-9 cm. Seasonality of course, at least two months in the cool environment of the Aveto. The dough is firm and elastic, slightly soluble in color from white to ivory with sparse holes cheese 'U Cabannin' obtained from the processing of raw milk Cabannina
Other special qualities: the ability to use coarse food, not very attractive for dairy animals of other breeds, the distinction of good and tenacious grazed able to climb or to penetrate densely bushy areas and rugged, make it extremely well suited to our area cattle
Efabis adaptability to marginal land: Excellent grazer, know how to use effectively the resources of the Ligurian vegetable, even in areas with steep slopes.
Efabis main colour: Astano dark line mills with light-colored and reddish shades
Horn shape size and comments: horns of medium length, thin, white at the base and black at the tip directed outwards, upwards and slightly back
Other specific visible traits: Size: small and light; coat and pigmentation: fine and soft skin with many folds on the dewlap, coat dark brown, sometimes light brown with intermediate shades, a very clear line mulina (cream-colored) characterizes the lumbosacral line with reddish tones. The hair is short and fine, the skin is pigmented, head, small, short, light and thin. straight profile dark eyes of medium size, large ears carried horizontally wide nostrils, black muzzle widely adorned in white, strong jaws, horns of medium length, thin, white at the base and black at the tip directed outwards, upwards and slightly back , front: harmonious horizontal thin long neck, with little dewlap; withers tight, shoulders harmonics chest of medium size; limbs with fine bones, strong feet and tightened with unghielli very hard; topline: regular, wide loins, croup: well developed broad and long, high-set tail, long, with large bunch; hindquarters: well sprung with well muscled thighs; hocks dishes with a slight angle, standing strong and tight; tethers are short, strong sexual characteristics: breast of proper invoice and good dimensions. The attack is wide and tall well back, is protruding between the thighs; regular quarters; nipples well-placed right size; mammary veins obvious and curvy with a large fountain of milk.
Description of origin: Originally from the Ligurian Apennines (provinces of La Spezia and Genoa). This breed is continuously decreasing and is facing extinction.

Description: Calvana cattle are bred in Tuscany, in central Italy, particularly in the provinces of Florence and Prato, but also in the provinces of Pistoia and Siena. Previously considered as a variety of Chianina breed, it is now recognised as a separate breed. The Calvana was in the past used for meat and work, but it is now kept for meat exclusively. It is a relic breed and a preservation program is ongoing.
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Fire protection, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: No
Additional information: always been considered a dual-purpose breed (work - meat) in the past has been used mostly for work while today it is bred for meat production
Adaptability to specific environment: Excellent grazer, know how to use effectively the available plant resources of the Apennines
Specific resistance or tolerance: Rustic and resistant to various pathogens
Special characteristic of product: T-bone steak, pot roasts and stews, these products typical of the Tuscan tradition
Efabis genetic features: Results of molecular analysis (STR) at the population level: the number of alleles and heterozygosity, the mean number of alleles per locus was relatively low (6.9), due to the presence of many actors linked by close ties of kinship and phenomena of inbreeding, but still higher than that found by the same in Garfagnina (6.5) and in Pontremolese (5,6). L 'observed heterozygosity is significantly lower than expected under Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium (0.411 vs. 0.673), intermediate between that of Pontremolese and Garfagnina. In conclusion we can say that there is a reduced genetic variability within the population
Efabis adaptability to marginal land: It is well suited to pasture even in difficult conditions.
Efabis main colour: porcelain white coat so in females than in bulls, and the calf is born fawn
Horn shape size and comments: short yellow at the base and black at the tip, in cows fit slightly forward and up, in bulls fit on the forward axis and head laterally forward and slightly upward
Other specific visible traits: size: medium large; coat and pigmentation: pigmented skin, thin, pasty, easy to lift, plenty of subcutaneous connective tissue; porcelain white coat so in females than in bulls who have successfully completed one year of age; bulls in gray shades can be found at circles in the front parts of the body and on the outside of the thighs, head light and expressive in cows, bulls in the shortest orbital detected with arches above; profile straight or slightly snub; eyes on edge of head and lively; pavilion with normal ears headset tending to thin, wide nostrils, black muzzle, strong jaws, short horns of yellow at the base and black at the tip, in cows fit slightly forward and upward, the bulls are part of the front axle, they head sideways forward and slightly upward; front: appiombi regular, short neck and muscular, of medium length with vertical skin folds on the sides, dewlap of average development in the anterior two-thirds, more abundant in the posterior third of the cows; withers higher than the back; muscular shoulders and attached to the body; chest is broad, deep and muscular, well-directed feet, toes tight; dorsal line: straight and muscular back and loins; lumbosacral attack straight; rump: Broad, set tail regularly thin, long enough that the stem does not exceed the point of the hock, the hind limbs: Perpendicular, muscular legs and thighs and buttocks thick; sexual characteristics: breast sufficiently voluminous; quarters uniform nipples with well-developed, visible veins.
Description of origin: A first hypothesis explains the origne of this breed to be due to the prolonged cross-breeding of existing hybrids containing blood of cattle podolici with the Chianina. Another hypothesis by origne to this breed of cattle from the merger of the Chianina breed for at least 20 centuries of Tuscany and Umbria, with cattle lineage podolica imported during the invasions.

Description: The Charolais is an international breed beef cattle. It originates in, and is named after, the Charolais area surrounding Charolles, in the Bourgogne-Franche-Comté region of Central-eastern France. Charolais is bred for meat.
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Fire protection, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: No

Description: Breed of Etruscan origin, it has been bred for over twenty-two centuries in Umbria, Tuscany and Lazio. Religious ceremonies and sacrifices of white cattle (bos magnus et albus) were common in ancient Rome. Chianina is the tallest bovine breed in the World: originally farm working animals, they are now bred for beef. The large T-bone steaks from Chianina carcasses are used for the typical "Bistecca alla fiorentina" grilled meat. The meat from this breed is a Protected Geographical Indication (PGI) certified as "Vitellone Bianco dell'Appennino Centrale" in a specific area of origin.
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Fire protection, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: This breed is one of the three breeds used to produce "Vitellone bianco dell'Appennino Centrale" PGI (Protected Geographical Indication)
Additional information: Type broiler characterized by somatic gigantism, large torso length, light skeleton. Nevrile, lively, adaptable to various environments and modest food.
Special characteristic of product: Protected Geographical Indication (PGI) White Bullock of the CENTRAL APPENNINO
Efabis genetic features: BLUP Animal Model; 'Index Morphology
Efabis main colour: Porcelain White. One can see gray shades in the front parts of the body
Horn shape size and comments: short, rather thin elliptical cross-section, directed laterally and forward
Other specific visible traits: Cloak - white porcelain . Can be found in the gray shades diffuse fronts corpo.Pigmentazione - have black pigmentation of the following parts : the free margin of the eyelids and eyelashes , oral mucosa , and perianal region perivulvare , tassel of the tail, the bottom of the scrotum , the pisciolare bow , muzzle , hooves and tips of the horns. The persistence of red hairs limited to the region of sincipite , a gray tail and partial depigmentation of the oral mucosa , are tolerated in subjects in possession of high morpho-functional requirements . Cute - pigmented , thin, easy to lift . Head - light , distinguished , expressive frontonasal profile with straight , wide muzzle , eyes on edge of head and vivid. Short horns , rather thin elliptical cross-section , directed laterally and forward. And ' Dehorning is allowed . Neck - short , muscular with a rather pronounced hump in bulls , muscular females ; slight dewlap . Shoulders - broad , muscular and well attached to the body , parallel to the median sagittal plane and properly angled . Withers - broad and muscular . Back - wide and muscular. Loins - muscular , thick , wide, long , back-lumbar line straight . Chest - broad and muscular chest - wide and deep . Of height at least equal to the distance sternum-ground with well arched cost Belly - large and sustained. Hips - full, well-connected with the adjacent areas . Croup - very muscular, very developed in length and width , horizontal or with a slight inclination angle . The sacral vertebrae are not detected. Thin tail with regular attack . Thigh - thick , downhill and convex , accentuated development of muscolare.Natica - markedly convex and descent . Forelegs - appiombi corrected, arm and forearm . Solid and light shin . Hindquarters - appiombi correct , muscular leg , lean strong hocks , solid and light shin . Feet - strong , tight , with high heels . Breast - developed vascularized and broad-based. Regular quarters . Spongy to the touch. Nipples very direct and just the right size for nursing. Testicles - proportionate, developed , and descended into the scrotum .
Description of origin: The Chianina is known and appreciated since 'antiquity: the Etruscans and the Romans used animals from the meal in our warm blanket in the triumphal parades and for their sacrifices to the gods, and large white cattle that most likely were the ancestors of today's cattle of the Chiana Valley
Location within country: ABRUZZO – BASILICATA – CALABRIA – CAMPANIA – EMILIA ROMAGNA – LAZIO – LOMBARDIA – MARCHE – MOLISE –PIEMONTE - PUGLIA – SARDEGNA – TOSCANA – UMBRIA – VENETO.

Description: Cinisara is a local dual purpose breed from the province of Palermo, in the Southern Italian island of Sicily. Medium-small sized breed with excellent grazing attitude. The coat is mainly uniform black, but also black pied or red pied animals are accepted. Milk yield is higher than Modicana, the other autochthonous Sicilian cattle, and milk is mainly used in cheese making.
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: No
Efabis cultural role comment: The Cinisara cow is valuable to the local enterprise and above all it is a privileged samples of livestock in the province
Adaptability to specific environment: It is fine but strong bones from cattle, from the tireless ability pascolatoria, adapted to poor pastures that can optimally exploit
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is reported to be resistant to anaplasmosis, piroplasmosis and tuberculosis.
Special characteristic of product: from his milk gives even caciocavallo (il caciocavallo di Palermo), ricotta and mozzarella
Other special qualities: its lactation curve is characterized by two peaks of production, one physiological (after about 5-6 weeks from birth) and one in correspondence of the spring period, in which there is a greater availability of fodder
Efabis adaptability to marginal land: It is a very rustic cattle, which prefers the steep pastures and poor which has been adapted for centuries, so much so that on-site it says that "The cow licks Cinisara stones and makes milk" .
Color comments: uni coloured: black
Other specific visible traits: size: medium; coat and pigmentation: thin skin, elastic and easily detachable from the underlying tissues, with short wool, fine and thick, black cloak uniform or with the typical size "agghia" (black with a white band which affects the head, topline, perineum, tail and ventral line), head light with a straight profile, large eyes, dark and lively, slightly protruding ears large with short hair and long thick outside edge of the ear extending to the hairless internally, black nostrils, black muzzle, long and strong jaws, curved horns, a black color. Front: thick neck, withers reading to the topline with peaks close well, strong shoulders and firmly attached; chest strong and deep, sturdy limbs, feet nails with sturdy black tending to slate. Topline: Horizontal with mild depression; loins in line with the back. Croup: detected and sloping, tail with high attack, presents slight relief of the first caudal vertebrae, with robust stem at the base, long and ending no later than the hock with black bow abundant. Hindquarters: long, with light bones; little thighs muscular, flat; appiombi regular, strong hocks; tethers short; unghielli tightened hard and compact. Sexual characters: breast uniform black, slightly hairy, with broad-based on high later; nipples tend to be long and thick; venous system embossed with large fountains and marked ..
Location within country: Sicily Region (marginal areas of the coastal and inland the northwestern part of the province of Palermo)
Additional performance parameters: the flesh of Cinisara tends to be clearer and brighter than that of other beef breeds. protein content is found to be the same (22%) than that of other breeds such as the Piemontese, Chianina and Bianca Belgian Blue, while the lipid content is found to be very low (1.9% for males and 2.6% for females).

Description: Holstein Friesian is the most famous international breed of dairy cattle. The breed originated from The Netherlands and it was improved in North America. It is now the most widespread dairy cattle in the world. The first Friesian cattle were introduced In Italy back in 1872 in Reggio Emilia, while U.S. Holstein Friesian was first imported in the Province of Rome in the late 1930's. By large the most widespread dairy cattle in Italy, its milk is also used for PDO cheese productions such as Gorgonzola, Grana Padano, Parmigiano Reggiano and Provolone.
Provision Uses: General crossbreeding, Meat, Milk, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer
Description Of Specific Uses: No
Additional information: The cosmopolitan character of the breed has meant, in fact, that in the countries where it has been bred populations are created with distinctive characteristics determined by the particular environmental conditions and breeding and selection of the various objectives pursued. The first subjects imported in the second half of the last century, from Holland, immediately showed great adaptability and production, while showing morphological characteristics typical of a dual-purpose breed. One of the founders of the Italian Friesian, the bull Carnation Producer, was purchased in the U.S. herd of Reclamation of Torre in Pietra (1929).
Efabis genetic features: Due to the presence of a recessive trait, in the breeding of Friesian may be present subjects with mantle piebald red. This, however, does not affect the purity of race and the subjects with this characteristic can be enrolled in the National Herd Book
Horn shape size and comments: very short in females, slightly longer in the bull
Other specific visible traits: Dappled coat black or red piebald . Tall stature . Expressive head , proportionate, distinct and strong, with well-defined outline and net jugular species in the region and with the upper profile straight , bright eyes , the ears are very mobile ; nostrils large , broad muzzle and strong jaws . Front harmonious whole; neck rather long and thin , rich in skin folds ; tightened pronounced withers and quite sharp ; shoulders harmoniously blended with the neck, chest high and wide to help increase the chest cavity ; limbs upright , well-spaced , with flat bone , strong feet , tight and with high sole. Topline straight , discovered, without empty retroscapolare and loins wide and strong. Croup long and wide, roughly level is not slanted towards the loins , with sacral vertebrae and the coccyx also slightly raised , not flat or tail attack back or too high, rather thin tail . Hindquarters upright , rightly placed , strong, lean, with flat bones ; buttocks with a straight profile hocks flat and wide , with a slight angle, free of defects and with visible veins and tendons . Feet strong , very compact, with high sole , especially the heel ; shackles short and strong . Fore udder moderately long and firmly attached , with lower profile and very nearly straight upward and lateral profile slightly rounded ; abdominal veins prominent and tortuous veins highly branched mammary not too big and accounted for; spongy tissue and elastic. Rear udder firmly attached , high and wide rear profile in line with or slightly projecting with respect to that of the buttocks ; marked division in correspondence of the suspensory ligament central veins and mammary tissue as in the front . Lower floor ( bottom of the breast to the point of insertion of the nipples ) parallel to the ground and not below the floor of the hocks . Strong median suspensory ligament , which divides the breast into two equal parts and symmetrical. Nipples just the right size , perpendicular , inserted in the center of each quarter , cylindrical trunks and ending with a strong sphincter.

Description: Garfagnina is a cattle breed from Tuscany in central Italy. A direct descendant of the primitive Podolica, it used to be a triple purpose breed (milk, meat and work). Since the beginning of XX Century, it was gradually replaced by other breeds. It is a relic breed and a preservation program is ongoing.
Other name: Modenese di monte, Montanara, Nostrana, Grigia appenninica
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: No
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to the local environment (hills and mountains).
Special characteristic of product: beef ofGargagnana and of Valle del Serchio
Efabis adaptability to marginal land: the breed is distinguished by good skills as poor utilization of grass sprouts of the forest and chestnut and well suited to the harsh weather conditions of the area
Efabis main colour: the coat, also called "frosted", has a color ranging from light gray to dark gray
Horn shape size and comments: horns pointing upward in the shape of a lyre. The color is light at the base of the horns becoming darker towards the tip
Other specific visible traits: size: medium; coat pigmentation and color of skin slate, thin and easy to lift; frosted cloak, head light of medium length, straight profile, dark eyes, ears frost edge slate; nostrils clear; muzzle slate, sturdy jaws; horns facing upwards in the shape of pounds, clear and dark all'attaccatura towards the tip. Front: thick neck, withers harmonious, strong shoulders and firmly attached, broad chest and deep, sturdy limbs, feet nails with robust color slate. Topline: curved downward; loins depressed. Croup: Broad and narrow sloping, strong tail with black bow high attack. Hindquarters: slightly mowed; skinny thighs, hocks slender, normal feet, long tethers. Sexual characters: breast slightly hairy; closer quarters; nipples regular; pronounced veins.
Description of origin: Cattle population in developed specific ecotype in the Apennines area of Garfagnana, a present time in the provinces of Massa Carrara, Lucca and Pistoia in Tuscany, Parma, Modena and Reggio in Emilia Romagna
Management system: Back Yard or Farm Yard Production, Scavenger

Description: Grigio Alpina - Grauvieh cattle is a dual purpose breed from Alto Adige/South Tyrol in Italy. Well adapted to mountain pastures, it shows very good milk and beef performances. It significantly contributes to local supply of milk for fresh consumption, as well as for the production of yogurt and cheese such as Graukaese, Puzzone di Moena, and Toblacher Stangenkase. A specific genetic program implemented since 1990 has differentiated this breed from the similar Tyroler Grauvieh breed in North Tyrol in Austria.
Provision Uses: Herding, Meat, Milk, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: No
Additional information comments: An irreplaceable role for a multifunctional sustainable development of mountain environment.
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to the local environment (mountains).
Color comments: uni coloured: grey
Other specific visible traits: The typical colour is lighter silver with darker shades around eyes, on neck, shoulders and hips. Sires are darker. Clear horns with dark tip
Description of origin: composite of local Grigia, Ultimo, Isarco, Passiria and Sare
Location within country: Grigio Alpina (Grauvieh) is traditionally diffused in Provinces of Bolzano and Trento and Belluno. In the last years some herds are emerging out of this area both in Norther and in Southern Italy.
Additional performance parameters: mean milk yield : 5065 kg with 3.73% of fat and 3.36% of protein

Description: Jersey is an international breed of British origin. Small-sized dairy cattle, they produce milk with very high fat and protein contents. In Italy, it is mostly kept together with other dairy breeds in order to improve the quality of bulk milk.
Provision Uses: Meat, Milk, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer
Description Of Specific Uses: No

Description: Limousine is an international beef breed originated from the Limousin region in France. It is generally farmed on range for the production of calves. These cattle are very robust and easy calving. After weaning the calves are fattened on farm where they efficiently produce high quantities of lean meat. The breed is also intensively used for crossing on dairy cows in order to obtain crosses more suitable for fattening. The quality of meat is good: lean, fine-grained and not coarse in fibre.
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Fire protection, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: No

Description: Marchigiana is an autochthonous beef breed from the Marche region, in central-Est Italy. Marchigiana breed derives from Asian cattle arrived in Italy around the 4th century AD. Crossing with Chianina and Romagnola were made to improve the breed, and then stopped in 1928 to fix the obtained traits. It has being exported to various European countries, North and South America. The Marchigiana is a large breed bred for meat production. The meat from this breed is a Protected Geographical Indication (PGI) certified as "Vitellone Bianco dell'Appennino Centrale" in a specific area of origin.
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: This breed is one of the three breeds used to produce "Vitellone bianco dell'Appennino Centrale" PGI (protected geographical indication)
Adaptability to specific environment: the excellent adaptability makes it an ideal cattle for grazing in difficult terrain, and then a recovery vehicle and economic exploitation of the so-called "marginal lands"
Efabis genetic features: BLUP Animal Model; 'Index Morphology'
Efabis main colour: gray almost white in both sexes. In males the presence of gray hairs in the forehand and around the eyes (holes). The calves from birth to 4-6 months are fromentino.
Horn shape size and comments: Horns medium-short and coarse, black tip
Other specific visible traits: Coat - white. Gray shades can be found widespread in the front parts of the body. Pigmentation - Black, varying in intensity of the skin, oral mucosa and natural openings. The persistence of red hairs limited to the region of sincipite, a gray tail and partial depigmentation of the oral mucosa, are tolerated in subjects in possession of high morpho-functional requirements. Cute - thin and easy to lift, soft to the touch. Head - light, with a straight profile. The horns are short and elliptical cross-section, directed laterally and upward. it permitted Dehorning Neck - Short and muscular. Massive and lumpy in males. Light dewlap. Shoulders - broad, muscular and well attached to the body, parallel to the median sagittal plane and properly angled. Withers - broad and muscular. Back - muscular, well developed in length and in width. Loins - muscular, thick, wide, long, back-lumbar line straight. Chest - broad and muscular. Chest - broad and deep, height greater than the distance sternum / soil, with well arched cost. Belly - large and sustained. Hips - full, well-connected with the adjacent areas. Croup - very muscular, developed in length and width, horizontal or slightly anterior-posterior tilt, sacral vertebrae are not detected. Tail end with correct attachment. Thigh - wide and thick, convex, downhill, with pronounced muscular development. Buttock - descent with a convex profile and very obvious. Forelegs - plumbs corrected, arm and forearm. Solid and light shin. Hindquarters - plumbs correct, very muscular leg, lean strong hocks, solid and light shin. Absence of tare. Feet - strong, tight, with high heels. Breast - developed vascularized and broad-based. Regular quarters. Spongy to the touch. Nipples very direct and just the right size for nursing. Testicles - proportionate, developed, and descended into the scrotum
Description of origin: it is derived from the crossing of sires Romagnola and Chianina with cows belonging to an ancient Podolian breed
Location within country: ABRUZZO – BASILICATA – CALABRIA – CAMPANIA – EMILIA ROMAGNA – LAZIO – LOMBARDIA – MARCHE – MOLISE – PUGLIA – SARDEGNA – SICILIA – TOSCANA – UMBRIA – VENETO.

Description: Maremmana is a very characteristic, long horned, beef breed reared in the Maremma, a former marshland region in Central-West Italy. The breed was used for field work. Its origin traces back to Asian Grey Cattle, in Italy since Etruscan times. The breed as we know it today is likely to derive from crossings with Podolian cattle taken by Eastern invaders at the end of the Roman Empire. It is exclusively kept on range in the provinces of Grosseto, Rome and Viterbo. This breed is perfectly adapted to the harsh terrain and poor pastures. It shows an excellent maternal ability and for this it is often used as maternal breed in crosses with beef breeds.
Provision Uses: Dam line, General crossbreeding, Herding, Meat, Skin/hides, Surrogate milk provision for suckling
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Fire protection, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Cultural Uses: Cultural and religious ceremonies, Tourist attraction / touristic potential
Description Of Specific Uses: No
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to the local environment (marginal areas).
Color comments: uni coloured: medium grey
Other specific visible traits: very long
Location within country: Toscana Region and Latium Region, central Italy

Description: Bianca Modenese is an autochthonous dual purpose breed from the province of Modena, in the Emilia Romagna region in North Italy. Medium sized, females are milky white coated while bulls are a little darker. It is a relic breed and an ongoing preservation program is trying to promote its products: the milk is used for the production of a breed specific Parmigiano Reggiano “di Bianca”, while meat is of excellent quality, savory and well marbled.
Provision Uses: Meat, Milk, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer
Description Of Specific Uses: No
Efabis cultural role comment: for Parmiggiano Reggiano Production
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to the local environment (hills and plains).
Color comments: uni coloured: white with black hooves, black muzzle and white horns black-tipped

Description: Modicana is a red coated cattle breed from the Italian island of Sicily (South Italy). It is a dual purpose breed (milk and meat) capable to stand very hot climate. Milk is used for Caciocavallo «Ragusano PDO» cheese and other high quality cheeses.
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: No
Specific resistance or tolerance: The animals are reported to be resistant to anaplasmosis, piroplasmosis and tuberculosis.
Color comments: uni coloured: brown with dark muzzle, dark-tipped horns

Description: Mucca Pisana is a breed of large cattle from Tuscany, in central Italy. Females coat is brown, with graduations from light to dark. They have a reddish dorsal line called “spigatura”. Males have a darker coat. It's a dual purpose, fast growing breed and its meat is very appreciated and certified by a quality brand. It is a relic breed and a preservation program is ongoing.
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: No
Color comments: uni coloured: brown, chestnut to black
Other specific visible traits: brown to black coloured coat; black mucosae and blacK muzzle, surrounded by a light ring; harmonious and medium-high animals.
Description of origin: composite of Italian Brown and Chianina

Description: Pezzata Rossa Italiana is an international breed widespread over many European countries. Breeding in Italy began in the North-Eastern Friuli region by crossing a local red pied population with Swiss, German and Austrian Simmental bulls. For years the breed was called "Pezzata Rossa Friulana", assuming the denomination of "Italiana" only in 1986 after its diffusion throughout Italy. it is a dual purpose breed: the milk is used for the production of over 20 cheeses including Montasio PDO and Latteria. The cheese exclusively produced by Pezzata Rossa milk is marketed under the “Solo di Pezzata Rossa Italiana” brand. Pezzata Rossa is also used as a beef breed to produce medium-heavy calves intended for fattening, particularly in Central and South Italy.
Provision Uses: Meat, Milk, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Skin/hides, Surrogate milk provision for suckling
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer
Description Of Specific Uses: No
Color comments: multi coloured: red, white

Description: Pezzata Rossa d'Oropa is a cattle breed from Piemonte region (North-west Italy). The Pezzata Rossa d'Oropa is of medium size, the coat is spotted red with a gradation from fromentine to red, brown on a white background. It is a dual-purpose breed and the breeding system is based on summer pasture and winter stabling. In the area of Biella, it significantly contributes to the supply milk for the production of Toma Biellese cheese.
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: No
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to the local environment (mountains).
Color comments: multi coloured: red, white, occasionally black-pied with white head

Description: Piemontese is an autochthonous breed of domestic cattle from the region of Piedmont, in north-west Italy. Piemontese cattle carry a specific gene mutation inactivating myostatin and causing hypertrophic muscle growth, or double muscling. Animals are mainly kept in stables to produce large amounts of very lean meat. A very effective breeding scheme has drastically improved ease of calving.
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer
Description Of Specific Uses: Only the meat of this breed can be used to produce "Vitelloni Piemontesi della coscia" PGI (protected geographical indication)
Efabis genetic features: A G to A transition in exon 3 of myostatin gene resulting in a cysteine to tyrosine substitution in the mature region of the protein (amino acid 313) is responsible for muscular hypertrophy, also known as 'double muscle' phenotype; currently, this trait interests almost all animals registered into Herdbook.
Color comments: uni coloured: uni blue, light brownish grey to white with black tail, eyelashes, muzzle, ears and hooves
Other specific visible traits: the bull has grey or light fawn coat with dark hairs at head (especially around eyes), neck, shoulder and distal regions of the legs; the head is square with medium sized horns, directed forward and to the side ; the neck is short and muscular , with well-developed dewlap ; The trunk is cylindrical , often saddled ; limbs are long ; the horns are black up to 20 months of age ; in adults they are yellowish at the basis and black at the apex; the calf has dark fawn coat.
Description of origin: The current breed is the result of a selective process occurred in Northern-Western Italy involving alpine cattle Piedmont populations characterized by red or fawn coat which were crossed with Grey autochthonous populations (Cristin, 1861-1862; Mascheroni 1929). The presence in Piedmont of T3 haplogroup common to Aurochs justifies the inclusion of this breed and the other Grey cattle breeds in Bos primigenius taurus subspecies (Hiendleder et al., 2008; Matassino e Ciani, 2009).
Location within country: District of Piedmont with particular reference to provinces of Asti, Cuneo and Torino.

Description: Pinzgauer is a dual purpose, transboundary breed from the Tyrol region, spanning across Italy and Austria. In recent years, until recently, the breed was extensively crossed with the Red Holstein to improve its milk production. Its coat shows chestnut-brown sides and white back and underside. The breed is characterized by great hardiness, longevity, fertility and adaptability to grazing at high altitudes.
Provision Uses: Herding, Meat, Milk, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: No
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to the local environment (mountains, pastures, woods).
Color comments: multi coloured: red, brown white, white stripes on back and belly

Description: Podolica is an autochthonous breed of cattle living in Southern Italy since prehistoric times. Formerly used for field work, it spread over mainland Italy and as far as Istria, now in Slovenia and Croatia. Also known as "Pugliese" from the South-Eastern region of Puglia, it is an example of successful biological adaptation to poor, hot and arid environments. Podolica breed originated from the Bos Taurus Primigenius, an ancient ancestor of all podolic-derived cattle. It shows a considerable variability in size and color, ranging from white to dark gray. Females are kept on range, they are docile and of excellent maternal attitude. A large proportion of them are mated to bulls of beef breed in order to produce calves with a sufficient beef conformation. Some podolica cows are also milked and the milk is transformed in the traditional "caciocavallo" cheese.
Provision Uses: General crossbreeding, Herding, Meat, Milk, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Fire protection, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Cultural Uses: Cultural and religious ceremonies, Tourist attraction / touristic potential
Description Of Specific Uses: No
Efabis cultural role comment: The power draught of Podolian cattle (currently Autochthonous Italian Grey Cattle) is still used in special events that evoke ancient traditions, uses and customs of the human population of Southern Italy. A particularly evocative feast, involving Podolian cattle (currently Autochthonous Italian Grey Cattle) for transport of logs is the festival celebrated in May in Accettura (Matera) and dedicated to the patron Saint Julian. This festival, culminating with the symbolic marriage between a "May" (tree trunk) and a 'holly,' is an old rite of fertility and good for a plentiful harvest.
Adaptability to specific environment: The animals are adapted to the local conditions (arid hills, Mediterranean scrub).
Special characteristic of product: 'caciocavallo podolico' cheese
Efabis environmental role: Thanks to semi-pastoral or semi-extensive farming system, Podolian cattle (currently Autochthonous Italian Grey Cattle) gives a high contribution to the landscape with particular reference to that of hills and mountains of Southern of Italy.
Efabis adaptability to marginal land: Podolian cattle (currently Autochthonous Italian Grey Cattle) has a great 'construptivism capacity (adaptiveness) in 'difficult' environments (arid hill - mediterranean scrub).
Color comments: uni coloured: medium grey comment: calves are born red
Other specific visible traits: grey coloured , with a tendency to dark grey-black in males, particularly on the sides of the head, ears, neck, shoulder, on 2 / 3 of the chest, abdomen, leg and lower part of leg, with shades progressively lighter from the upper third of the trunk to the line-lumbar spine; in females the colour tends to be lighter until white; the muzzle is black and surrounded by clear halon; skin: is dark pigmented, fine, elastic and abundant so it forms a dewlap hanging from the chin to the sternal region, falling beyond knee height in the best bulls; also the buccal mucosa and natural openings are black pigmented; in some female lines the natural openings may be depigmented; horns: are macrocer, positioned on the same axis of sinciput with circular or elliptical basal section, yellowish coloured on 2 / 3; the section becomes permanently circulate in its black coloured upper third; therefore, for two years, during growth and development, horns are entirely black and only in later years the clear part emerges; they are half-moon shaped in bull and lyre shaped in cow, directed laterally, then forward and up, with length of 45 - 50 cm in adult.
Description of origin: composite of local and old Podolian breeds. Podolian, a cattle domestic population of the subspecies Bos primigenius taurus, descends from Aurochs (Bos primigenius primigenius) that arrives to Italy during the Würm Last Glacial period (80,000÷40,000 years ago) and spreads throughout the Italian bio-territory where it remains until about 6,000 years ago; the first appearance of a cattle with big horns (resembling Aurochs) of incipient domestication, from which the current Podolian derives, can be traced back to this period.

Description: The origin of the breed is rather uncertain: some Authors consider it to derive from the Parmigiana breed, a now extinct variety of Reggiana. Other scholars trace its origin back to an Iberian population. Medium sized, red coated, for its excellent robustness and rusticity Pontremolese was used for field work. Notably, Pontremolese cattle was used to transport marble from Carrara caves to the port. It is a relic breed and a preservation program is ongoing.
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: No

Description: Pustertaler Sprinzen, or Barà, breed originated in Pusteria Valley in Alto Adige/South Tyrol by crossing an alpine, red coated breed of Celtic origin, with a gray breed. In XIX Century the morphological and productive characters of the breed were already well fixed. Currently in Italy, 90% of the population is bred in Piemonte (north-west Italy) and 10 % in South Tyrol. Due to its excellent rusticity qualities, it grazes on mountain pastures during summer, while in winter it is housed in the valley barns. It is a dual purpose breed with a prevalence for milk used for typical cheeses like Toma.
Provision Uses: Herding, Meat, Milk, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: No
Efabis cultural role comment: South Tyrol - Pustertal
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to the local environment (mountains, poor pastures).
Color comments: multi coloured: black, red, white, with red or black pied sides

Description: The name of the breed come from the province of Origine: Reggio Emilia in northern Italy. Originally a triple purpose breed (milk, work and meat) it is now reared to produce high quality milk for Parmigiano Reggiano PDO cheese. The breed shows an exceptionally high frequency of K-casein β, favorable for the production of Parmigiano Reggiano PDO cheese. A special brand of Parmigiano Reggiano is made exclusively by milk of this breed.
Provision Uses: Meat, Milk, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer
Description Of Specific Uses: Only the milk by this breed can be used to produce Parmigiano Reggiano cheese PDO (Protected Denomination of Origine) of the type "da Vacche rosse"
Efabis cultural role comment: for Parmiggiano Reggiano Production
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is known for its adaptation to the local marginal conditions.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Reproductive qualities are reported for this breed.
Other special qualities: This breed has productive qualities.
Color comments: uni coloured: red, brown, yellow with light muzzle

Description: Rendena is a dual purpose breed from the Alpine Rendena Valley, in the Trentino region. Small sized animals, well fitted to mountain pastures, because of their efficiency they are also kept in the provinces of Padova and Vicenza on flat land farms. Rendena cattle are strongly tied to the territory: before WWII the breed was outlawed and breeders preserved it by hiding the bulls. The milk is used in the area of ​​origin for cheese making.
Provision Uses: Meat, Milk, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: No
Color comments: uni coloured: dark chestnut-brown, pale muzzle and dorsal stripe
Location within country: Province of Trento, Vicenza and Padov

Description: Romagnola is an autochthonous beef breed from the Emilia-Romagna region in northern Italy. Very rustic, it belongs to the Podolic group of grey cattle. It is generally kept on range for the production of calves. The meat from this breed is a Protected Geographical Indication (PGI) certified as "Vitellone Bianco dell'Appennino Centrale" in a specific area of origin.
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Fire protection, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: This breed is one of the three breeds used to produce "Vitellone bianco dell'Appennino Centrale" PGI (protected geographical indication)
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to the local environment (hills, pastures).
Color comments: uni coloured: light grey to white with pigmented skin, dark muzzle and horns comment: calves are born brown

Description: Sarda is a beef breed from the island of Sardinia (Western Italy). Small sized animals, well fitted to poor pastures thanks to its excellent rusticity and frugality, it lives in the most unfavorable areas. The population present in Sardinia assume different denominations according to the coat color and the stature. Changes in economic conditions and specialization of modern dairy breeds marginalized this breed: today the residual use of the Sarda breed is the production of meat, anyhow of of excellent quality.
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Fire protection, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: No
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is well adapted to the local environment (mountain areas with arid soils).
Color comments: uni coloured: yellow multi coloured: pied, brindle

Description: Sardo Bruna is a dual purpose breed from the island of Sardinia (Western Italy). Originated by crosses between Sarda cows and Bruna bulls, it is currently confined to hilly and mountainous areas, where it usually represents a complementary activity to dairy sheep farming.
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Fire protection, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: No

Description: Sardo Modicana is a dual purpose breed from the island of Sardinia (Western Italy). Originated by crosses between Sarda cows and Modicana bulls, imported from Sicily at the end of the XIX Century in order to improve the Sarda aptitude to field work. Medium to large in size, the coat shows varying shades of fromentine from light red (especially in females) to dark vinous (mainly in males). The breed guarantees a moderate production of milk mainly used for home cheesemaking.
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: No
Adaptability to specific environment: The animals are adapted to the local conditions (arid soils).
Color comments: uni coloured: yellow-brown to dark red

Description: Valdostana Pezzata Nera is a dual purpose cattle breed from Valle d'Aosta region in the Alps, at the border with France. The complete name of the breed is "Valdostana Pezzata nera - Castana", meaning Valdostana Black Pied - Cestnut, because the coat color is highly variable from solid cestnut to blac-pied, with all intermediate combinations, including solid black. Animals with more than 12,5 % of "Castana" type are considered "Castana". A transboundary agreement exists that considers Valdostana Castana equivalent to the Swiss breed Hérens. Valdostana is mainly bred for milk, used to make the PDO cheese "Fontina". During summer, herds are taken to mountain pastures and leading cows from different herds fight to establish hierarchy. After a while, each pasture has its own "reine" (queen). At the end of summer the reines are taken together at a huge event were they fight in a sort of championship. The event is safe for the animal, it is very traditional and it attracts a lot of spectators. The winner is the yearly regional reine.
Provision Uses: Herding, Meat, Milk, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Cultural Uses: Fighting, Cultural and religious ceremonies, Tourist attraction / touristic potential
Description Of Specific Uses: Only the milk by "Valdostana" breeds can be used to produce "Fontina" cheese PDO (Protected Denomination of Origine)
Additional information: Valdostana (both Black Pied and Red Pied) is one of the 11 breeds of the European Breed Federation of the Alpine System. The others are: Abondance (France), Grigio Alpina (Italy), Herens (Swiss), Hinterwälder (Germany), Pinzgauer (Austria), Rendena (Italy), Tarentaise (France), Tiroler Grauvieh (Austria), Vordelwälder (Germany), Vosgienne (France). Both Valdostana Pezzata Nera and Valdostana Pezzata Rossa are registered in the Breed Society "ANABORAVA", founded in 1980.
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is known for its adaptation to the local marginal conditions (mountains).
Special characteristic of product: On range conditions, Valdostana cows fight to establish hierarchical social structures. This attitude is exploited in traditional shows and competitions known as 'The queens fights' . The PDO cheese 'Fontina' can only be made by milk from the two breeds 'Valdostana Pezzata Nera' and 'Valdostana Pezzata Rossa'
Color comments: multi coloured: black, white
Other specific visible traits: It is similar as Pezzata Rossa, but it has a more harmonious conformation. The coat is black pied; the legs and ventral region are white; the head is black with white spots on the forehead.
Description of origin: local breed, derived from Illyrian Celtic
Location within country: Aosta Valley, in North-West Italy, at the border with France and Switzerland.
Additional performance parameters: MIlk production: on average, 2,846 kg per lactation with 3.43% of fat and 3.38% of protein.

Description: Valdostana Pezzata Rossa is a dual purpose cattle breed from Valle d'Aosta region in the Alps, at the border with France. The breed is mainly bred for milk, used to make the PDO cheese "Fontina". Other local cheeses are Fromadzo DOP, Reblec, Seràs, Salignon and Toma di Gressoney. During summer, herds are taken to mountain pastures.
Provision Uses: Herding, Meat, Milk, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: Only the milk by "Valdostana" breeds can be used to produce "Fontina" cheese PDO (Protected Denomination of Origine)
Additional information: Valdostana (both Black Pied and Red Pied) is one of the 11 breeds of the European Breed Federation of the Alpine System. The others are: Abondance (France), Grigio Alpina (Italy), Herens (Swiss), Hinterwälder (Germany), Pinzgauer (Austria), Rendena (Italy), Tarentaise (France), Tiroler Grauvieh (Austria), Vordelwälder (Germany), Vosgienne (France). Both Valdostana Pezzata Nera and Valdostana Pezzata Rossa are registered in the Breed Society "ANABORAVA", founded in 1980.
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is known for its adaptation to the local marginal conditions (mountains).
Special characteristic of product: The PDO cheese 'Fontina' can only be made by milk from the two breeds 'Valdostana Pezzata Nera' and 'Valdostana Pezzata Rossa'
Color comments: multi coloured: red, white with white head, light muzzle
Description of origin: It probably derives from piebald cattle originating from Northern Europe introduced in Italy by the Burgundians.
Location within country: Aosta Valley, in North-West Italy, at the border with France and Switzerland.

Description: Varzese-Ottonese-Tortonese is an ancient breed of dual purpose cattle from the Italian mountain area in North-West Italy among the regions of Lombardy, Emilia Romagna, Piemonte and Liguria. Rustic and long-lived (15-20 year old cows and oxen were not rare). The Varzese breed is capable to exploit meager pastures.
Provision Uses: Herding, Meat, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Land degradation and erosion prevention, Pollination and seed dispersal, Vegetation management, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: No

Description: Animals must be black , females are acceptible with white markings on the udder and on the underline towards the navel. White markings on the scrotum is permissible in the male. Animals must be broad, deep, blocky , and polled.
Additional information: Breed development controlled by the Jamaica Black Cattle Breeders Society. The Society operates an open Herd Book policy where approved females are entered. Approved males are entered in an Approved Register and enjoy the same status. Visual appraisal to ensure conformatiy to breed standards are conducted annually.
Description of origin: composite of Aberdeen Angus and Brahman
Management conditions performance measur: Range managed herds
Comments management conditions: Average daily gain and carcass characteristics measured under feedlot conditions. Other performance data obtained under extensive grazing conditions.
Additional performance parameters: Av. 210-day weight ; males 175 kg, females 156 kg: Av. 400-day weight; males - 375 kg : Conception rate , avg. 87%

Description of origin: composite of Ongole, Hissar and Mysore Zebu
composite of Jersey (80%), Zebu (15%) and Friesian (5%)
composite of Red Poll, Devon and Zebu

Color comments: multi coloured: black with brownish hair tips
Description of origin: Developed through crossbreeding Japanese indigenous breed cattlle with exotic breeds.

Location within country: Kumamoto Prefecture, Kyushu and Kochi Prefectures, Shikohu

composite of Japanese Native and European breeds

Description: mountain
Special characteristic of product: sufficiently high milk yield. Meat characteristics of the Alatau breed are quite satisfactory.
Other specific visible traits: The body building of animals is good.
Description of origin: This cattle was bred by crossing the Shvits breed with the Kirgiz cattle.

Adaptability to specific environment: The most valuable features of the breed are its adaptability to the ecological conditions experienced in the breeding zone, high vitality and strong constitution.
Special characteristic of product: The Aulieatin cattle meat quality is satisfactory.
Color comments: uni coloured: usually black with white markings on underside, sometimes grey
Other specific visible traits: The head is light, lean, with a prolonged facial part; the neck is thin, covered with small skin folds. The back and the small of the back are flat, straight, of medium width; the sacrum is a bit elevated. The skeleton is thin ( the metacarpus girth is 17.5-18.5 cm). The udder is of a medium size, with relatively uniformly developed segments. The skin is dense, elastic. The exterior defects include the narrow and roof-like croup, the irregular building of extremities.
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 5 months per year and fed on grazing, fodder and concentrates.

Adaptability to specific environment: they use efficiently the coarse and juicy fodder, are well-adapted to severe conditions of the North Kazakhstan.
Color comments: uni coloured: greyish of various tints
Other specific visible traits: The animals of a new breed are characterized by the clearly defined meat type of their body building.
Description of origin: The selection program included the raising and intra-breeding of three-breed hybrids of Sharolez, Aberdin-Angus bulls and white-headed breed cows. The third generation hybrids were intra-bred.

Specific resistance or tolerance: Young animals have a high growth rate: even with moderate feeding.
Description of origin: This cattle was bred in Kazakhstan from the animals, imported from the Baltic countries and the European part of Russia, and also on the basis of the absorbing and reproducing crossing of aboriginal breed animals.
Location within country: spread in the rural areas of almost all regions of the Republic.
Additional performance parameters: The animals have the high potential of milk productivity and are very exacting to the feeding level and fodder quality.

Adaptability to specific environment: good adaptation to breeding in the mountains.

Description Of Specific Uses: good meat productivity.
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is highly adapted to grazing on poor vegetation and surviving harsh changes of the weather. The body temperature of these animals is fairly stable under harsh winter conditions or very hot sunny conditions.
Special characteristic of product: Their meat is juicy.
Other special qualities: The animals are known for their high viability.
Color comments: multi coloured: red of different shades, sometimes with a white head and a stripe along the upper part of their body, the animals often have white spots on the lower part of their body
Horn shape size and comments: the horns are not long and are in the same plane with the forehead.
Other specific visible traits: strong constitution, the body building in the most of animals is good, their muscles are well-developed, the chest is deep and wide. The head is small and the forehead is short. The facial part of their head is prolonged, with the humpy nose profile. They are medium-sized animals ( the wither height in cows is 126 cm), with compact body building ( the slanting body length is 150-155 cm). The withers, the back and the small of the back are usually flat and wide. The sacrum is a bit elevated sometimes. The legs are strong, built correctly. The muscles are well-developed. The udder is small. During the winter season the skin is covered with thick hair.
Description of origin: Taurino-Mongolian type from Asian Bos primigenius, composite of Simmental, Shorthorn and local cattle
Location within country: north of Caspian Sea, Rostov Region and Lower Volga
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 6-7 months per year and fed on grazinig, fodder and concentrates.
Comments management conditions: This breed is known for its ability to graze on poor vegetation like Sagebush pasture.

Adaptability to specific environment: The animals can tolerate both extremes of hot and cold climate. Well-adapted to the use of natural pastures.
Special characteristic of product: good meat quality and precocity.
Color comments: uni coloured: red often with white on head, belly and feet
Other specific visible traits: small cattle, deep and wide chest, with the compact body building, with strong light skeleton; the body is round and wide, with well-developed muscles. By winter the animals are getting overgrown with long thick hair.
Description of origin: composite of Kazakh and Hereford. It has been raised by crossing the domestic Kazakh and partially Kalmyk cattle with Hereford breed animals.
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 6-7 months per year and fed on grazing, fodder and concentrates.

Description Of Specific Uses: Though some animals and herds have the traits of the milk-and-meat cattle, most of red steppe breed cows are of the milk type and are characterized by the following exterior features.
Color comments: multi coloured: red, varying from light-red to dark-red, many cows have white spots- mainly on the lower part of their body, the bulls' front and upper parts of the body are usually of a more dark colour
Other specific visible traits: The animals are of medium height, with a bit deep and prolonged body. The head is not big, light, a bit prolonged. The chest is deep and of medium width. The back and the small of the back are wide and long enough, the sacrum is a bit elevated. The skeleton is light. The udder is well-developed, of a round shape. The skin is thin, elastic, with small folds on the neck.
Description of origin: red Ostfrisland cattle X grey Ukrainian breed

Adaptability to specific environment: These animals are well-adapted to the hot climate and efficiently using the rough stalked vegetation near ponds.
Specific resistance or tolerance: esistant to blood-parasite diseases.

Adaptability to specific environment: well-adapted to grazing on natural pastures of arid steppe and semi-desert zones. Young animals inherited from the aboriginal cattle the ability to quick fattening on natural pastures.
Special characteristic of product: high milk yield, combined with high meat quality.
Description of origin: imported from the breeding farms of Russia and Ukraine, and later from Austria, Switzerland and Germany; The Simental cattle was bred in Kazakhstan in 1932-1959 by crossing Kazakh, Kalmyk and red steppe breeds with Simental bulls.
Location within country: The main range of this breed includes Pavlodar, East-Kazakhstan and Ural regions.

Description: This zebu type is closely associated with the Pokot community in Kenya and Karamoja in Uganda. Coat colour is highly varied ranging from brown/red to darkish brown.It is the hardest of all zebu types in east Africa. The animals are able to walk through rough, stony and rocky terrains under high ambient temperature for a long distance while in search of water and pastures.
Provision Uses: Draught power, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides, Transport

Description: The name Boran is for the community where the Breed was developed in Kenya.
Description Of Specific Uses: Meat is destined for local markets and export.
Color comments: A range of coat colours reported for Kenyan Boran cattle breed include: black, light red, red, white, brown, roan and cream.
Comments management conditions: This breed is often kept on ranches and usually has an adequate water supply. Cattle are fed on total grazing. Dressing percentage (%) reported here is mean of 6 males at the age of 5 years Data on birth weight was collected under on station management condition Daily gain (avg., g) in this report refers to male animals from birth to 45.5 months old
Additional performance parameters: Parturition percentage (%): Min. 75.3, Avg. 83.57, Max. 88.40; Weaning weight - mean for both sexes (kg): Min. 129.5, Avg. 153, Max. 177 Yearling weight - mean for both sexes (kg): Min. 162, Avg. 186, Max. 211

Comments management conditions: The breed endures inadequate grazing and water supply.
Additional performance parameters: Performance data for this breed is very scant and what is available is not very reliable.

Description: Maasai Zebu is predominantly found in southern Kenya extending to north-east Tanzania with close association with the Maasai community. Comparatively, it is the largest of all SEAZ types in Kenya.
Provision Uses: Draught power, General crossbreeding, Meat, Milk, Saving security, Skin/hides, Transport

Description: The type is small in size and fine-boned. It’s the dairy type of the SEAZ comparatively producing more milk than other zebu types. The types has a thoracic hump varying in size and shape from round from front to back and hangs backwards in bulls. Moderately well-developed udders but will small closely placed teats.

Description: Alatau breed bred in 1950 on the basis of the absorption cross-breeding of local cattle bulls Kyrgyz Schwyz, Yaroslavl breeds. Breed of combined meat and dairy production. Alatau common species in Kyrgyzstan, Kazakhstan, and was taken out in Mongolia. Animals brown suit.

Additional information: Data before independence refer to Former USSR. Planned pedigree breeding and milk recording started at the beginning of the century but the herd-book began in the 20's. There is also a catalogue of bulls. Selection is focused on high productivity, a strong body and good udder shape. The number of cows has decreased considerably and is still doing so (although the rate of decrease has slowed down) due to the agricultural reform. The data for 1994 has been obtained from pedigree work and milk recording summaries. In 2003, this breed account for 74% of the total cow population.

Description: This breed is part of the brown branch, a large branch including in particular the brown of the Alps, the Tarentaise, the Gascon or the Mirandaise. It could be more precisely related to the Gascon. Within this brown branch, it is often attached to the fawn branch, and not to the alpine branch. She would then be the descendant of a breed that came from North Africa and arrived in Spain then in the southwest of France with the migration of the Arabs in the 7th century, just like the Parthenese which strongly resembles it, as well as the races nearby (Nantes and maraîchine). This would also explain its resemblance to various Spanish breeds.
Color comments: the aubrac breed wears a tawny coat . The skin is black, which is visible at the nostrils and around the eyes. The neck of the bulls is darker, like the ends (ears, bottom of the legs and tail). The horns are white at the black end. The hooves are black and hard
Horn shape size and comments: The horns directed obliquely and slightly forward then raised and turned over in a twist, they are black at the top, the base having to be as white as possible
Other specific visible traits: the aubrac breed wears a tawny coat . The skin is black, which is visible at the nostrils and around the eyes. The neck of the bulls is darker, like the ends (ears, bottom of the legs and tail). The horns are white at the black end. The hooves are black and hard. It is a medium format cow . Females have on average chest circumference of 190 cm for a chest depth of 70 cm. The basin is 53 cm wide
Description of origin: This breed is part of the brown branch, a large branch including in particular the brown of the Alps, the Tarentaise, the Gascon or the Mirandaise. It could be more precisely related to the Gascon. Within this brown branch, it is often attached to the fawn branch, and not to the alpine branch. She would then be the descendant of a breed that came from North Africa and arrived in Spain then in the southwest of France with the migration of the Arabs in the 7th century, just like the Parthenese which strongly resembles it, as well as the races nearby (Nantes and maraîchine). This would also explain its resemblance to various Spanish breeds.
Location within country: breed used in crossbreeding in favorable stock areas

Horn shape size and comments: horns well set, medium size, starting horizontally to run upwards and then forwards, light in colour with dark tips
Other specific visible traits: Rather long head , broad and convex forehead, wide ears directed towards the back furnished with long hairs , very slightly convex muzzle, rather broad muzzle, nostrils of pink colour .
Location within country: originated in Plateau of Zaer North-east of Rabat, in particular the hills of D'Oulmes and the neighbouring areas of Khenifra, Meknes, Sale and Khouribga, now in North-western Morocco

name used for Red Steppe in Moldova 1918-45 when it was part of Romania

Totally from the beginning of creation the Black lemming type of Moldavian zone, about 4.0 mln of cows and heifers were inseminated by sperm of black lemming and Goldstein bulls. As a result, the contribution of different breeds in milk production has changed.

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is well adapted to the dry conditions of south and central Moldova.
Description of origin: This breed has been created in the south of Moldova by crossing local Grey Steppe cows with Red Steppe bulls imported from Ukraine. Currently the number of animals is reduced as a result of crossing with Black and White and Holstein breeds.

This breed was created by crossing local Grey Steppe cows and Simmental bulls for several generations, starting at the end of 19th century. Since 1963 this breed was further crossed with Jersey and since 1970 with Black and White and Holstein breeds with the objective of creating the Moldavian Black and White type

Special characteristic of product: Good milk fat content (3.9 - 4.1%) is reported for this breed.
