Description: The name of the Angus breed derives from its place of origin in the Shire, Aberdeen and Angus counties of Scotland
Provision Uses: Meat, Pelt or fur, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Sire line, Skin/hides
Description Of Specific Uses: For consumption, the fur (leather) is used for the manufacture of clothing and footwear
Production environment/management system: Extensive management system in grazing, intensive in feedlots
Adaptability to specific environment: Angus cattle do well on rangelands with temperate to cold climates.
Specific resistance or tolerance: It is resistant to pigmentation problems, eye cancer, infectious keratitis and legs necrosis.
Specific reproductive characteristic: EARLY: Females reach puberty at 13 months. FERTILITY: ease of cows to produce one calf per year; Stallions' libido is recognized at the field level. CALVING EASE: The low birth weight of her offspring facilitates childbirth. MATERNAL ABILITY: They take care of and protect their young, they provide enough milk for the young to arrive at weaning with good weight.
Special characteristic of product: The quality of the meat is recognized for its colour, juiciness, texture, softness and flavor.
Color comments: Black Angus: Animals with a black colour ; black with spots behind foreskin; brownish black with pigmentation of the fur and mucous membranes. Red red with colour noses; red and white coat behind foreskin; yellowish coat with pink pigmentation.
Other specific visible traits: The Angus breed is of moderate size, with medium fine fur , elastic, covered with a soft, short thick coat. FEMALES: Head: Straight or slightly concave profile, rounded forehead, size rounded ears. Neck: Long, fine and with a soft insert on the head. Forelimbs: Medium and well poised. Hips: Wide and with good opening of the sitting bones (birth carcass ). Hindquarters: Medium with strong bone, plumb and separated. Udder: medium size , shaped and implanted, with well developed, symmetrical quarters and fine size -sized nipples. MALES: Head: Strong snout, wide and rounded jaws with small ears. Neck: Wide and with greater superior prominence. Forelimbs: Medium and well poised. Hip: Solid and flat at the quadrille level. Hind limbs and buttocks: They are wide, deep, muscled, and long. The legs: They are medium, with strong bone, well poised and separated. Testicles: Descended, of good circumference and without excess scrotal fat.
Description of origin: The Angus breed was introduced to Mexico from the United States, in 1904, by Captain William Benton, a British subject who settled in the State of Chihuahua.
Location within country: La raza Angus se encuentra distribuida principalmente en los Estados de Aguascalientes, Baja California Norte, Chihuahua, Coahuila, Colima, Chiapas, Durango, Guanajuato, Jalisco, Puebla, Querétearo, San Luis Potosí, Sonora, Tabasco, Tamaulipas y Zacatecas
Management system: Extensive (non back yard), Intensive, Semi Intensive
Management conditions performance measur: fundamentally in grazing, in which depending on the climatic situation and pasture production, they are supported with cut grass, silo and other types of forage and minerals
Additional performance parameters: Angus females reach puberty at 13 months and may be giving birth at 18 years* they have high fertility and can produce one calf per year* rapid growth, when the calves are weaned between 6 and 8 months they often weigh 280 Kg and reach 400 Kg in their first year of life

Description Of Specific Uses: For consumption, the fur (leather) is used for the manufacture of clothing and footwear

Provision Uses: Meat, Pelt or fur, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Skin/hides
Description Of Specific Uses: For consumption, the fur (leather) is used for the manufacture of clothing and footwear

Adaptability to specific environment: One of the qualities of this breed is its adaptation to the environment, mountains, hot and cold climates, humid and desert.
Specific resistance or tolerance: It is a breed very resistant to all vectors (sancudos, mosquitoes, horseflies) due to its influence of the Brahman breed (50%)
Specific reproductive characteristic: One of the qualities of the Beefmaster breed is its fertility, as it was one of the six essential characteristics for which this breed was created.
Other special qualities: Breed created based on its six essential characteristics for which it was created: Weight, meekness, fertility, rusticity, conformation and maternal ability
Color comments: The colour is variable, there is no specific colour , currently the breeders by selection are looking for a red coat .
Other specific visible traits: Females should be expressive with a long neck , smooth shoulders, straight dorsal line, breadth and leg length, correct udder implantation. In the male based on the racial pattern of the breed, the male should appear male with enough masculine expression, bulky neck , leather in his tie, soft and muscular arms, as well as his arm and forearm. Strong dorsal line and width in his thorax and functional ventral line.
Description of origin: It originated in Texas, United States of America in 1933, based on Brahman (50%), Hereford (25%) and Shorthorn (25%) blood . In 1966 the first animals arrived in Muzquiz, Coahuila, Mexico. As of 1972, this breed was dispersed to other states of the Mexican Republic. Most of the animals distributed were of pure breed.
Import: In 1966, 32 cows and two bulls were imported from Texas, the United States of America, which was the founding lot. Starting in 1972, frequent imports were made from the country of origin, in order to improve the characteristics of the breed.
Location within country: The Beefmaster breed is distributed in 27 states of the Mexican Republic with different altitude, temperature and type of soil.
Management conditions performance measur: Intensive stable management
Additional performance parameters: Weaning weight 250Kg finding animals up to 320 Kg. Weight per year between 440 to 520 kg

Description: Initially this cattle was designated as "Brahmin" and then a Latin suffix was added to the word, which was called for a time "Brahmin". But JW Sartwelle, who was the first director of the Brahman Cattle Breeders Organization of the United States, was the one who officially adopted the word Brahman, around 1924, to designate this new breed .
Provision Uses: Meat, Pelt or fur, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Sire line, Skin/hides
Description Of Specific Uses: For consumption, the fur (leather) is used for the manufacture of clothing and footwear
Adaptability to specific environment: The most distinctive feature of Zebu cattle and therefore Brahman is their ability to adapt to adverse tropical conditions. Part of this adaptation is due to the presence of sweat glands that allow it the ability to adapt to high rates of temperature and humidity.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Tolerant to high temperatures, humid climates, rusticity, ability to take advantage of forages of low nutritional quality and resistance to internal and external parasites, which allows them a greater adaptation to the severe conditions of the tropical environment.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Ability to reproduce at high rates of temperature and humidity; as well as ease in childbirth and maternal ability.
Special characteristic of product: Brahman is conceptualized for its meat production in terms of rapid growth , muscular development, quality and yield of the carcass, early completion and ideal conformation of muscle masses.
Color comments: Two groups of colors are classified: Brahman Gray or White and Brahman Red . The white colour in the black, gray and red hair coat stands out in fur different shades. The front and rear thirds are generally darker in males. In females the coat is lighter; gray with red, gray or white spots, which do not occupy more than a third of the body, individually or accumulated. In red fur, white spots in shaded areas not associated with the rest of the body.
Horn shape size and comments: They have symmetrical colour horns . It is accepted dehorning in males and females. The natural absence of horns (mochos) is allowed. Moving or colour white are disqualified.
Other specific visible traits: The strict selection resulted in the Mexican Brahman, racially showing uniformity in its phenotype, highlighting its development, size, conformation, skeleton and good temperament, good poise in its forelimbs and hindquarters, long and strong bones, firm and dark hooves, as for genitalia; in the male sheath, navel and foreskin collected, testicles and scrotal bag of good size and conformation, with soft and fine fur . In the female, a well udder with small teats covered by fine fur , a line back lumbar line well covered by wide and long muscles, a broad and deep thorax, a little protruding sacrum, a long and wide hips. As well as long, prominent buttocks and muscles. His fur is dark, good pigmentation in mucous membranes.
Description of origin: Originally from the United States, this breed originated from an initial nucleus of 266 bulls and 22 cows of different types of zebu imported to North America between 1849 and 1926. The first importation of Brahman cattle from the United States to Mexico was in 1932, specifically They arrived in the State of Tamaulipas.
Location within country: The Brahman cattle breeders are distributed in the States of Aguascalientes, Campeche, Colima, Coahuila, Chiapas, Chihuahua, State of Mexico, Guerrero, Jalisco, Michoacán, Morelos, Nayarit, Nuevo León, Oaxaca, Puebla, Quintana Roo, San Luis Potosí, Sinaloa, Tabasco, Tamaulipas, Veracruz, Yucatán and Zacatecas. However, specimens of this breed are found in all the states of the Mexican Republic
Management conditions performance measur: Grazing with supplementation

Description: The name of the Charbray breed derives from the combination of the names of the two breeds that give it origin, which are Charolais and Brahman.
Provision Uses: General crossbreeding, Guard, Meat, Pelt or fur, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Skin/hides
Description Of Specific Uses: For consumption, the fur (leather) is used for the manufacture of clothing and footwear
Production environment/management system: Extensive management system in grazing, intensive in feedlots
Color comments: The Charbray red is a white to soft colour breed .
Description of origin: Charbray cattle are a synthetic breed (5/8 Charolais - 3/8 Zebu). It is considered that this breed had its origin in Mexico from the 1940s, although its formal recognition did not occur until the 1990s.
Location within country: It is located mainly in desert, semi-desert, subtropical and tropical areas of Mexico, with a greater presence in the states of Sonora, Chihuahua, Tabasco, Nuevo León, Tamaulipas and Veracruz, where 87% of the registered population is concentrated.

Description: The name of the Charolais breed derives from its place of origin and historical cradle in the Counties of Charolles in the Burgundy Region of the country of France.
Provision Uses: Meat, Pelt or fur, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Sire line
Description Of Specific Uses: For consumption, the fur (leather) is used for the manufacture of clothing and footwear
Production environment/management system: Extensive management system in grazing, intensive in feedlots
Color comments: The hair colour of the patent leather breed is distinctive, being colour , also accepting white cream or slightly straw, as well as some colour cream or straw white or vice versa. The tail should be white, cream or straw.
Horn shape size and comments: The horns appear in both females and males , white or yellowish of medium length. Animals of the genetics line mochas or melons can also be presented, as well as false horns.
Description of origin: The Charolais breed was introduced to Mexico from the country of France in 1930 by Mr. Pugibet, a Mexican industrialist, of French origin.
Import: In 1930, 10 heifers and 2 males were imported from France, in 1931 a second importation from France of 12 heifers and 6 bulls was made and a third importation was carried out in 1937 from the same country bringing 7 pregnant heifers loaded into France. These imported animals were fully identified.
Management conditions performance measur: Stabled and fattened animals (grain -rich rations) animals at 12 months of average age for a period of 150 days
Comments management conditions: The vast majority of patent leather breeders manage their bellies by grazing induced rainfed or irrigated meadows, with mineral supplementation throughout the year and a smaller percentage supplementing pre -weaning offspring. Most post -weaning animals are supplemented with protein and minerals plus grazing.

Description: The great Indian breed of the Kankrej territory in Gujarat, Bombay province in India, takes its name from this region, in the first Brazilian imports that speak of Gujarat or Guyerate.
Provision Uses: Meat, Milk, Pelt or fur, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Sire line, Skin/hides
Description Of Specific Uses: For consumption, the fur (leather) is used for the manufacture of clothing and footwear
Adaptability to specific environment: The most distinctive feature of Zebu cattle, and therefore Guzerat, is their ability to adapt to harsh tropical conditions. Part of this adaptation is due to the presence of sweat glands
Specific resistance or tolerance: Tolerant to high temperatures, humid climates, rusticity, ability to take advantage of forages of low nutritional quality and resistance to internal and external parasites, which allows them a greater adaptation to the severe conditions of the tropical environment
Specific reproductive characteristic: Ability to reproduce at high rates of temperature and humidity; as well as ease of delivery and maternal ability
Other special qualities: Hardiness
Color comments: The coat of hair on black fur is colour gray to dark gray. Anterior and posterior thirds generally with more intensity of colour, sometimes reaching black. In females the coat is lighter, it can be white . Calves at birth mostly have a reddish or yellowish colour on the top of the head , which disappears at an older age .
Horn shape size and comments: The horns are long, thick and symmetrical with a circular or elliptical section at the base, going horizontally outwards when leaving the skull, curving upwards in the shape of a lyre (due to its similarity to the musical instrument) with the tips turned inwards and backwards. The base of these is covered with fur and hairs to a higher point than the rest of the zebu.
Other specific visible traits: The animals of this breed show in both sexes a majestic appearance and great presence when walking, because they carry their head erect, with bulky and striking horns. In short, their appearance denotes physical strength. The head is moderately wide and short in the male, and longer and narrower in the female; with a sub -concavilline profile, straight face and wide black pigmented nose; large black eyes with a meek expression; wide, elongated and oblique ears; its short neck is relatively thick, the body well developed, with a deeper and longer thorax; hump of good size and shape: the limbs of medium length , strong bones. The fur is colour . Males with size pendulous foreskin.
Description of origin: Of Brazilian origin. The first documented importation from Brazil to Tampico, Tamaulipas, Mexico was in 1923; 16 bulls identified as Guzerat arrived, destined for: One to Tantoyuca, Veracruz; two to Pánuco, Veracruz; nine bulls, including Rabbit ABBA 1020, Guzerat bull , born in 1920 in India and bought by Manuel E. Guzmán; one to the JA de Abreu farm for use with Jersey cows by Dr. Eloy Gómez de Altamira, Tamaulipas; and Pontal, a Guzerat bull who was the Grand Champion of Brazil, bought by Gonzalo N. Santos for the Gargaleote Farm in Tamuín, SLP. A Guzerat bull was gifted to Manuel Guzmán Willis for his services to the Brazilians. In the importation of Morais to Mazatlán, Sinaloa, in 1924, 18 Guzerat females came, the only ones imported. Thirteen managed to breed in Texas, including the most important breeding cow , Hattie Cleo 11, named Old Bob after her owner, because of her short tail . Without an exact date established, it was reported that in 1925 [a source says it was in the 1930s] a ship wrecked off Tampico in a strong storm, although others indicate that it was near Veracruz. The surviving animals were confiscated by the federal government, and at least one bull was raffled between the governors of the entities. It was Jalisco's turn, and although he passed from one rancher to another, he spent most of his life with Salomón de Anda. The bull was Abanico, and he had been the great champion in Rio de Janeiro, before leaving Brazil
Import: In subsequent imports from Brazil, they were carried out in 1945 where Guzerat animals arrived, destined for Tempoal, Veracruz and Altamira, Tamaulipas. And in 1946 four Guzerat were imported, sent to Manuel Station, Tamaulipas. The first permit for the free importation of cattle was granted by the federal government in 1932 for 11 Guzerat females from the JD Hudgins farm, it was given to Daniel Breen for the Santa Juana, Tamaulipas farm. From this date until after 1942, most animals entering the United States were identified as Guzerat. During this period, out of a total of 158 imported animals, 40 bulls and 22 females were identified as being of the Guzerat breed .
Location within country: The Register Cattle breeders are distributed in the States of Campeche, Chiapas, Michoacán, Nuevo León, Sinaloa, Tabasco, Tamaulipas, Veracruz and Yucatán.
Management conditions performance measur: Grazing with supplementation

Description: Its name derives from its place of origin. The land of the Gyr cattle is the Kathiawar, as the name implies it is probably from the Gir forest in the south of the Kathiawar peninsula in the state of Saurasthra, India.
Provision Uses: Dam line, Meat, Milk, Pelt or fur, Skin/hides
Description Of Specific Uses: For consumption, the fur (leather) is used for the manufacture of clothing and footwear
Adaptability to specific environment: The most distinctive feature of the Zebu cattle, and thus the Gyr, is their ability to adapt to harsh tropical conditions. Part of this adaptation is due to the presence of sweat glands that allow the ability to reproduce at high rates of temperature and humidity.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Tolerant to high temperatures, humid climates, rusticity, ability to take advantage of forages of low nutritional quality and resistance to internal and external parasites, which allows them a greater adaptation to the severe conditions of the tropical environment
Specific reproductive characteristic: Ability to reproduce at high rates of temperature and humidity; as well as ease in childbirth and maternal ability
Special characteristic of product: Hardiness
Reference for special qualities: Feed efficiency in residual feed consumption tests. CAR
Color comments: Black fur , pink on the udder and inguinal region. The coat colour of hair, a varied and exclusive feature with combinations for this zebu; uniform red in all its shades up to; the white coat , red sardinian and the red coat , sardinian red both in different proportions and distribution on the body make a wide range of classifications such as: choker red , sardinian red , red sardinian, light red (red mulberry); when the predominance is colour the white and the total head are partially reddish. Another variant of combinations is the light Moor, predominantly colour with totally or partially white ears and head , and the dark Moor, predominantly colour , with black head and ears. Coat of copper-yellow, muddy, gray, black and all- white hair are not allowed.
Horn shape size and comments: The horns are another unique feature of this breed; colour in color, symmetrical, flattened, thick at the base, with an exit direction downwards and backwards without impairing the movement of the ears; those that are directed upwards and curved inwards are of greater distinction. In the mocha variety , there is a total absence of horns, it is possible the presence of vestiges of horns, which are known as button, callus or stump; those that must be colour , without bony bases, adhered only through the fur.
Other specific visible traits: The most obvious and distinctive characteristics are in the conformation of its head, it has a profile with a wide and ultra convex forehead (it has prominent curvature). The position of the eyes is lateral, protected by abundant wrinkles of fur on the eyelids. The ears are medium and hanging, start in the shape of a tube, at the upper edge they roll on themselves, opening immediately and gradually, to end shape curving at the tip with a turn towards the face, a feature known as “ hawk ”, unique distinctive of this cebuino. Black fur , pink on the udder and inguinal region. They are medium -sized specimens.
Description of origin: Mexican Gyr cattle are of Brazilian strain . Few specimens arrived in Mexico and the United States in the 1940s and began to mix with the existing zebu . Due to their great rusticity, they become very popular from the semi -desert plains of Texas, in the United States, and in Mexico in the states of Coahuila. Nuevo León, Tamaulipas, to the more humid tropics of Tabasco and Chiapas, passing through Veracruz to Campeche and Yucatán, in addition to its diffusion on the Pacific coasts.
Location within country: Los criadores de Ganado de Registro se encuentra distribuidos en los Estados de Aguascalientes, Campeche, Chiapas, Jalisco, Puebla, Guerrero, San Luis Potosí, Edo de México, Nayarit, Michoacán, Sinaloa, Tabasco, Zacatecas, Tamaulipas, Veracruz y Yucatán.
Management conditions performance measur: Grazing with supplementation
Additional performance parameters: Weaning weight 160 Kilograms Weight per year 246

Provision Uses: Meat, Pelt or fur, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Sire line, Skin/hides
Description Of Specific Uses: For consumption, the fur (leather) is used for the manufacture of clothing and footwear
Adaptability to specific environment: The great quality is their great adaptability to different climates, however, in dry tropics and humid tropics, pure animals do not express their productive characteristics to the maximum, since their coat is long and they tend to accumulate fat between their muscle fibers. which causes problems with heat tolerance in hot and humid areas. However, if they are born in the zone or young calves arrive, they can adapt without problem. It is a temperate zone breed . The breed is very hardy and adaptable, since although it originates from a cold and humid zone like Great Britain, it has thrived with great success in much harsher climates. The breed has adapted to a very wide range of climates on almost every continent. They have good movement capacity on stony and sloping terrain; Its type of diet is varied, showing good behaviour to produce grass -fed meat . Currently, there are different herds in areas from the semi -humid tropics to the temperate zone . Hereford crossbred animals are very well behaviour.
Specific resistance or tolerance: They have a great capacity to adapt to diets high in fiber or the by -products of agriculture and the breed and their crosses have the unique ability to hibernate, sustaining their meat to weight faster than any other in the pasture. Having survived intense competition from numerous continental breeds, it is recognition of the Herefords' ability to produce quality meat economically. This versatile breed is the leader in feedlot adaptability with noteworthy international influence. They have the ability to turn grass into quality meat and winter well. Its outstanding characteristics: Adaptability, Fertility, Docility, Hybrid vigor vigor and heterosis , Quality meat , Versatility, Efficiency, Yield, Longevity, Feed conversion, Carcass yield , Carcass, Marketing, Availability, Profitability. A disadvantage of the breed is with animals not pigmented in their ocular mucosa, predisposing them to eye cancer. However, the use of genetically pigmented animals within the breed has allowed them to be more tolerant or resistant to this deficiency.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Fertility, puberty, precocious, high percentage of calf harvest.
Special characteristic of product: Outstanding characteristics are: Longevity, growth, carcass characteristics. Higher weight for age and rate of increase, whether in pasture or feedlot cattle. The ability to set maximum prices in the markets such as finished meat . A higher sale price for breeding stock. Greater profit economy in feedlot and grass -fed meat . Lower maintenance costs. Docility and ease of use. Lower labor costs, thanks to its easy -going temperament. Early maturity and longevity.
Other special qualities: One of the most salient advantages is the impact it has on your resulting crosses. Currently on the market there are many breeds, the result of two or more crosses. The Hereford is part of the origin of many of these, which have had excellent acceptance in the environment, some examples of these crosses are: the Beefmaster cattle composed of the Shorthorn, Zebu and Hereford, the Braford cattle that is the cross of Brahman with Hereford (In its different percentages), this cross has given very good results in humid and hot areas, and also has a great adaptability and production in arid and temperate climates. The Angus crossbreeding with Hereford is one of the most popular in the United States, both for breeding and for fattening.
Reference for special qualities: Periocular Pigmentation (PPO) has an estimated heritability of 0.4 according to Woodward and Knapp; Anderson's later work had similar results from 0.4 to 0.46. This would be a medium heritability , similar to that estimated for birth weight . On the other hand, PPO has a positive correlation with pigmentation of the sclerocorneal limbus (PLEC) (KM Davis 2013), which is important to avoid injuries that originate specifically in the eyeball and has the advantage that it is already expressed at birth, unlike the pigmentation of the LEC, which is modified by increasing in the life of the animal (Vogt et al)
Color comments: Its appearance combines white and a wide range of reds, ranging from bay to cherry. White spots on the head, back of the ears, on the chest, belly, lower limbs and on the tip of the tail are intrinsic characteristics of this breed. Their fur is short and on the forehead, they usually have curls. Around the eyelid it has a red pigmentation.
Horn shape size and comments: Most animals have short, thick horns that generally curve downward on the sides of the head, but there is a polled line (Polled Hereford).
Other specific visible traits: They have well -developed forequarters, a deep chest, a broad head with a large mouth, short ears with stocky legs, and a short forefoot. Relatively short neck , well muscled and powerful in males and thin and slender in females. Reduced dewlap , good insertion of the neck in the back. Not very prominent cross, rounded, full and covered towards the sides. Long and broad back, well muscled and well directed. Deep, long and arched chest, well muscled, insensibly joined with the back. Elongated flanks with marked flanks. The belly is deep, wide and well proportioned. The dorsal-lumbar horizontal line , broad, flat and muscular. Wide and well muscled loins. Horizontal, broad, square and muscular croup. Tail well set, long and with abundant terminal speck. Apparent muscular hindquarters, very muscular in the back and deep. In females, correct implantation of the vulva. Well -formed udders, of correct insertion and separation of quarters, with appreciable venous system, well developed and correctly implanted nipples. In males, testicles normally developed, well descended and of correct anatomical conformation. The animals are mountain type.
Herdbook established: En México, el libro genealógico se estableció en 1989 por parte de la Asociación Hereford Mexicana.
Description of origin: The first commercial breeder of record in the Southwest of the United States was the Rancho San Rafael of Scotsman Colín Cameron in Lochiel, Arizona, adjacent to Mexico, had in 1880, thousand head of pure cattle. Later this ranch passed into the hands of the Green Cattle Co., which in the sixties still operated in Sonora. Later in 1887, Captain J.B. Gillete from Marta, TX. , on his ranch in Big Bend Park, adjacent to the state of Chihuahua, he established a large breeding stock with border ranchers who followed his example. In the state of Chihuahua, registry Hereford stallions brought from Missouri in the year of 1900.
Import: In 1906, according to the historian Francisco Aldama, Don Abraham González Casavantes as agent of a cattle company in Indiana, USA, introduced a game of 100 heifers and 37 bulls of the Hereford breed that he placed among Chihuahuan farmers and from there spread throughout the Republic. Mexican.
Location within country: Chihuahua, Sonora, Coahuila, Nuevo León, Zacatecas, Baja California, Tamaulipas, Aguascalientes, Jalisco, Michoacán, Durango, Nayarit, San Luis Potosí y Guanajuato.
Management system: Back Yard or Farm Yard Production, Extensive (non back yard), Intensive, Semi Intensive
Management conditions performance measur: Fattening in corral
Comments management conditions: Admission process, vaccine, hormonal implants, deworming, vitaminization, feeding special diet to finish with grain, forage and minerals

Provision Uses: Dam line, Milk, Pelt or fur, Skin/hides, Surrogate milk provision for suckling
Description Of Specific Uses: For consumption, the fur (leather) is used for the manufacture of clothing and footwear
Production environment/management system: Intensive, semi-intensive and backyard management system
Comments management conditions: In medium and high input systems pure Holstein are used and in backyard and double purpose production systems, holstein* Zebu crossbreds are used.

Description: Its name derives from the place of origin, Uberaba zone , region of the state of Minas Gerais, Brazil
Provision Uses: Meat, Milk, Pelt or fur, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Skin/hides
Description Of Specific Uses: For consumption, the fur (leather) is used for the manufacture of clothing and footwear
Adaptability to specific environment: The most distinctive feature of zebu cattle and therefore Indubrasil is their ability to adapt to adverse tropical conditions. Part of this adaptation is due to the presence of sweat glands that allow it the ability to adapt to high rates of temperature and humidity.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Tolerant to high temperatures, humid climates, rusticity, ability to take advantage of forages of low nutritional quality and resistance to internal and external parasites, which allows them a greater adaptation to the severe conditions of the tropical environment
Specific reproductive characteristic: Ability to reproduce at high rates of temperature and humidity; as well as ease of delivery.
Special characteristic of product: Indubrasil has been characterized by its meat aptitude
Other special qualities: Hardiness
Color comments: The coat of hair on white fur is colour , ash and uniform red , the anterior and posterior thirds, as well as the extremities, may be dark. In white coats, the occasional spot that is not defined or loaded in colour, light red and ash, is permissible, as well as reddish ash and its shades.
Horn shape size and comments: They are symmetrical, of medium size , black in colour , from their emergence They are directed backwards, upwards, pointing immediately inwards, with tips in the shape of a rhombus and converging
Other specific visible traits: The profile of the head is long, wide and from sub-convex to convex; the forehead is broad, smooth and slightly prominent. The black, elliptical eyes, protected by wrinkles of the fur on the upper eyelids; their sleepy look is distinctive of this breed. It is the zebu with the longest ears, there are also size -sized ones. However, they always exceed the nose; They are thick, their base is tubed, pendular, with the inner face of the pavilion directed towards the front, with the upper edges that rotate on their own axis and the blunt tips are directed inwards, in a convergent direction. The large size identifies these specimens; The great body volume derives from the length, width and depth of the trunk, as well as the front and rear extremities of medium length with strong and thick bones, wide thighs and legs, with good muscular coverage.
Description of origin: Of Brazilian origin, at the beginning of the 20th century, the crosses of different breeds began in the Uberaba zone , the Mineiro Triangle region; starting with cows from the Mysore, Hizar, Mehwati, Sindi group, especially Ongole, in Brazil, called Nelore. Guzerat bulls were used by many breeders, and the offspring of this cross were crossed with Gyr, giving rise to the Indubrasil breed . In Mexico it began as a breed after imports from Brazil in 1945 and 1946. However, there are photographs of bulls imported to the United States in 1924, with a conformation similar to what was called Indu-Uberaba, later , Indubrasil.
Location within country: The Registry Cattle breeders are distributed in the States of Chiapas, Jalisco, Michoacán, Quintana Roo, Tabasco, Veracruz and Yucatán.
Management conditions performance measur: Grazing with supplementation

Description: The name derives from its geographical place of origin (Limoges Province, France)
Provision Uses: Meat, Pelt or fur, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Sire line, Skin/hides
Description Of Specific Uses: For consumption, the fur (leather) is used for the manufacture of clothing and footwear
Adaptability to specific environment: Adaptability to extreme climates of both low and high temperature, the latter in the presence of low relative humidity. Outstanding ability to travel long distances to feed and ingest water, in diverse topographic regions and varied food sources of reduced or high digestibility, as well as a wide range of nutrients.
Specific resistance or tolerance: None identified.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The Limousin breed has remarkable precocity and fertility, with a gestation rate between 75-95%. The average productive life of Limousin cows exceeds 12 years with an average number of 9 calvings, it is frequent the presence of productive units with 18 years of age in the production units. Ease of childbirth and maternal skills are notable characteristics.
Special characteristic of product: Specialized to achieve high carcass yield , greater than 65%, as well as a higher ratio of meat to bone and fat, which is reflected in the highest availability of edible proportions, especially due to the abundance of cuts of higher commercial value such as: hindquarters, back and loin (on average the eye area of the loin is 84.193 cm2). The meat is characterized by being lean, with an average backfat thickness of 0.674 and a marbling percentage of 0.787.
Other special qualities: Among the meat breeds, it stands out for its ability to convert the food consumed into kilograms of live weight in less time. Feed efficiency is a relevant indicator in terms of sustainability and profitability, it is then that the identification of specimens with the best relationship between the amount of feed required and the unit of product generated have been considered in the selection criteria of the breed. meat.
Reference for special qualities: Population with molecular markers for double muscle: homozygous non -carriers 99.74 %, heterozygous carriers 0.26 %and homozygous carriers 0.00 %.
Color comments: Specimens of colour red or dark red color, with lighter areas around the eyes, muzzle , crotch and belly.
Horn shape size and comments: The horns are generally larger in diameter and length in males than in females. They are white with colour areas in both sexes; of variable length , they are directed outward and forward in a horizontal plane. By genomics: 295 (genotyped population ) Horned homozygous 88.86 % Heterozygous polled 10.24 % They are Homozygous Horns 0.00 %
Other specific visible traits: Size head and broad head. Small ears with blunt tips. Natural presence or absence of horns, and most dehorned. Of medium size and outstanding: length, breadth and body depth. Abundance of muscular masses with balanced distribution on the back, back, loin, hips and legs. Skeletal structure with bodily harmony and evident functionality such as the width of the birth carcass , strength in the dorsal lumbar line ; as well as structural conformation with sexual dimorphism associated with hormonal balance and accentuated width of the snout (nose and mouth). Fine bone with both fore and aft extremities well poised, with strong and wide hooves , which allows to travel long distances efficiently in different topography.
Description of origin: Originally from the south -west of France in the former Province of Limoges. In 1970, the first genetic material (semen) of the Limousin breed of the Prince Pompadour Stallion arrived from Canada and the United States of America to Zacatecas, being the State that is considered the gateway of this cattle and where in 1971 it was They had the first half blood calves with Creole cows.
Import: At the end of the seventies, some female imports were made from Canada and the United States of America to the states of: Chihuahua, Zacatecas, Coahuila, Jalisco, Aguascalientes, Nuevo León, Tamaulipas and Guanajuato. In December 1988 a group of Zacatecan breeders led by Mr. Rubén López Pro, made a trip to the United States of America and Canada to import Limousin females and breed , arriving in Zacatecas on February 26, 1989. Since 1990, it began with the importation of proven genetic material from France, which has positioned the Mexican Limousin in the American continent as a benchmark for its racial qualities in strict adherence to the racial standard of the country of origin (France). The rigorous selection and genealogical certainty supported by parentality tests are the main commitments of each of the breeders, which has allowed advances with absolute certainty in maternal qualities, as well as those of muscular conformation, feeding efficiency and reproductive behaviour .
Location within country: In Mexico, it is present in 19 of the 32 States of the Republic, covering the various climatic types of the country: semi -desert, tropical, subtropical, temperate and mountain, under different production systems. With greater presence of specimens with genealogical records in: Jalisco, Guanajuato, Durango, Aguascalientes, Zacatecas, Sonora, Tamaulipas, Michoacán, Puebla and Querétaro.
Management system: Extensive (non back yard), Intensive, Semi Intensive
Management conditions performance measur: Behaviour tests, high performance diets in energy and protein
Comments management conditions: Intensive feeding system.
Additional performance parameters: Weaning weight 221.93 Kg Weight per year 341.39 Kg

Provision Uses: Meat, Pelt or fur, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Sire line, Skin/hides
Description Of Specific Uses: For consumption, the fur (leather) is used for the manufacture of clothing and footwear
Adaptability to specific environment: The most distinctive feature of the Zebu cattle and therefore the Nelore is their ability to adapt to adverse tropical conditions. Part of this adaptation is due to the presence of sweat glands that allow it the ability to reproduce at high rates of temperature and humidity, contrary to specialized European breeds.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Tolerant to high temperatures, humid climates, rusticity, ability to take advantage of forages of low nutritional quality and resistance to internal and external parasites, which allows them a greater adaptation to the severe conditions of the tropic environment.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Ability to reproduce at high rates of temperature and humidity; as well as ease in childbirth and maternal ability
Other special qualities: Hardiness
Color comments: With black fur , the coat of hair can be white, light gray or dark, with or without spots of the basic tones scattered throughout the various regions of the body. In the females, the tonalities are reddish in the forehead and dorsolumbar region. One or another stain not very charged in its colour, different from the ideal coats. In the anterior and posterior thirds it may present more intensity of colour, dark gray. Some calves are reddish at birth, a characteristic that disappears at an older age . Coats painted black and painted red are permissible.
Horn shape size and comments: The distinctive shape, direction and size of the horns are short, firm, colour in color, shape , thicker at the base, flattened and oval in section, rough, with longitudinal striations; they are born upwards accompanied by the profile, well implanted, similar to two sticks stuck in the skull. With growth they can be directed outwards, backwards, upwards, or curved backwards or to the sides. In females they are thinner and longer. In the mocha variety it is the total absence of horns, it is possible the presence of traces of horns, which are known as: button, callus or stump, which must be colour , without bony bases and attached only through the fur.
Other specific visible traits: The distinctive shape, direction and size of the horns are short, firm, colour in color, shape , thicker at the base, flattened and oval in section, rough, with longitudinal striations; they are born upwards accompanied by the profile, well implanted, similar to two sticks stuck in the skull. With growth they can be directed outwards, backwards, upwards, or curved backwards or to the sides. In females they are thinner and longer. In the mocha variety it is the total absence of horns, it is possible the presence of traces of horns, which are known as: button, callus or stump, which must be colour , without bony bases and attached only through the fur.
Description of origin: Of Brazilian origin. At the importation from Brazil, by Pedro Márquez Núñes and Octacilio Lemgruber in 1923 there was a Nelore bull that was bought by Samuel Melo and Ostos from Tantoyuca, Veracruz. Another bull in the same import was Satán, a Nelore, son of Tango and Candoca, born on May 29, 1919 and 2nd place in the Rio de Janeiro show in 1922 or 1923, which was bought by Tomás Garrido Canabal for his farm in Frontera, Tabasco. It is assumed that the other animals that arrived in Yucatán and Tabasco before 1930 were of the Nelore conformation. In 1927, seven animals were lowered from a boat in Tampico. Musquetero, a Nelore bull , was bought by Don Ventura Calderón from Altamira, Tamaulipas, but this bull did not have a lasting influence on the national livestock. It is believed that the other six animals were also Nelore and were bought by the Melo and Ostos. Tupa 53/16, a Nelore bull imported from 1945, was bought by Malcolm Niven from Micos, San Luis Potosí. The latter is the first imported bull that left offspring documented in the books of the Mexican Association of Zebu Breeders.
Import: Nelore Brasil bulls were imported in 1946, of which it has not been possible to identify them by name, as were the bulls used by the Pasquel brothers from San Luis Potosí. After the 1980s, animals were imported from the United States and semen was imported in 1997.
Location within country: The Register Cattle breeders are distributed in the States of Campeche, Chiapas, Michoacán, Nuevo León, Quintana Roo, Sinaloa, Tabasco, Tamaulipas, Veracruz and Yucatán.
Management conditions performance measur: Grazing with supplementation
Additional performance parameters: Weaning weight 173 kilograms Yearly weight 261 kilograms

Description: The name refers to its coat of intermixed colour and white hairs , commonly called Sardo fur, which when combined with the black colour is called Black Sardo.
Provision Uses: Meat, Milk, Pelt or fur, Sire line, Skin/hides
Description Of Specific Uses: For consumption, the fur (leather) is used for the manufacture of clothing and footwear
Adaptability to specific environment: The most distinctive feature is its ability to adapt to harsh tropical conditions. Part of this adaptation is due to the presence of sweat glands.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Tolerant to high temperatures, humid climates, rusticity, ability to take advantage of forages of low nutritional quality and resistance to internal and external parasites, which allows them a greater adaptation to the severe conditions of the tropical environment
Specific reproductive characteristic: Ability to reproduce at high rates of temperature and humidity; as well as ease of delivery and maternal ability
Special characteristic of product: Sardo Black cattle adapt to the demands of this globalized market. They are good producers of meat and milk, excellent in their nutritional conversion, rusticity, fertility, earliness, great maternal ability and outstanding versatility to be used in crosses with other European breeds, such as American Swiss and Holstein, they have capable females to give good milk production
Other special qualities: Sardo Black females show marked meekness, maternal ability, adequate hip inclination and amplitude of the same, for greater ease of calving, which together favors the survival of calves. The udder with strong ligaments, of medium volume with good irrigation and conformation; totally or partially pigmented; with symmetrical, small to medium nipples, well distributed and black in colour
Reference for special qualities: Feed efficiency in residual feed consumption tests. CAR
Color comments: The coat of hair is: In Light Black Sardinian, the coat of white colour with spots and/or black fringing predominates. In Dark Black Sardinian, the black coat predominates with white spots and/or white crinkles; In Sardo Black the coat of coat is of equal proportion of black and white colour with spots and/or fringed of black or white, with totally or partially black ears, head and legs . Occasionally some brown spots
Horn shape size and comments: Symmetrical, cylindrical, of colour color, thickness and medium length , directed backwards, outwards and upwards. In the Mocha variety , absence of horns.
Other specific visible traits: They are animals of great stature, robust constitution, strong skeleton and musculature, active and docile temperament, medium size head with sub -convex profile. Long, strong and well poised limbs, broad chest, very good thoracic capacity, with arched and deep ribs, broad flanks, kidney -shaped hump implanted at the top of the withers, long and broad back and loin, as well as on the hip with sacrum. little protrusion, good muscular masses in the upper body, regular foreskin, sheath and navel, good and uniform testicles and scrotal bag, in the female well udder covered by fine fur as well as the teats and good size.
Description of origin: The Black Sardo breed is the youngest Zebu breed in the world and Mexico is its birthplace. In the center of the State of Veracruz on the Gulf of Mexico Coast. We can affirm that the antecedents of this breed are a crossbreeding between the zebu cattle existing in some regions of the Gulf coast and these specimens with such characteristic fur that they were identified in their respective records as agryrado-indubrasil, a Moorish coat colour . Both the light moor and the dark moor correspond to the Gyr and Deoni races.
Location within country: Registered Cattle breeders are distributed in the States of Campeche, Chiapas, Colima, Jalisco, Puebla, Oaxaca, Guerrero, Edo de Mexico, Nayarit, Nuevo Leon, Michoacán, Tabasco, Tamaulipas, Veracruz and Yucatán.
Management conditions performance measur: Grazing with supplementation
Additional performance parameters: Weaning weight 188 kilograms Weight per year 286

Color comments: The Simbrah breed has different colorations in its coat ranging from light to dark bay, with indefinite spots. Uniform solid colour are acceptable, except all white or all black
Import: The first imports of pure Simbrah animals came from the United States in 1983 to the state of Tabasco.
Location within country: It is found throughout most of the country, both in desert and tropical areas. The greatest presence of animals in breed purity is found in the states of Tabasco, Nuevo León, Sonora, Tamaulipas, Sinaloa, Chiapas, Campeche, Yucatan and Jalisco, where 85% of the population of pure animals is found.
Additional performance parameters: Weaning is practiced at 205 days with weights of 225 kilograms

Description: The name of the Simmental breed derives from its place of origin Simme Valley in Berner Oberland, Switzerland
Provision Uses: Dam line, Meat, Milk, Pelt or fur, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Skin/hides
Description Of Specific Uses: For consumption, the fur (leather) is used for the manufacture of clothing and footwear
Adaptability to specific environment: Adapted to diverse environmental conditions, both in hot and dry climates and in temperate and cold climates. Developing best at altitudes above 300 meters and with low humidity.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Females reach puberty at an early age , present their first heat at 10 to 12 months of age, their first parturition between 24 to 30 months. Their parturition interval ranges from 12 to 13 months during their productive life. The longevity in the producing herd reaches up to more than 10 calvings. The average calving percentage is 84%, with an average birth weight of 37 kg. Males are fertile from 12 months of age, with a scrotal circumference of 30 cm in diameter and their productive longevity greater than 10 years.
Special characteristic of product: It is a breed by function and type belongs to the Dual Purpose group (meat and milk)
Color comments: The Simmental breed has different colorations in its coat ranging from light yellow to dark yellow, as well as light red to dark red , as basic colors. In addition to the white colour that could go in greater or lesser quantity; the majority of the body may be of a basic colour with white spots. It stands out that its head is colour in different proportions , as well as its legs
Horn shape size and comments: They are light in colour or streaked, with an average length of 35 cm, curved to the sides. Genetics line animals can also be presented polled that are accepted for registration, as well as with false horns.
Description of origin: The Simmental arrived in Mexico in 1973 with the importation of 10 bulls from Germany and Switzerland, carried out by the then Secretariat of Agriculture and Hydraulic Resources (SARH), which spread throughout the eastern country through its network of semen banks. genetic material.
Import: In 1984, a cow was imported from the United States and in 1985, 2 purebred females were brought in, 1 stallion from Switzerland. Subsequently, the number of these animals was increased by importing from Germany, France and England.
Location within country: This breed is spread throughout much of the country, mainly found in the states of Nuevo León, Sonora, Jalisco, Zacatecas, Chiapas and Guanajuato where 83% of the inventory of this pure breed .
Additional performance parameters: Weights at weaning (205 days) males 235 Kg and females 323 Kg *Weights per year males 355 Kg and females 323 Kg

Adaptability to specific environment: This breed is confined to the high and colder mountains of the North-east of Myanmar and lower tracts of the Himalaya.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Mythum mate in the forest but rarely in captivity.
Color comments: multi coloured: dark slate in colour with white stockings below the knees comment: calves are born dark red in colour which turns into the characteristic colour by 6 months of age, they have a dorsal ridge on the crest of the shoulder
Other specific visible traits: short tail, big dewlap, flat forehead
Location within country: Chin State, North-western hilly part of Myanmar bordering Manipur State in India
Comments management conditions: In Myanmar the breed is semi-domesticated and retains certain wild instincts. The animals are reared in the forests, browsing on shrubs, bushes and leaves. The animals return to the owner if he provides regular feeding of a small amount of salt.

Other special qualities: Animals of this breed are docile and intelligent animals.
Other specific visible traits: males have a very prominent hump and sloping rump and a tall and deep chest
Description of origin: It is believed that Pya Zein derived from white Indian Zebus most likely Hariana or Ongole which have been imported at the beginning of the 20th century. The breed has been selected further.
exotic; imported during the colonial period and Post Independence period

Color comments: uni coloured: reddish brown, fawn

Efabis environmental role: Important role in protection of biodiversity and enviromental.

Other specific visible traits: Busha breed is usually single colored with different level of pigmentation. There are black, red, dark or light brown and different light colors to the total white colored heads. Horns are thin and bended to forward in the form of wreath, but sometimes in the form of pitchfork.
Location within country: Busha reared mainly in mountain, less developed villages that are far away from the urban centers.
Performance data reference: B. Marković , M. Marković1 and N. Adzić (2007): The farm animal genetic resources of Montenegro, ADZIC, N., LJUMOVIC, M, Markovic, M., Markovic Bozidarka (1997): Autochthnous breeds of livestock in Montenegro and their importance. LJUMOVIC, M., (1964): Prilog poznavanju nasljednih i ambijentalnih varijacija – tipova goveda Polimlja (disertacija). Titograd. Management conditions performance measur: Management conditions are usually very extensive. Animals are on the pastures, sometimes very pure pastures, without additional feeding. Housing period is very short, two to three mounts.

Description of origin: locally adapted breed; imported from South Africa; With the restocking program, after the peace agreement, some Nguni cattle were reintroduced into the country, coming from South Africa, and nowadays they are completely spread out and crossed with the indigenous breed.

Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed has a high level of tick tolerance.
Specific reproductive characteristic: This breed is reported to be fertile and the females are known for calving ease.
Color comments: multi coloured: coloursided
Other specific visible traits: Sanga type
Description of origin: The Nguni breed is a Sanga cattle breed related to the following breeds and varieties: Swazi in Swaziland: Landim in Mozambique: Bapedi in Transvaal: Bavenda (Sibasa) in Nord Transvaal: Venda and Ciskei Nkone in Ciskei and Shangaan in Gazankulu.
Comments management conditions: In Mozambique the Landim/Nguni cattle are reared under two production systems: a) Pastoral range-livestock, transhumant, fed on extensive grazing in an agro-pastoral farming system within the semi-arid ecological zone, kept to produce traction, milk, meat and for security and social reasons; b) Pastoral range-livestock, stationary, fed on extensive grazing in a pastoral farming system within the semi-arid ecological zone, main product is meat. (Sonia Maciel: questionnaire for the project identification missions of AnGR, August, 1994)

Description of origin: indigenous breed The origin of this breed is somewhat confusing, with some authors stating that these cattle might have originated from the Mashona breed in Zimbabwe, whereas others propose that it might be a product of crosses between the Angoni and the Landim cattle, prevalent in the neighboring areas of Tete (province) lowlands.
Location within country: Concentrated in the lowland areas of Tete province, province, conretely spread throughout the 10 southern part, in the arid and semi-arid lowland areas of the province.

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to the arid zone.

Import: 2014 - 57 females from South Africa; 2015 - 83 heifers from S Africa; 2019 - about 70 from S Africa

Description: Off white with pink muzzle. Previously animals of this breed were reported as having brown or ash areas on the white coat.
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer
Additional information: The animals are reported to show resistance to local pests and diseases. Resistance to heat stress is also reported for this breed.
Adaptability to specific environment: Resistance to heat stress is reported for this breed.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The animals are reported to show resistance to local pests and diseases.
Color comments: Off white with pink muzzle. Previously animals of this breed were reported as having brown or ash areas on the white coat.
Description of origin: The origin of this breed remains a mystery and up to now nobody has been able to trace back with certainty from where these cattle The origin of this breed remains a mystery and up to now nobody has been able to trace back with certainty from where these cattle originate. What everybody seems to agree upon is that this breed has its origin in North Europe and most probably came through France if not from France.
Location within country: Curepipe Livestock Research Station, Stevenson Street, Les Casernes, Curepipe
Performance data reference: Characterization of the Creole Cattle in Mauritius in Proceedings of the Meeting of Agricultural Scientists (2005)- In press
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 12 months per year and fed on a ""cut and carry"" system and supplemented with concentrates.
Comments management conditions: The fodder available consists mainly of sugarcane tops for about six months from July to December while for the rest of the year it consists mainly of mixed fodder like elephant grass (Pennissetum purpureum), herbe d’argent(Ischaemum aristatum), herbe collier (Coix lacrhyma jobi) etc. On top of the basal diet of fodder the animals receive a concentrate supplement (14-15 % Crude protein) at the rate of 2kg for maintenance purposes and 0.5 kg/litre of milk produced.

These breeds are mostly kept by private companies. On these farms, weaners are imported and fattened until they reach slaughter weight. They are fed mostly on a molasses/bagasse/dry straw based feed, the raw materials being by-products of the local sugar industry. Animals are kept in an open yard system. The animals are sold directly to butchers and/or to private individuals.

Description: Australian Milking Zebu means dairy cattle developed in Australia and having Zebu inheritance (mainly Jersey x Sahiwal/Red Sindhi)
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Regulation and control of animal/human diseases, Water quality and flows regulation/purification, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: Predominantly used for dairy production. Meat is a byproduct.
Additional information: Australian Milking Zebu were imported into Malaysia from Australia for experimental purposes to determine their suitability as a dairy breed for the Malaysian environment. The performance of AMZ was not encouraging and hence the best breeding stock were integrated into the Sahiwal-Friesian breeding program while the poor milkers were culled.
Additional information comments: There are currently no Australian Milking Zebu cattle herds in Malaysia.
Adaptability to specific environment: Adapted to hot tropical environment
Specific resistance or tolerance: Heat tolerance; Tick resistance;
Specific reproductive characteristic: Reasonable fertility.
Special characteristic of product: Good quality milk with high milk fat (4.5%).
Other special qualities: Good temperament.
Reference for special qualities: Hayman R.H. (1974). The development of the Australian Milking Zebu. World Animal Review 11:31-35.
Color comments: Coat in all shades of brown from light tan to almost black, and can have white markings: underside is lighter in color, while hips, head and shoulder tend to be darker;
Other specific visible traits: Slightly dished face, dark eyes and a light band around the muzzle; deep in body and full and deep in the barrel; well-developed udder and well-placed teats; - Very docile animal though can have a nervous disposition
Description of origin: A composite breed using foundation stock Jersey, Sahiwal and Sindhi; originates from Australia.
Import: import since 1978 from Australian Milking Zebu from Australia. Herdbook maintained in Australia by CSIRO (Commonwealth Scientific & Industrial Research Organization) Australia.
Location within country: Peninsula Malaysia - AMZ research program discontinued.
Performance data reference: Sivasupramaniam, G., Clark R.H. and Keling N. (1981). An interim report on milk yield and calving interval of imported Friesian, Jersey and Australian Milking Zebu cattle in Majuternak farms. Proc. 5th. Ann. Conf. Malay. Soc. Anim. Prod., pp. 105-117. Genting Highlands, Malaysia. Sivarajasingam S. and Wan Zahari M. (1985). Breeds of dairy animals and their performance in Malaysia. Livestock Technology (Teknologi Ternakan), Vol. 1 No. 2.
Management conditions performance measur: Under government livestock farm conditions
Comments management conditions: Semi-intensive feeding using forage and concentrates (mainly oil palm based).
Additional performance parameters: Quite well adapted to Malaysia but dairy performance inferior to Friesian-based cattle.

Description: Similar to the Bali cattle on the island of Bali in Indonesia
Other name: Balinese, Lembu Bali, Bos banteng, Banteng
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Regulation and control of animal/human diseases, Vegetation management, Waste recycling of non-human edible feed, Water quality and flows regulation/purification, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: The meat is reputed to be lean and very tender.
Additional information: A conservation herd is located at the National Veterinary Institute in Kluang, state of Johore. Performance data for animals at the conservation herd captured using the DairyChamp software.
Additional information comments: Felda Farm Products Corporation maintains a herd of about 1,000 head of Bali cattle.
Adaptability to specific environment: They are extremely hardy under the hot and humid equatorial conditions in Malaysia. They can cope well with poor pasture or fodder.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The animals of this breed are reported to show a high degree of disease resistance.
Specific reproductive characteristic: This breed is very fertile, possibly due to the long heat period.
Special characteristic of product: Niche market for Bali cattle meat. Meat promoted as special cattle meat.
Other special qualities: In male animals, the fawn coat turns black with maturity. Able to convert low quality feeds.
Color comments: reddish-brown with characteristic white stockings and a whitish rump patch; males turn black with maturity
Horn shape size and comments: thick, tapered horns, curving upwards and outwards
Other specific visible traits: zebu, medium-sized breed well developed body, strong legs beef-type
Location within country: Bali cattle are found in small pockets in several parts of Malaysia.
Management conditions performance measur: Semi-intensive system
Comments management conditions: Grazing and supplementation with other forages and a little concentrate.
Additional performance parameters: Meat:Bone ratio approximately 5:1, Rib-eye area approximately 75 cm sq.

Other name: Banteng Sondaicus Schlegel and Müller, Banteng Babteng Wagner

Description of origin: Synthetic beef breed (Kedah-Kelantan x Brahman) was developed by the Malaysian Agricultural Research and Development Institute.

Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Regulation and control of animal/human diseases
Adaptability to specific environment: The animals are reported to have a high tolerance to bad climate and tough tropical conditions (wet and hot). They can live on high lands with a slope of 50 to 60 degrees and at altitudes of 1 500 m asl.
Special characteristic of product: These animals produce good, tasty meat and leather of good quality.
Other special qualities: The Burmese Gaur is the third largest animal after the rhino and elephant. It feeds mainly on natural grasses and leaves from trees.
Other specific visible traits: very big animals
Description of origin: The Gaur is the largest of the Asiatic bovids. Two subspecies are recognised, B. g.gaurus (India, Nepal) and B. g. laosiensis (Myanmar, Thailand, Laos, Vietnam, Cambodia and West Malaysia).
Comments management conditions: The animals move in small groups over a large area and so they cause little damage to agriculture and forestry.

Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Regulation and control of animal/human diseases
Description of origin: Synthetic breed developed at the Malaysian Agricultural Research and Development Institute for use in producing feedlot cattle (terminal crosses).

Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Regulation and control of animal/human diseases
Regulation and control of animal/human diseases
Location within country: Gemas Livestock Breeding Center in Gemas, Johore.

Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Regulation and control of animal/human diseases
Color comments: multi coloured: various colours, usually red and speckled white/red
Other specific visible traits: large heads, bulging foreheads, narrow face, long pendulous ears
Description of origin: imported from Brazil; originating from the Indian sub-continent: used for the Mafriwal Breed Development Project

Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Regulation and control of animal/human diseases
Additional information: Individual cows need to be better housed and fed as compared to indigenous cattle breeds.
Additional information comments: Currently, some entrepreneurs are farming Holstein Friesian cattle under environmentally-controlled housing.
Adaptability to specific environment: This breed needs high-input, shaded environment.
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed exhibits less tolerance to tropical diseases and needs to be better managed and fed as compared to indigenous breeds.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Heat stress can depress reproductive performance. Hence heat stress needs to be reduced using better housing.
Special characteristic of product: High milk yield.
Other specific visible traits: taurus, large breed, milk-type, black & white coloration
Description of origin: Imported mainly from Australia, New Zealand, United States of America (semen) and Canada (Semen).
Import: Since 1970's, live Friesian cattle from Australia. Since 1970's, frozen Holstein semen from Canada. Since 1990's, frozen Holstein semen from the United States.
Location within country: Mainly in states of Melaka, Kedah and Perak.
Performance data reference: Cameons J.K. (1979). Holsteins and holstein crosses. Malayan Agricultural Journal 51:204-216. Sivarajasingam S., Yusof S., Ngah M., Sivasubramaniam G., Abas M. O. and Eusof J. (1982). Proc. 6th Annual Conference of the Malaysian Society of Animal Production, 10-11th August 1982, Genting Highlands, Malaysia.
Management conditions performance measur: Medium input production system.
Comments management conditions: Ambient temperature ranged from 24 to 34 degrees C. Relative humidity about 80-85%. Animals grazed on pasture. Concentrate feeding before milking under sheds. Good SPS management.
Additional performance parameters: Nil.

Provision Uses: General crossbreeding, Meat, Pelt or fur, Saving security, Sire line, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Regulation and control of animal/human diseases, Vegetation management, Waste recycling of non-human edible feed, Water quality and flows regulation/purification, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: indigigenous beef breed and resemble high tolerance of tropical climate and disease
Adaptability to specific environment: This breed is very well adapted to the Malaysian environment.

Specific reproductive characteristic: The breed shows a high fertility.

Description of origin: indigenous breed cattle. Descended from Thai.
