Description: Nondescript composite of breeds derived from the Indian continent
Provision Uses: General crossbreeding, Meat, Milk, Pelt or fur, Saving security, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Regulation and control of animal/human diseases, Vegetation management, Waste recycling of non-human edible feed
Description Of Specific Uses: Mainly use for fresh milk production. Meat is from males and spent females.
Additional information: The population of pure Local Indian Dairy is decreasing due to its very poor milk production compared to Dairy Crossbred cattle.
Additional information comments: Most of the Local Indian Dairy population has been crossbred with temperate breeds using artificial insemination.
Adaptability to specific environment: Very adaptable to the Malaysian (hot-humid) climate and can live on poor quality forages.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The animals of this breed are reported to show a high degree of resistance against tick borne and parasitic diseases.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The breed is reasonably fertile and has good mothering abilities.
Special characteristic of product: Very high milk fat (4.5 - 4.8%).
Other special qualities: Animals have poor temperament and poor dairy character.
Reference for special qualities: Rajagobal K.M. (1969). A comparative study of the performance of temperate crossbred and the Local Indian Dairy - type cattle. Kajian Veterinaire, Malaysia-Singapore, 2 (2), 76-82.
Color comments: uni coloured or multi coloured: white, grey, brown or a mixture of these
Horn shape size and comments: Animals have horns with pointed tips, usually curved outwards and upwards
Other specific visible traits: Zebu with large hump, well developed dewlap, black skin, large horizontally directed ears and rounded back.
Description of origin: The LID breed is of mixed ancestry. Indian migrants brought Hallikar, Ongole and Kankrej from South India during the early part of the 20th century. The random intercrossing of these breeds has resulted in the LID breed.
Import: Mixture of zebu breeds imported from Southern India since 1880.
Location within country: LID cattle are found mainly in the western part of Peninsula Malaysia.
Performance data reference: FAO Breed Survey Sivarajasingam S., Mukherjee T.K. (1975) Heritability estimates of milk yield and birth weight in tropical dairy cattle breeds in Malaysia. Trop. Agric. (Trinidad) 52: 223-228. Sivarajasingam S., Mukherjee T.K., Djafar I. (1974) The genetic performance of Local Indian Dairy cattle and its crossbreds. SABRAO J. 6: 39-45.
Management conditions performance measur: LID cattle are normally grazed in tree crop plantations during the day. At night they are mostly kept in stalls. They are milked twice, once in the morning and once in the evening.
Comments management conditions: LID cattle are normally grazed in tree crop plantations. They are stall-fed at night. Feed supplementation is minimal.
Additional performance parameters: Average Services Per Conception (on AI) = 2.1

Description: Synthetic dairy-beef breed derived from superior Holstein and Zebu inheritance
Other name: Malaysian Friesian Sahiwal, Malaysian Friesian Sahiwal
Provision Uses: General crossbreeding, Meat, Milk, Sire line
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Regulation and control of animal/human diseases, Vegetation management, Waste recycling of non-human edible feed, Water quality and flows regulation/purification, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: Bred for economic production. Diet composed largely of local feedstuff.
Adaptability to specific environment: The population is bred for its adaptability to hot and humid environment and tropical based feed stuffs.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Mafriwal are raised on government farms under strictest disease control.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The reproductive performance is 20% higher than 75% Holstein cross-breds but 5% less than the F1 crosses.
Special characteristic of product: The breed has been created for economic milk and beef production in the tropics.
Other special qualities: The breed is adapted to be milked by machine.
Color comments: comments: most animals are black or black and white.
Description of origin: Mafriwal are a composite of 62.5% Holstein (North America) and 37.5% Zebu. The Zebu component is mainly composed of improved Kenyan Sahiwal or Brazilian Gir. The Minister of Agriculture of Malaysia declared Mafriwal a breed on 30 August 1997.
Location within country: Mafriwal cattle are located in three Departments of Veterinary Service Farms in the state of Johore. These government farms are the Institute Haiwan, Air Hitam and Padang Hijau.
Management system: Back Yard or Farm Yard Production, Intensive, Semi Intensive
Performance data reference: CHEAH P.F. and KUMAR R.A. (1984). Preliminary observations on the performance of Sahiwal x Bos taurus dairy cattle. Malaysian Veterinary Journal 16(1): 1-7.
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were obtained from animals kept under semi-intensive conditions. The animals have been grazing and received additional concentrate feeding (approx. 3 kg/day).
Comments management conditions: The cows are grazing 18-20 hours per day on pasture and brought in for milking in the early morning and late afternoon. Fodder and concentrate are given only during milking.
Additional performance parameters: Good adaptability to tropical environment.

Other name: Borneo Banteng, Bos javanicus butleri, Sapi Utan
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Regulation and control of animal/human diseases
Description of origin: variety of Banteng: Bos (Bibos) javanicus butleri (Lydekker)

Description: Brazilian import. Name appears to indicate origin from the Nellore district of Andhra Pradesh in India.
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Habitat provision and biodiversity, Regulation and control of animal/human diseases, Vegetation management, Waste recycling of non-human edible feed, Water quality and flows regulation/purification, Weed control and biomass residue management
Description Of Specific Uses: Mainly used as a meat breed. In integration projects (cattle in oil palm plantations), the Nelore is often used as as sire breed. It is also used in crossbreeding due to its adaptability to the tropical environment.
Additional information: Imported for meat production and tropical adaptability.
Additional information comments: Nucleus herd had 1,237 head of purebred Nelore cattle in year 2008.
Adaptability to specific environment: Adapted to hot and humid tropical climate.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Good tolerance to ticks and tropical diseases.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Satisfactory reproductive performance.
Special characteristic of product: Meat of reasonable quality.
Other special qualities: Highly adaptable to equatorial environment.
Color comments: uni color: white, gray
Horn shape size and comments: Short horns, growing outwards and inwards.
Other specific visible traits: zebu, large breed, medium-sized head and broad forehead, long and deep barrel, strong legs, long and tapered tail, beef-type
Location within country: Nucleus herd at the Ulu Lepar Federal Livestock Center in Pahang state. Found in tree-crop integration areas in Malaysia.
Management conditions performance measur: Medium input production system
Comments management conditions: Grazing on pasture with a little supplementation using concentrates.
Additional performance parameters: On feedlot able to grow in excess of 700 g/day.

Description: Originating from India/Pakistan - large numbers in Central and Southern areas of Pakistan, and in Punjab/Bihar/Uttar Pradesh in India.
Other name: Montgomery, Lola, Multani, Teli, Lambi Bar
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Regulation and control of animal/human diseases
Description Of Specific Uses: Sahiwal mainly a milch breed. When no more useful for milk production, animals are slaughtered for meat production.
Additional information: No pure Sahiwal herd exists.
Additional information comments: In the 1950's and 1960's, the Sahiwal was used in crossbreeding with local breeds. Subsequently it was used as a foundation breed in the development of the Mafriwal.
Adaptability to specific environment: Adapted to tropical environment.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The animals are reported to show resistance to tick borne diseases.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Satisfactory breeder.
Special characteristic of product: This is an excellent zebu dairy breed.
Other special qualities: Excellent in crossbreeding with temperate breeds such as the Holstein, to produce a tropically well-adapted yet high producing dairy animal.
Reference for special qualities: CHEAH P.F. and KUMAR R.A. (1984). Preliminary observations on the performance of Sahiwal x Bos taurus dairy cattle. Malaysian Veterinary Journal 16(1): 1-7.
Color comments: Red or light red in color. Some animals with patches of white.
Horn shape size and comments: Short, thick and blunt, curving upwards, forwards and inwards.
Other specific visible traits: zebu, medium sized breed, medium-sized forehead, wedge-shaped barrel, short legs, long tail, well-developed udder. dairy-type
Description of origin: Imported from Pakistan and India in 1900 - 1930: to date no pure-bred animals exist; Semen imported from Kenya - Kenyan Sahiwal in mid 1980's.
Import: Imported since 1900 from Sahiwal breed of Pakistan and India. Imported in 2 shipments from 1985 (approximately) from Sahiwal breed of Kenya.
Location within country: Used as a foundation breed in the development of the Malaysian Friesian Sahiwal (Mafriwal) cattle breed. Nucleus herd of Mafriwal in Kluang, Johore. Other Mafriwal animals distributed throughout Peninsular Malaysia.
Performance data reference: N2-56 N3-60 F66-49 FAO Breed Survey
Management conditions performance measur: Medium input production system.
Comments management conditions: Grazing with a little concentrate feeding.

Description: Belongs to the family Bovidae in the order Artiodactyla.
Other name: Bos gaurus hubackii, Malayan Gaur, Malayan Bison, Gaur
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Regulation and control of animal/human diseases
Description Of Specific Uses: Seladang is considered wildlife and has great touristic potential due to its large size and beauty.
Additional information: The lifespan of the gaur in captivity ranges between 17 - 19 years.
Additional information comments: The reintroduction of gaur into the wild by the Department of Wildlife and National Parks Malaysia follows the Guidelines for Reintroductions prepared by Species Survival Commission of the IUCN. The primary objective of this reintroduction is to re-establish, enhance and increase the long-term survival of a viable, self sustaining gaur population in the wild.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The animals of this breed are reported to show a high degree of disease resistance.
Color comments: Dark brown coat.
Horn shape size and comments: Medium sized curved horns. Horns curved upwards and backwards.
Other specific visible traits: Dark brown coat, a hump between the shoulders and white 'stockings' on all four legs. New born calves are yellowish brown in color and change into adult coloration at the age of 3 months.
Description of origin: Bos (Bibos) gaurus hubbacki (Lydekker), variety of Gaur
Location within country: Mainly in primary forest of Malay Peninsula
Performance data reference: FAO Breed Survey Momin Khan M.K. (1977) The future of Seladang. Nature Malaysia 2; 22-27. Momin Khan M.K. (1973) Studies on the Seledang (Bos gaurus) in the State of Perak. Malaysian Nature Journal 26; 163-167.
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were measured on animals kept under stationary conditions, housed and fed on fodder (in captivity).
Comments management conditions: The animals raised in captivity are kept confined to an intensive management system and are given cut fodder.
Additional performance parameters: When Seladang males are mated with female cattle (Bos taurus x Bos indicus crosses), the offspring have massive musculature in the forequarters. Hybrid bulls weigh 600 - 1 000 kg and are 1.4 to 1.7 m tall. Hybrid cows are slightly shorter and about 200 - 300 kg lighter as compared to their male sibs.

Specific resistance or tolerance: Heat tolerant, parasite and disease tolerant
Reference for special qualities: DAGRIS 2007. Domestic Animal Genetic Resources Information System (DAGRIS). (eds. J.E.O. Rege, O. Hanotte, Y. Mamo, B. Asrat and T. Dessie). International Livestock Research Institute, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. http://dagris.ilri.cgiar.org
Description of origin: Locally adapted breed. The original cattle and their traditional owners arrived in South Africa about 590-700 AD and migrated along the western side of southern Africa to areas of the Western Cape Province. The breed evolved through gradual genetic selection (initially for traction) from among the acquired local Sanga stock by settled Dutch (Afrikaans) in South Africa in the 18th and 19th centuries. Surviving herds of the Rinderpest plague of 1896-99 and the Boer War of 1899-1902 provided the foundation stock of the modern Africander breed. The herd book was set up in 1907 and the breed association was established in 1912. The breed has since been exported to neighboring countries.

Color comments: uni coloured: black, red multi coloured: pied, coloursided
Horn shape size and comments: long horns, crescent or lyre shaped
Other specific visible traits: Sanga type

Color comments: uni coloured: usually dun or black
Other specific visible traits: Sanga type
Description of origin: similar to Kaokoveld (but smaller), Kavango and Caprivi

Other name: AzaouakDamerghou, Azawa, Azawal, Shanun Adar, Tagama, Taureg, Azaouak
Other special qualities: Good walker.
Color comments: uni coloured: red-mahony, blond, dark fawn, white, grey and even black coloured
Other specific visible traits: West African (Shorthorned) type, similar to Shuwa
Performance data reference: FAO Breed Survey Pagot (1985) L'Elevage en pays tropicaux. IEMVT (1971) Principal races domestiques de zones tropicales d'Afrique Francophone et de Madagascar.

Description: The Bororo breed represents approximately 41.55% (RGAC 2007) of the national herd and takes its name from a Peulh tribe in Niger. The same breed receives several other names. This breed originating in Niger is present in Nigeria, Benin, Mali, Burkina Faso, Cameroon and the Central African Republic.
Other name: Djafoun, Fellata, Gabassae, Gadehe, Hanagamba, Kreda, Mbororo, Ogha, Rahadji, Rahaza, Red Bororo, Red Fulani, Brahaza
Color comments: uni coloured: mahogany, sometimes white
Horn shape size and comments: very long (up to 63 cm) lyre shaped horns
Other specific visible traits: slender body with long legs

Other name: Diali., Djerma, Jali, Jalli, Jalliji, Jeli, Peul Nigerien, Shanun Bayaro, Djeli
Color comments: uni coloured: white, sometimes white with spots
Other specific visible traits: West African Zebu type

Other name: Bokoloji, Chanoun mata, Goudhalé, Sokoto Gudali, Gudali
Other specific visible traits: Rather long and broad ears, well-developed hump.
Location within country: South of Maradi and in the districts of Gaya (Department of Dosso), Konni (Department of Tahoua) and Diffa (zone of Bosso).
Management conditions performance measur: Breeding Station Kirkissoye.

Description: It was raised on the border with Nigeria by the Katsinawa Peuhls in the south of the Department of Maradi
Other name: Baharie, Bare, Borrie, Boudouma, Buduma, Chad, Dongole, Kuburi, White Lake Chad, Kouri
Other special qualities: The animals can stay afloat and swim long distances.
Color comments: uni coloured: light or white, occasionally with spots
Additional performance parameters: fertility rate: 67-76%, dairy production: 1260 kg for a lactation period of 280 days, average live body weight : 400-500 kg

Color comments: uni coloured: red

Horn shape size and comments: Lyre shaped horns. These hornes are fine in cows and thick in oxen and bulls.
Location within country: South of the Maradi department close to the border of Nigeria.
Comments management conditions: Kept by the Katsinawa Peul pastoralists.

Color comments: multi coloured: usually pied, white, black, red or brown
Other specific visible traits: West African Zebu type. Medium to large sized animal. A pendulous hump and a short head and muzzle.

Other name: Azaouak, Azawa, Azawal, Tagama., Taureg, Shanun Adar
Other special qualities: Docile, can be trained for ploughing and carting.
Color comments: Uni coloured: blond to dark fawn, sometimes they are white, brown, pied and black
Other specific visible traits: West African (Shorthorned) type, similar to Shuwa
Location within country: Native to Azawak valley north east of Nigeria and distributed along its northern border. Generally, found on the Nigerian border in western Sokoto State. Also occurs in North western Kwara State and dotted along the northern order of Nigeria from Sokoto to eastern Kano.
Performance data reference: FAO Breed Survey Pagot (1985) L'Elevage en pays tropicaux. IEMVT (1971) Principal races domestiques de zones tropicales d'Afrique Francophone et de Madagascar.

Color comments: uni coloured: brown multi coloured: red pied, black pied

Description of origin: Muturu (Shorthorn) x White Fulani (zebu); absorbed by Zebu

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to a harsh climate.
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is reported to be trypanotolerant.
Color comments: uni coloured: white, grey and black colours predominate, pied and brown also occur
Other specific visible traits: small hump or humpless
Description of origin: composite of humpless Dwarf Muturu (from southern Nigeria) and Zebu (from northern Nigeria)

Other name: Baharie, Bare, Borrie, Boudouma, Buduma, Chad, Dongole, Kuburi, White Lake Chad, Kouri
Other special qualities: The animals can stay afloat and swim long distances. Kuri cattle are excellent carting animals.
Color comments: uni coloured: light or white, occasionally with spots
Other specific visible traits: Large-bodied hump less cattle.
Location within country: Lake Chad Basin of Nigeria, Bornu State.

Other name: Forest Muturu, Nigerian Shorthorn, Pagan, Nigerian Dwarf
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is reported to be trypanotolerant.
Color comments: uni coloured: black comments: generally, black coloured or black and white for those found south of Niger-Benue Rivers and Plateau State, Forest Muturu have a white patch around the muzzle and a tawny line above the vertebral column, in the north, brown, red and tawny colours occur
Other specific visible traits: smallest cattle breed known, humpless.
Description of origin: variety of West African Shorthorn: In Nigeria all Shorthorn cattle are called Muturu. There is no distinction between the Dwarf (Forest) and the Savannah types.
Management conditions performance measur: Available information on the production characteristics of this breed have been compiled and reviewed by the authors from exsisting literature for animals kept under different management conditions.
Additional performance parameters: The animals and their hides are used mainly for ritual sacrifices and cerimonies, particularly funerals. Muturu are, also, commonly kept as pets or, frequently, they are used for prestige or dowry purposes.

Other name: Boyenca, Fouta Jallon, Fouta Longhorn, Futa, Malinke, Mandingo, N'dama Peti, Outa Malinke, Boenca
Adaptability to specific environment: The animals can survive under very humid conditions.
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is reported to be trypanotolerant.
Specific reproductive characteristic: They are exceptionally fertile, early maturing.
Other special qualities: The animals are well known for their hardiness.
Color comments: uni coloured: usually fawn, red or brown, occasionally or black multi coloured: occasionally pied
Other specific visible traits: Medium-sized, compact body, short legs, broad straight back, and no hump. Females have small dew-lap in male and fairly large head.
Location within country: Occur in Southwest (Fashola and Ado-Ekiti) and south east (Adada) of Nigeria.

Other name: Djafoun, Fellata, Gabassae, Gadehe, Hanagamba, Kreda, Mbororo, Ogha, Rahaza, Red Fulani, Brahaza
Color comments: uni coloured: mahogany, sometimes white
Horn shape size and comments: very long (up to 63 cm) lyre shaped horns
Other specific visible traits: Slender body with long legs. Very large bodied breed with deep burgundy coloured coat, pendulous ears and long thick horns.
Location within country: Native to the Arid and Semi Arid regions of Northern Nigeria

Color comments: uni coloured: usually dark red, also black or pied.
Other specific visible traits: Well developed hump in males.
Description of origin: West African Shorthorned Zebu type, similar to Azaouak
Comments management conditions: The animals encounter the necessity to search for both water and feed during the dry season.
Additional performance parameters: Good dairy animal. Average milk yield 1,212kg over 259 days.

Color comments: uni colour: cream, light grey or dun comment: some have darkened patches around the front half of the body
Horn shape size and comments: Horns are very short or effectively absent.
Other specific visible traits: Short legs. Dewlap and skin folds are very well developed.
Performance data reference: N2-78, 79 FAO Breed Survey Rege J.O.E. et al (1994) Anim. Prod. 51 (1) in press.

Other name: Akou, Foulbe Blanc, White Kano, Yakanaji, Bunaji
Color comments: uni coloured: usually white with black skin and points
Horn shape size and comments: lyre shaped horns, up to 51 cm
Other specific visible traits: Large well-developed dewlaps, especially in males.
Location within country: Northern Nigeria, from Lagos State to Sokoto, Katsina and Kano States. Spread across the Middle Belt.

Color comments: uni coloured: black, red, brown, dun comments: pied or speckled with white
Description of origin: variety of Adamawa with Muturu blood

Other specific visible traits: Zebu cattle
Zebu cattle

Location within country: Mateares, Los Brasiles, La Paz Centro, Nagarote & Matagalpa

Other name: Improved Criollo, Milking Criollo, Tropical Dairy Criollo, criollo lechero centroamericano, Criollo Lechero Tropical

composite of Simmental and brahman (5/8 Simmental 3/8 Brahman)

mostly tethered with individual farmers having up to 5 animals, which they rotate around their land

Description: Polled beef breed
Red and white cattle with special horn shape.
Breed specialized for beef production. Economic breed.

Description: Dual purpose breed, originating from Belgium
There is also a strain Belted Galloway. In 2008 with 49 adult breeding females.

Description Of Specific Uses: Galloway is of great importance for grazing and nature management.

Description: Fast growing animal with carcass with a good conformation.
The Brahman breed was developed from progeny of four Indian cattle breeds with some infusion

De Deep Red is descended from the Meuse-Rhine_IJssel (Netherlands). The animals are red with small white patterns on head an tail tip and on the four legs (6 points white). They have a dark pigmented nose and blue tongue.
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Vegetation management
Description Of Specific Uses: Brandrood cattle is important for grazing and nature management.
Additional information: Because of the fact the original breed was MRIJ, no population data from before 1980 are known. By that time all these cattle were registered as MRIJ.
Efabis cultural role comment: known from old paintings f.e. Paulus Potter
Efabis environmental role: Especially for nature management. Some farmers milk Deep Red cattle.
Color comments: uni coloured: red with white spots on head and white tail tip
Other specific visible traits: Quiet character
Location within country: eastern and southern parts of The Netherlands

Description: Dwarf cattle breed from Africa (Dahomey (now Benin)).

Efabis main colour: One colour: black, brown or dun
Other specific visible traits: miniature

Description: website www.fleckviehstamboek.nl. Fleckvieh in the Netherlands is used for crossbreeding. Fleckvieh aus Wikipedia, der freien Enzyklopädie Das Fleckvieh, auch Simmentaler oder Simmentaler Fleckvieh genannt, ist eine Rasse des Hausrindes. Die Benennung ist jedoch in der Schweiz unterschiedlich zu der in Deutschland und Österreich. In Deutschland und Österreich werden Fleckvieh und Simmentaler bzw. Simmentaler Fleckvieh synonym verwendet. In der Schweiz bezeichnet man als Simmentaler Tiere, die weniger als 12,5 % Red Holstein Vorfahren besitzen, während der Begriff Swiss Fleckvieh bis 1. Juli 2008 Tiere bezeichnet, die zwischen 12,5 und 75 % Red Holstein Vorfahren haben. Ab 1. Juli 2008 wurde die sogenannte Blutgrenze zur Abgrenzung gegenüber Red Holstein auf 87 % erhöht. Zudem soll Swiss Fleckvieh zu einer eigenständigen Rasse werden[1]. Allerdings führt auch das Fleckvieh in Deutschland und in Österreich einen gewissen Anteil an Red Holstein-Blut. Fleckvieh ist eine sogenannte Zweinutzungsrasse, bei der die Milch- und die Fleischleistung gleichermaßen eine Rolle spielen. Die Rasse geht auf Hausrinder im Simmental im Berner Oberland zurück, das bereits im Mittelalter für seine großwüchsigen und gescheckten Rinder bekannt war.

This was till 1975 the most important breed in the Netherlands. Black and white cows. Dutch Friesian cows were exported to the USA, were from these animals the Holstein Friesian is bred. Due to the selection from dual purpose to specialized dairy cattle the milk production of the HF is higher and muscling is lower.http://www.frieshollands.nl
Additional information: 2005: This indigenous Dutch breed is a black and white dairy type cattle. During a century the FH breed was the most important breed in the Netherlands (till about 1980). In 1963 the cattle population was 71% FH and 26% MRIJ. In 2007 less than 1% is FH.
Color comments: black and white

Description: Red and white cattle. Conformation like Dutch Friesian (FH). Red colour is single recessive gene. Homozygote animals can be darker red than heterozygote animals.http://www.zeldzamerassen.nl/roodbontfriesvee/Geschiedenis Red and white cattle. Conformation like Dutch Friesian (FH). Red colour is single recessive gene. Homozygote animals can be darker red than heterozygote animals.http://www.zeldzamerassen.nl/roodbontfriesvee/Geschiedenis Red and white cattle. Conformation like Dutch Friesian (FH). Red colour is single recessive gene. Homozygote animals can be darker red than heterozygote animals. http://www.zeldzamerassen.nl/roodbontfriesvee/Geschiedenis
Other name: Red Friesian, Friesian Red and White
Additional information: 56 breeders in 2004.
Additional information comments: Unofficial sub-herdbook established in 1897. Bloodgroup research by Mr.C.Buys, Nude 25, NL-6702 DJ Wageningen, Netherlands, Tel. 0317-414052
Efabis cultural role comment: Unoffic. sub-herdbook established in 1897
Color comments: multi coloured: red, white
Other specific visible traits: dual purpose breed
Description of origin: indigenous breed, Dutch Friesian (carrying red factor)

Description: The Glan cattle were imported again in Limburg by Natuurmonumenten in 2002. From the Eiffel. To graze in Noorbeek.
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Vegetation management
Description of origin: imported from the Eiffel. Now nature management. In the past: milk, meat, draught.

Description: Groningen Whiteheaded is an old Dutch breed. In the beginning of the 20th century is was found in Groningen and Utrecht-South-Holland. It is a dual purpose breed with 60% milk and 40% meat part. Some say 50-50. The cattle are black and white or red and white with white head and black eye-rings, white ""socks"", belly and tailtip. They are about 133 cm high. Strong legs and claws, good food-efficiency.
Description Of Specific Uses: More interest in this breed for crossbreeding with HF (F1 product). And from organic farmers.
Additional information: There is a strong influence of HF. Ca. 6 000 cross-breds Groninger Blaarkop x HF exist. A breeding structure for pure-breeding is in place and results in a slow increase of numbers of pure-bred females.; 2004: 20% is black Groningen, 80% red. About 1500 animals is 8/8 Groningen breed. http://szh.nowonline.nl/GroningerBlaarkop www.regionalcattlebreeds.eu
Additional information comments: There are many crossbreds with HF. Narrow blood characteristics. All AI males go back to one male in 1924.
Specific reproductive characteristic: For cows easy calving and high fertility is reported.
Other special qualities: The animals have strong legs and feet. The breed is known for longevity with an average age of 5.04 years.
Efabis adaptability to marginal land: big claws for wet area's. Is said about this breed.
Color comments: multi coloured: black and white or red and white with white head and black eye-rings, white ""socks"", belly and tailtip
Horn shape size and comments: middle size, horizontal, sometimes driphorns or volatile horns
Other specific visible traits: In 2008 about 25% is black white headed and 75% is red.
Location within country: From origin: Province Groningen and around Utrecht to West Nederland. Now the whole country.
Comments management conditions: suckling cows are kept in natural areas.

Description: Around 1930 created by crossings of several primitive breeds to look like the original "Oerrund". The Heck looks like the original breed but is a lot smaller.
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Vegetation management
Description Of Specific Uses: Heck breed is important for grazing and nature management.

Description: Sortbroget Jydsk Malkekvaeg, imported from Denmark in 2007. Found at 2 farmers: Westergaard en Kortegaard. Originally found at poor ground is Jutland, Germany and Netherlands. Kortegaard still at Gelders Landschap. Westergaard now at Natuurmonumenten. In 2021 Vereniging het Heiderund.
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Vegetation management
Color comments: about 110 wither height
Description of origin: These cattle origin in Jutland, but similar cows were in the past in the Netherlands.

Description: 98% of Dutch dairy cattle is Holstein. In 1975 1,2% of all AI was from this breed, in 1980 10,7% and in 1984 already 44,9%.
Additional information: In the Netherlands Holstein Friesian is the main cattle breed.
Special characteristic of product: This breed is known for the high milk production.
Color comments: Black and white or Red and White
Horn shape size and comments: Most horns are removed. There are some polled cattle.
Other specific visible traits: milk type
Description of origin: composite of Dutch Friesian (Netherlands) and Holstein-Friesian (USA and Canada).
Performance data reference: EY 305 days: Black and white: 9705 kg and Red and White: 8694 kg

Description: 98% of Dutch dairy cattle is Holstein. In 1975 1,2% of all AI was from this breed, in 1980 10,7% and in 1984 already 44,9%.

Dutch Belted cattle have a white belt. More than 25 cm. Between the shoulder and the hip. Between 126-136 cm. Horns, feet and tongue have to be pigmented. https://zeldzamerassen.nl/lakenvelderrund/de-vereniging/
Description Of Specific Uses: In the past the animals were used as ""park-cattle"".
Additional information: Lakenvelder population: 50% black and 50% red; semen of 10 bulls at KI Samen BV, 1100 inseminations a year and unknown number of natural matings in 2004. 1100 females and 30 males and 304 breeders in 2004.
Efabis cultural role comment: as old animal used as "park-cattle" by country-seats
Color comments: multi coloured: black or red with white belt
Horn shape size and comments: occurrence of rare polled animals, little volatile horns
Year of origin: In 1772 this breed was already described. In 1950 the breed was almost extinct. No herd book meant no sires to use.
Import: 5-20% Belted Galloway imported from United Kingdom since 1960: 5-20% Dutch Belted imported from USA since 1979

Description: Limousin is beef breed, originally from France.

In 1963 was 26% of the Dutch cattle population MRIJ. Dual purpose, sober, strong, calm, robust, muscled red and white cattle. Thick thighs and strong legs. Females are about 137 cm in height and weigh 600-800 kg. Males somewhat taller. Strong points of the MRIJ breed are longevity, low veterinary cost, little feet or fertility problems and high revenues from sale of cull stock, resulting in a high net income or margin per kg of milk. The optimal environment for the MRIJ breed is considered to be a production system with much grass or silage, or even with permanent pasture, a so called extensive farm management system (<12.000 kg milk/ha).
Other name: MRIJ, Meuse-Rhine-Yssel cattle, Red and White, Roodbont
Additional information: The population of MRIJ is decreasing quite fast.
Other special qualities: This is a dual-purpose breed which can economically compete with the HF cattle.
Color comments: multi coloured: red, white
Other specific visible traits: Dual purpose breed. Strong points of the MRY breed are longevity, low veterinary cost, little feet or fertility problems and high revenues from sale of cull stock
Description of origin: Indigenous breed. MRY was developed in two regions in the Netherlands, in the province Overijssel and in the eastern part of Brabant. MRY is a dual purpose breed, selected for both milk and meat production. Since 1874 animals are registered in the Nederlands Rundvee Syndicaat (NRS) an since 1905 MRY is recognized as a breed. There are also populations of MRY or (strong) related breeds in Luxembourg, Belgium (Belgian Red Pied or Pie Rouge de Belgique), Germany (German Red or Deutsche Rotbunte), Spain and also in Ireland and Eastern Europe.
Import: since 1970, max 12% Red Holstein (USA) is in the population, The number of animals has decreased the last 30 years due to the replacement by Red Holstein.
Location within country: southern and eastern Netherlands; along the rivers.
Additional performance parameters: Dual purpose breed. Height between 1905-1955 was 130 cm. In 2000 a mean MRIJ cow was 137 cm. In 2014 139 cm.

Description: the smallest breeds of cattle in the world
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to middle mountain (1 500 m asl.) altitudes.
Color comments: Body colour varies from black to white i.e. black, brown, grey, white, spotted black and white.
Other specific visible traits: Achhami cattle are the smallest breeds of cattle in the world. They are less than 1 metre in height at withers. Ear is straight with an average length of 17 cm. Its temperament varies from docile to wild. The wither height of Achhami cattle was 110.8 ±1.9 cm at the age of 9 years. Similarly, maximum body weight and body length were 149.38±5.1 kg and 98.07±1.52 cm respectively at the age of 8 years (Annual Report of ABD, 1994/95). Morphology Summery:(lenght in cm.) Body length 92.1 Heart girth 118.6 Height at wither 90.8 Height at hip bone 88.5 Head length 33.2 Tail length 72.42 Horn length 3.0 Ear length 16.8 Neck length 30.8 Loin girth 115.4 Barrel height from ground 44.8 Fore legs above knee 32.1 Fore legs below knee 26.7 Rear legs above knee 34.8 Rear legs below knee 32.8
Description of origin: This is a indigenous breed of Nepal.
Location within country: Achhami cattle are located in the far western region of Nepal (Achham District).
Comments management conditions: They are kept in semi stationary production systems.
Additional performance parameters: They have low milking ability and produce on an average of 1.5 kg milk with standard errors of 0.22 kg in a lactation length of 225 days. Although the average daily milk yield is less than 2 litres but it has wide variation ranging from 1 to 4 litres. This indicated that the breed has potential to produce more than what it is producing.

Special characteristic of product: These animals produce good, tasty meat and leather of good quality.
Other specific visible traits: very big animals
Description of origin: The Gaur is the largest of the Asiatic bovids. Two subspecies are recognised, B. g.gaurus (India, Nepal) and B. g. laosiensis (Myanmar, Thailand, Laos, Vietnam, Cambodia and West Malaysia).

Description: Khailla cattle are found from Siwalik range (400 m) to high mountains (4000 m) of the country. They are located mainly in far western hilly regions of the country and are a good draught breed. These cattle are well adapted and can graze on the slopes of the hills and mountains. Besides the draught power they are used for milk and manure too. They are larger size and strongly built. They are localized in limited areas and are few in numbers. They have been characterized at phenotypic level only.
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer
Other specific visible traits: Khaila cattle are good draught type animals located in far western region of the country. They are strongly built and suitable for draught purpose. They are larger indigenous cattle breed in the country (Table 2). About 42% of the Khaila cattle are black and white in colour and the horn of 65% cattle are straight and upward in direction (Kunwar et al., 1998). These animals have a wild temperament and are difficult to handle, except, by the owner. Morphology Summery: Body length 128 Heart girth 162 Height at hip bone 118 Head length 48 Tail length 99 Horn length 18 Ear length 23 Neck length 41 Loin girth 170 Barrel height from ground 56 Fore legs above knee 85 Fore legs below knee 32 Rear legs above knee 68 Rear legs below knee 43
Description of origin: Natibe breed of the Bos indicus specie. There is no written record on the origin of the Khailla cattle. It is believed that these cattle (Doteli Gai) came from Doti and Dadeldhura districts.
Location within country: Far western hilly region of the country.
Additional performance parameters: Khaila is a large sized cattle having low milk yielding ability but good draught characters. They produce on an average of 2.5 kg milk per day in a lactation length of 10 months (305 days). They are hardy and suitable for hill conditions. They can thrive in harsh environments and can produce in low input system.

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to high altitudes (3 000 m asl.).
Description of origin: Kirko and Lulu cattle seem to have the same genetic origin and are considered to belong to the same breed genetically but are found in two different locations.
Location within country: Trans-Himalaya, eastern region of high altitude area (around 3 000 asl.)
Comments management conditions: Management is very poor and most animals depend on natural grass and fodder in the area.

Description: Only humpless indigenous breed of cattle found in Nepal.
Other name: Lulu gai, Lulu meh, Lulu mo
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to high altitudes (3 000 m asl.). They are very hardy and adapted to cold and dry areas.
Other specific visible traits: This is the only breed of cattle in the country that is humpless. Summery of measurement (cm.) Body length 99.4 Heart girth 114.2 Height at wither 87.2 Height at hip bone 87.7 Head length 34.6 Tail length 50-60 Horn length 15.8 Ear length 13.8 Neck length 29.1 Loin girth 109.4 Barrel height from ground 40.7 Fore legs above knee 28.1 Fore legs below knee 24.6 Rear legs above knee 34.2 Rear legs below knee 35.3
Description of origin: Kirko and Lulu cattle seem to have the same genetic origin and are considered to belong to the same breed genetically but are found in two different locations.
Location within country: western region of high Himalayan Zone (above 3 000 m asl.), Mustang and Manang District.
Management conditions performance measur: A small study was carried out on performance data in the Western Region of the Mustang District including 19 cows (ranging from 1st to 12th lactation) which were recorded for 3 months.
Comments management conditions: Management is very poor and most animals depend on natural grass and fodder in the area.
Additional performance parameters: Lulu are a small sized cattle having low milk yielding ability. They produce on an average of 1.6 kg milk with 0.3 kg of standard errors in a lactation length of 195 days. The range of milk production lies between 0.5 to 3.57 litres. The highest milk production was found in the 7th lactation. The Lulu Mo (♀) is weighed higher than Lulu Meh (♂) due to better care and management of female calves than male. Body weight of most of the Lulu cows, aged from 2 to 18 years, averaged between 150 to 200 kg. The maximum body weight observed was 227 kg in males at 6 years of age. These animals are very hardy and suitable for cool and dry place. They can thrive in harsh environments and can produce in low input system. They attain sexual maturity at about 3.5 years and produce the first progeny at an age of 4 to 4.5 years (Table 3). This figure is quite high when compared with European cattle (Jersey and Holstein-Friesian) which attain sexual maturity at about 1.5 to 2 years. Gestation length is about 9 months (280 days) which is similar with several literature reports. This is well within the range of cattle breeds.

Other specific visible traits: Zebu

Description: Pahadi cattle, which represent the majority of cattle population in the country are located across the hills and are good for draught purpose in the terraced hill conditions. They are adaptable to cool and harsh climatic conditions and can thrive and work in low input system. They are also used for milk and manure.
Other name: Nepalese Hill, Nepali Hill Zebu, Pahari, Pahari Guie, Pahari Sandhe, Black Hill Zebu
Adaptability to specific environment: Good for draught purpose on the terraced hills. Adapted to cold climate conditions.
Color comments: They are mostly black in colour.
Other specific visible traits: Zebu, Indian hill type
Description of origin: Native breed of the Bos indicus species.
Performance data reference: FAO Breed Survey Epstein (?) Domestic Animals of Nepal.

Description: Siri was a popular breed of eastern Nepal, considered to be introduced to Ilam through Darjeeling of India from Bhutan via Sikkim (Epstein, 1977). Siri, a productive breed in the hilly areas of eastern region, particularly Ilam district has been extinct from the country (Neopane, 2002). They were reared in eastern hilly region 1200 meter above sea level. They had undergone cross breeding with local cattle and are extinct at pure form.
Color comments: Body colour varies from black to white i.e. black, brown, grey, white, spotted black and white.
Horn shape size and comments: sharp horns projecting forward and slightly upward (Shrestha, 1994).
Other specific visible traits: They have a well developed udder and are larger than black Pahadi cattle. They have wide flat forehead and small ears.
Description of origin: Considered to be introduced to Ilam through Darjeeling of India from Bhutan via Sikkim (Epstein, 1977).
Location within country: Siri cattle were reared in eastern hilly region above 1200 meter above sea level.
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were measured under stationary conditions with all year round housing and grazing and fodder.
Additional performance parameters: They can produce up to 6 liters of milk per day.

Specific resistance or tolerance: A good disease resistance is reported for animals of this breed.

Description: The Guabalá cattle population was identified in 2006 in the hands of producers in the region of Remedios and Tolé province of Chiriquí and also in the zone of El Valle de Antón, in the province of Coclé and is the object of survey due to its good adaptation to these regions. The phenotypic characteristics of the Guabalá population are: red colour , pronghorn in red and blond. Robust appearance and well -proportioned hindquarters, with a large, elongated head . Also small ears with long antlers and sharp points. There is a conservation nucleus for Guabalá Bovines in the Ollas Arriba zone in Capira, in the Province of Panamá Oeste, under the responsibility of IDIAP, the Instituto de Investigación Agropecuaria de Panamá.
Color comments: colour , splashed and blonde red
Horn shape size and comments: small ears with long antlers and sharp tips
Other specific visible traits: Robust appearance and well proportioned hindquarters, with a large and elongated head . Hair short and lustrous coat, a product of the “Slick” gene , very common in other creole breeds.
Description of origin: The Guabalá cattle population was recently identified in 2006 in the hands of producers in the region of Remedios and Tolé province of Chiriquí and also in the zone of El Valle de Antón, in the province of Coclé and is the object of survey due to its good adaptation to these regions. Jorge de Alba himself estimated that contrary to what was thought, they are different populations, at least phenotypically, which has originated this survey since it was thought that in the Panamanian territory there was only a single population of Creole cattle. The phenotypic characteristics of the Guabalá population are: red colour , pronghorn in red and blond. Robust appearance and well -proportioned hindquarters, with a large, elongated head . Also small ears with long antlers and sharp points. Don Juan Castrellon is credited with creating the breed in the 19th century.
Location within country: Guabala, Chiriqui province; Bejuco, Ollas above Panama Oeste province; Las playitas, Panama province

Description: It was originated in the area that includes the Ngöbe-bugle indigenous region in the mountainous zone of the Chiriquí province and a diversity of colors has been identified such as pronghorn in black, red pronghorn, ashen, black, black cariblanco and presents diversity in the size of hair The average size is 1.20 m at the withers and 1.79 m in body length. At birth, females and males can weigh 27 and 28 kg respectively and an adult weight of 465 kg. The total population is not exactly known since it is located in areas of difficult access, without penetration roads.
Specific resistance or tolerance: resistance to plagues and diseases
Color comments: a. Brown Creole: it is characterized by its brown colour and some other dark tones on the face and vertical part of the body. In addition , white colour appear on the vertical part of the body, legs and face. Individuals with cream colour may also appear all over the body. b. Criollos Cariblanco: It is characterized by its grayish colour on the body, white spot on the face and dark circles around the eyes. c. Creole Black: black on the body with slight white spots on the face and body.
Horn shape size and comments: The horns are generally large, orthosis type (thin, strong at the base, directed sideways, forward and upward in the shape of a lyre), smooth, firm , white colour the base from light to light dark towards the tips.
Other specific visible traits: The head is rectangular in shape , slightly elongated, somewhat narrow towards the nose and wider and stronger in the eyes. In its profile, it is flatter and slightly sub -concave. Its forehead is of medium width and the nasal region is straight, short and wide. The nose is completely black and the muzzle has wide, round and well separated nostrils. The mouth is wide and strong. The eyes are elliptical in shape , with slightly protruding orbits , black . The eyelids are clean and wrinkle free. The ear is short, with lively movements, rounded, with abundant long villi on its outer pin.
Description of origin: In the Republic of Panama, the entry of cattle was made at the request of Pedro Arias de Ávila, given the food shortage of the newly created city of Panama in 1519. The entry was made through Santa María la Antigua del Darién in the Year 1521. As a result of this fact and with the rapid proliferation of these animals within the new territory and with the foundation of new cities, migrations were carried out from Panama to the west reaching Chiapas, Mexico and from Panama to the region from Peru to South America, making Panama an important dispersal point for these animals in much of the continent.
Location within country: Gnäbe-bugle, Region; Gualaca Chiriquí province, El Ejido, Los Santos province; Calabacito, Mariato, Veraguas province; Rio Hato, El Coco, Coclé province;

Comments management conditions: as pure bred used in intensive systems, as crossbred (Pardo suizo * zebu) used in extensive/double purpose production systems
as pure bred used in intensive systems, as crossbred (Pardo suizo * zebu) used in extensive/double purpose production systems

Description of origin: Variety (with coloured reduced to a few spots on side) of Polish Marsh. Whitebacked cattle originate from aurochs Bos primigenius. It is found in the region from the Narwia river, through the Bug river basin, to the Wieprz river. In the middle of the 20th century it was considered extinct. When few individuals were found, working on restitution of the original population began.
Location within country: the north-eastern and central Poland (the Nadbuzanski region; the Narwia river region, the Podlasie province and the Lublin province)

Other special qualities: This hardy breed is known for longevity and vitality.

Management conditions performance measur: Performance was measured on the pedigree herds.
Additional performance parameters: Average dressing percentage: heifer - 56.2%, bull calf - 57.5%. Milk is very valuable for cheese production.

Additional information comments: The Mertolenga breed is an intrinsic part of the historical evolution of the largest rural and agricultural region of Portugal.
Efabis cultural role comment: The Mertolenga breed is closely linked to Portuguese culture, especially in the region where the herds of the Genealogical Book are based. From a very early age the Mertolengo males were worked to be used as animal traction in the ploughing of the Alentejo and Ribatejo rice areas. This breed is also used as a halter in the driving of wild cattle.
Adaptability to specific environment: Very good adaptability. It is a breed adapted to the Mediterranean climate in the south of Portugal, where winters are cold and humid and summers are extremely dry and hot. This adaptability is much more noticeable with the aggravation of the characteristics of this type of climate due to climate changes.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Calving ease.
Efabis environmental role: It is an important breed in the development of rural areas, especially in combating desertification. It is a smaller breed than other continental breeds and therefore has the possibility to contribute to the production of quality beef with lower emissions of harmful gases.
Efabis adaptability to marginal land: It is perfectly adapted to environments with skeletal soils and very low organic matter content. It makes good use of all sorts of spontaneous, not being selective.
Horn shape size and comments: White thin horns, dark on the edges, elliptical, hook-shaped, “acabanadaos” or in low lyre.
Other specific visible traits: Three well marked and distinct phenotypes with different coats: the red one, in which we have the absence of white coat; the sorrel one, in which there is an interpolation of red and white coat in several percentages, which gives different shades to each animal; and the spotted one, with well defined red mesh areas in which there is no white coat.
Description of origin: For Bernardo Lima (1873), a small "alentejano", well adapted to the hills of lean pastures and hard loads. Hard to carry and to plough in the hillsides and saws and producing the best ox of halter. It exists in Baixo Alentejo, in the lands of Mértola, Alcoutim and Martinlongo. As a halter ox it was taken to the care of wild cattle in the region of Ribatejo. It was a unicoloured Mertolengo, with a more “retinta” color, without meshes and with spiral horns. Professor Paula Nogueira (quoted by Isaías Vaz, 1987) states that in Baixo Alentejo, the oxen are less corpulent and in the region of Mértola, cut by the Guadiana, there is a variety called Mertolenga, composed of animals with little body and rather cherry or brown color, whose shapes make the transition of the Alentejo cattle to the Algarve cattle. Teófilo Frazão (1961), states that the real Mertolengo was that bovine adapted for its smallness and hardness to the rough, montuous, quite folded and scarce in forage lands of Mértola and Alcoutim, which coincided with the variety mentioned by B. Lima. Still for T. Frazão (1961), with the franchise of the border to the cattle of the two iberian countries, for around 1900, came between them, spotted cattle that, already in the neighboring country, had fame for rusticity and good nail for the campaign of wild cattle. Some were left on the left bank of the Guadiana, others went to the fairs of Garvão and Aljustrel and from there to Ribatejo. With the need for an energetic animal for the rice areas of the Tejo, Sado and Sorraia, since the Alentejano, Mirandesa and Brava breeds, due to their nature, did not meet the requirements, the Mertolenga breed's wild red phenotype appears, with a straight profile, high hooked horns and a feisty nature. Its origin is associated with the lands of Coruche, in the first decades of the 20th century, with interference from “flavor” Charnequeiro cattle and spotted Mertolengo cattle coming from Garvão, and from there it extended its area of dispersion to the valleys of other rivers (Frazão, 1961). From the explanations given by various scholars of the Mertolenga breed directly reflect the use of the original “alentejanado” Mertolengo and the imported “Baixo Guadiana” Mertolengo, the permanence of the genetically strong white colour, giving rise to the “rosilho mil-flores” Mertolengo (which added the “ruão” component of the Mertolenga breed of cattle) and which quickly, by the combination of partial advantages of the other two types, expanded throughout the region of Serpa and Évora, and had as a place of racial solidification the Herdade da Abóboda, due to the effort of several enthusiasts and connoisseurs, of which we highlight Dr. António José Borges Bettencourt, Prof. Nuno Maria Villas Boas Potes and Dr. Isaías Monteiro Vaz. The latter as Technical Secretary of the Breed, in a phase of national turbulence, achieved the great feat of standardizing, within its specificity, the three Mertolengo’s phenotypes.
Location within country: South of Portugal in the Alentejo and Ribatejo regions
Comments management conditions: This breed is suited to husbandry under harsh conditions.

Description: Red-coated bovine animals that have a strong skeleton with wide joints. They are tall and long with the front third more developed than the rear. Their geographical area of dispersion is the Azores Archipelago – Portugal.
Provision Uses: Dam line, Draught power, General crossbreeding, Herding, Horns, Meat, Milk
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Fertilizer, Vegetation management
Cultural Uses: Hobby, Cultural and religious ceremonies, Tourist attraction / touristic potential
Additional information: The breeders of the Ramo Grande are the guardians of an unequalled genetic heritage that over several generations and sometimes under difficult conditions, insisted on keeping as a legacy from their ancestors, in the eagerness to preserve the heritage they had received and which they have always cherished as members of the family.
Efabis cultural role comment: In the traditional festivities of the Azores Archipelago in the various islands, the Ramo Grande cattle participate in ethnographic parades representing various activities in which they played a key role by the time when they were the main driving force. These parades are highly appreciated by the population in general and by visitors to the region, namely emigrants.
Efabis cultural value: It is associated with the “cultural role” referred to in the previous point and there is a great deal of information on the management and practices carried out with bovine animals of this breed, including their teaching for work or ethnographic parades, which is transmitted from parents to children. Particularly on the festivities of the Holy Spirit, the meat of these cattle has always been the preferred one to make the typical dishes of this period characteristic "functions".
Adaptability to specific environment: The soil and climate conditions in the Azores favour pasture production throughout the year, despite fluctuations resulting from temperature and pluviosity fluctuations, which cause the peak of grass production to occur in spring/summer. The biodiversity of the pastures is high and allows most of the nutritional needs of Ramo Grande cattle to be met throughout the year. From its beginning, the production of these cattle in the Azores is based on the use of natural resources, with a strong connection to the natural and sustainable environment.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The production system of Ramo Grande cattle depends essentially on grazing and fodder production, being the products obtained through environmentally sustainable methods, with low incorporation of outside inputs to the farm of origin.
Specific reproductive characteristic: They have a high productive longevity (8.6 years on average), being the average total number of births 5.22.
Other special qualities: They are docile and easy to teach animals, both for some work on the land (which are already practically residual) and for their participation in ethnographic parades.
Efabis genetic features: Bulky, late-growing cattle, but which may extend to 8 years of age or more
Efabis environmental role: Raised outdoors on pastureland 365 days a year.
Efabis adaptability to marginal land: They adapt themselves to lands at different altitudes and to pastures with different floristic compositions.
Color comments: Red, more or less intense
Horn shape size and comments: They are medium sized and predominantly “opistóceros”, i.e. at birth they deviate a little backwards, then come out almost horizontally to the sides, turning forwards with their tips facing upwards.
Description of origin: Native breed from the cattle that came to the Azores at the time of the discovery and settlement of the islands (15th century)
Location within country: Autonomous region of the Azores - Portugal

Provision Uses: Dam line, General crossbreeding, Herding, Horns, Meat, Pack/baggage, Pelt or fur, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Sire line, Skin/hides
