Description of origin: Originally from the Cantal – Auvergne region, France

Description: His fur it is red colour or black . They are always mochos. Short head , short neck without dewlap, broad trunk, muscular quarters, fine fur , fine, silky hairs

Description of origin: recently imported from United Kingdom, Scotland; exotic

Description: The Blonde d'Aquitaine breed comes from the regrouping in 1962 of the three branches of blond cattle (Garonnais, Quercy and Blond des Pyrénées) that populated the Southwest of France. This cash, after being used for a long time for traction, has been redirected towards meat production.
Additional information: The males are very walkers, they work well, and the cows are very good mothers. Thanks to the morphological features of the pelvis, and in particular to its wide opening, the cow does not present difficulties in calving
Color comments: Its coat is ripe wheat colour , varying from dark to light.
Horn shape size and comments: The horns are arranged horizontally and curve downward and forward.
Herdbook established: Oficina de Registros Zootécnicos de la Asociación Rural del Paraguay (ORZARP)

Additional information: Good growth ability. Advantageous feed conversion. Excellent quality of meat and carcass. Tame temperament.
Color comments: Red, short hair ; pigmented fur , well vascularized thick leather .
Herdbook established: Asociación Paraguaya de criadores de Bonsmara

Description: The Boran cattle breed originated in North Africa, approximately 1,300 years ago, as a result of natural selection . Their habitat was the mountains, along with other wild animals. However, nowadays, it is widely used for its enormous qualities.
Adaptability to specific environment: It is a very rustic breed , which has such fine hair that it produces more oil, which allows it to better resist ticks, vectors of some diseases in livestock.
Herdbook established: Oficina de registros Zootecnicos de la Asociación Rural del Paraguay

Description Of Specific Uses: It is a biotype that is characterized by its high production, even under adverse environmental conditions, fertility and maternal ability; feature that make the Braford a fundamental tool for meat production.
Additional information: Muscular, as he age, well balanced, with greater development seen from the side of its forepart, forequarters and depth of the anterior rib in relation to its rear part.
Color comments: The pampa feature will always be present in a minimum of 30% of the face of the animal, noting the contribution of the Hereford. The accepted coats will be: • Colorado, Barcino, Bayo, Osco.
Herdbook established: Asociacion Paraguaya de Criadores de Braford

Description: The Brahman breed was created in the United States of America with the careful crossbreeding of four Indian breeds of cattle (Bos Indicus). Rigid and careful selection from the start resulted in the most efficient meat producing breed for most climates: the Brahman.  Brahman cattle are extremely resistant to heat and high humidity. The Brahman is the best breed in the grazing field for its hardiness and hardiness. These cattle respond excellently to good pastures, but at the same time perform better than many breeds in poor field conditions or prolonged droughts. Brahman cows are excellent mothers, they produce a lot of milk and of good quality. The result is heavy, fleshy calves.
Additional information: These cattle respond excellently to good pastures, but at the same time perform better than many breeds in poor field conditions or prolonged droughts. Brahman cows are excellent mothers, they produce a lot of milk and of good quality. The result is heavy, fleshy calves.
Adaptability to specific environment: Adaptation to the environment and productive potential.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Brahman cattle are extremely resistant to heat, high humidity and external parasites. Brahman's tolerance to ticks is of great economic importance due to less use of chemicals and greater weight gain.
Specific reproductive characteristic: The reproductive performance of an animal is related to its adaptability and nutritional levels. With tropical climates like ours, the Brahman breed is in an excellent position to adaptation to the environment. If we add to this its rusticity and longevity, we find an animal with excellent reproductive qualities.
Color comments: The predominant colour , on fully pigmented fur , is white, however there are also medium gray, dark gray and red Brahman, which originally has Gyr blood .
Horn shape size and comments: The horns are short to medium thick, directed backwards and outwards.
Herdbook established: Asociación Paraguaya de criadores Brahman

Description: Primary Coats: Black or Red. Good bone development, strong limbs with ease of movement.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Short to medium size , good retraction capacity, moderate external preputial opening that allows easy and rapid exteriorization of the penis, angle of fall of approximately 45º with respect to the abdomen, it should not exceed the line of the hocks. Retractable preputial mucosa, unexposed, moist. Medium long foreskin is permissible, reaches the hock line without exceeding it, partial but not permanent exposure of the preputial mucosa. Small or medium folds (aprons) that do not impede reproductive function. Males a minimum of 400 kg, with a minimum scrotal circumference of 32 cm
Color comments: ALLOWED Primary Coats: Black or Red  DESIRABLE Secondary Coats: Barcino (red barcino, snowy barcino, black barcino) Nevado (snowy barcino, dark snowy) Sullen (sullen red , dark sullen). Very light snowy, very dark surly
Other specific visible traits: Good bone development, strong limbs with ease of movement. The broadest and well -muscled males.
Herdbook established: Asociación de Brangus del Paraguay
Location within country: A nivel nacional en todo el territorio del Paraguay

Description: The Charolais breed had its origin in the central -west and south -western regions of France, in the former French provinces of Charolles and Niemen. White coat cattle were first observed in the 16th and 17th centuries, they were known and accepted in the French markets. His highly developed musculature, which is found in the extremities and on the back
Additional information: It is a tall and long animal with good ground clearance.
Color comments: Charolais animals are colour or white ; the hair can be short in summer, it thickens and lengthens during cold seasons.
Horn shape size and comments: The horns are short, although the amochados are being preferred
Herdbook established: Asociacion Paraguaya de Criadores de Charolais

Description: The Chianina breed is one of the oldest in the world. Originally from Italy of origin in the middle valley of the Tiber and in the Val di Chiana, from where the breeding spread to the provinces of Siena, Arezzo, Liorna, Pisa, Florence and Perugia. Considering itself as a triple purpose animal in its home country
Specific resistance or tolerance: It has excellent adaptability to grass in various conditions, as it feeds on forage and is resistant to diseases and ectoparasites.
Color comments: The coat is white in both sexes. The male has black tones in the hindquarters (gray tones). Sometimes it has black hairs around the eyes.
Horn shape size and comments: Medium -cut and thick horns, black at the tip.
Herdbook established: Oficina de registros Zootecnicos de la Asociación Rural del Paraguay

Description of origin: imported; locally adapted; descending from the cattle introduced during the conquest by the Spaniards
Location within country: river basin of Arroyos & Esteros in Eastern Region

Adaptability to specific environment: well adapted to marsh ecosystem
Description of origin: imported; locally adapted; descending from the cattle introduced during the conquest by the Spaniards
Location within country: south of the eastern region; marshy zone of Ñeembucú

Adaptability to specific environment: Adaptability, since it has shown great performance in diverse conditions such as arid and semi -arid areas, as well as in the humid tropics.
Specific reproductive characteristic: High fertility and precocity index, since it reaches puberty at a very early age and can be considered in the breeding months at 15 months of age , so normally the females of this breed have their first offspring at 2 years of age . with proper management, producing one calf per year.
Color comments: Reddish, yellow, dark red or black.
Description of origin: The origin of this breed is in the Simme Valley located in the Bernese Oberland, Switzerland. The Simmental name derives from its original location. In the German language the word "Thal" or "Tal" means "Valley". Simmental literally means Valley of the Simme. This Valley is located where the Simme River flows in the central and western part of Switzerland where its climate is cold and where there is alpine and subalpine vegetation that offers excellent meadows.

Description: The Gelbvieh is a German bovine breed , originally from Franconia to the North of Bavaria, it is the result of crosses made in the 18th century between the Red Holstein, Deutsches Rotbunte, Simmental and Brune
Additional information: The head is proportionally wide and deep, of a medium length, with good separation between the eyes. The fur around these is thick, flexible and slightly wrinkled and pigmented.
Color comments: Has a uniform light brown coat
Herdbook established: Asociación Paraguaya de Criadores de Gelbvieh

Additional information: Their offspring are born with low weight , so there is no problem at birth, the maternal ability feature of the breed, achieving a high weaning rate and good weights.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Resistance to high temperatures, poor quality forages and diseases.
Color comments: They are generally mottled in colour , ranging from red to white. The typical colour is white speckled with red , having lines with more red than white, being specimens with roanism.
Horn shape size and comments: The horns grow backwards and upwards in a spiral.
Description of origin: On the Katiawar peninsula in western India, it is the primary habitat of the Gyr breed . In this region, the average maximum temperature in the shade in summer is 36 - 37 ° C and the minimum in winter reaches 15 ° C; the region is very humid.

Description: Hereford presents remarkable zootechnical characteristics and of outstanding conformation, very good poise, outstanding butcher attitude; females express their fertility with very early pregnancy
Additional information: The Hereford is fundamentally a meat producing breed , recognized for its adaptation to all areas productive, it is precocious reproductively, of easy calving, great dairy ability and long life
Color comments: Colorado from bay to cherry, with white spots on head, back of ears, chest, belly, underside of the limbs and tip of the tail
Horn shape size and comments: If they are horned, they must have good implantation and development
Herdbook established: Asociación Paraguaya de Criadores de Hereford

Color comments: White and black, and white and red.
Horn shape size and comments: The horns are always present although dehorning is a common practice.
Description of origin: This breed is originally from Holland, known for its large size and high milk production, it is a docile breed . White and colour in well black areas, cattle can be totally black or totally white. It can also be found in colour and white , the pigmentation of the fur corresponds to the colour of the hair
Location within country: In the Eastern and Western Region

Adaptability to specific environment: The jersey cow adapts quickly to the different climates of our country.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The Jersey breed has shown a remarkable climatic adaptation in the different regions of the world It performs better than other breeds in tropical conditions due to its greater resistance to heat (1 ° C more than the Swiss Brown and 2 ° C more than the Holstein).
Specific reproductive characteristic: Its speed of development, and its early puberty allow to obtain pregnancies before 15 months. Due to the wide and easily dilatable birth carcass and the low birth weight of the Jersey calf (25 kg). This breed has minimal dystocia problems.
Color comments: The coat is of variable colour , from light brown to black, through tan, overcoat and, less frequency , greyish. The fur on the head and neck is darker, with a light ring around the muzzle. The colour of the udder, belly , and inner thighs are lighter than the rest of the body and all cows have a black muzzle and black eyelashes.
Description of origin: The Jersey Cattle Breed originated on the island of Jersey, located in the English Carcass , between England and France. It is one of the oldest recognized breeds, dating back almost 6 centuries.

Description: The Limousin is a rustic cattle its conformation oriented towards the production of meat; its colour is light yellow (bay) or golden red .
Additional information: Calving ease, good carcass production
Color comments: Its colour is light yellow (bay) or golden red .
Other specific visible traits: The head is strong, of medium size , broad and bulging forehead, convexilinear profile; nape prominent and rounded, full of hair hair; little marked orbits; elliptical horns, inserted behind the nape, slightly arched forward. The neck is short and muscular, well attached to the trunk, dewlap median.
Herdbook established: Asociacion Paraguaya de Criadores de Limousin

Description: It originated from the districts of the same name in India. It comes from areas of very fertile land that are periodically subjected to periods of extreme abundance of rainfall, alternating with periods of absolute drought.
Adaptability to specific environment: Very rustic, great adaptability to extreme conditions in tropical environments. Sober to feed on coarse and not very abundant grasses.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Stamina and ability to travel long distances in search of food
Other special qualities: Excellent maternal ability
Color comments: The coat varies from white to gray, black , and black overalls.
Description of origin: This breed is native to India specifically from the province of Madras, west of India, it is also known as Ongole.

Description: It originated from the districts of the same name in India. It comes from areas of very fertile land that are periodically subjected to periods of extreme abundance of rainfall, alternating with periods of absolute drought.
Other specific visible traits: The coat varies from White to Gray, and black overall
Herdbook established: Oficina de registros Zootecnicos de la Asociación Rural del Paraguay

Adaptability to specific environment: It resists more varied climates: cold, hot, dry or humid.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The strength of its poise allows it to travel long distances in search of food, especially in the poor and rugged terrain of many extensive mountain farms. In addition, it has a great resistance to diseases, which together with the above gives this breed a great power to adaptation to our environment.
Specific reproductive characteristic: This quality, well demanded by farmers, and essential for all exploitation. The Norman cow generally gives one calf per year. The average parturition interval is 416 days and the average length of gestation is 284 days. In addition to this quality, cows have a faster postpartum recovery, which allows them a better disposition for dairy production and easy preparation for the next gestation. In general, 70% of cows become pregnant with the first insemination, carried out around 55 days after the previous calving. When there are no poor nutritional conditions, health or management, this percentage can increase, and in any case 95% of the cows are pregnant with the second insemination or mount.

Description: One of the main objectives is its preservation as an animal genetic resource of the country. It is a cattle with a bullfighting profile since it originated in the Iberian cattle that arrived with the colonization and went through a process of natural selection and allowed this population to adapt to the Paraguayan Chaco (Prieto C, 2002). It lives in the Western Region, mainly in the transition zone between the Lower Chaco and the Central Chaco. After a process of crossbreeding with British cattle, they were isolated and, in addition to the adaptation from the original Creole cattle, the rusticity, precocity, and fertility were worked, giving these animals a productive configuration beyond the cultural and biological legacy that they suppose.
Additional information: There is a cultural factor that should not be neglected, since the Creole cattle have left their mark both in the production of leather, in the settlement of Mennonite settlers in the Paraguayan Chaco, in the survival of the soldiers during the Chaco war and in the somehow, in the foundations of Paraguayan livestock, all this documented by photographic archives and various literary works.
Additional information comments: The Pampa Chaqueño bovine is a biological resource that is only found in Paraguay, so it is a legacy for the country and the world. Having a great potential socio-economic value as it is a unique resource for the small producer, which could become the ideal livestock for subsistence and minor commercialization. Being also a unique tool for the increase of the national Procreo indices.
Adaptability to specific environment: Animal with a bullfighting profile that acquired certain characteristics that allowed it to develop productively under unfavorable circumstances. Docile but vigorous. The cattle are able to cope with the harsh environmental conditions of the semi -arid thorn forest of the Chaco as well as the periods of prolonged flooding in the lower Chaco areas.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The animals are able to withstand the harsh Chaco environment and are still very fertile.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Precocity: Individuals who reach sexual maturity, growth and composition at an earlier age than the national average. (able to reproduce before 14 months, with finished steers around 20 months)
Special characteristic of product: Rusticity: Bovine with aptitudes inclined to the production of quality meat , capable of facing adversities thanks to the efficiency of conversion from pasture to meat and moderate size , short hair, mobility of the tail and skin tissue as well as the pigmentation of apricots . Adaptability to adverse soils: Rustic resistant to droughts and floods, moderate frame, highly variable forage supply during the year, so it has a feed/ meat conversion efficiency, early growth and completion, horn/ mocho to protect itself from wild predators , vigorous, maternal ability.
Other special qualities: Fertility: Able to produce progeny each cycle, with good performance in functional evaluations, remarkable maternal ability, with good milk production. Capable of to keep a general pregnancy rate above 90% under favorable conditions.
Reference for special qualities: Formation: Cattle of Creole origin, with high selection pressure in butchering characteristics, which allow good production of kg of meat/ha, as well as good carcass yield .
Color comments: Main Colour : Tricolor hairs forming the red and brown tones in their different shades, from the iodized tint, through the light brown, cherry red to burnt red, not necessarily evenly distributed. With melanin stars present. Coat distribution, mainly found with the Pampa character, where the face and white extremities are presented, and the pigmented body, but in a variable distribution. Present different types of signs on the limbs, or are completely pigmented. Diamond, Star, Malacara are other common coat colour distributions on the face. Fur: Leather of moderate thickness, loose and foldable. Soft to the touch and pigmented. Mobile Members: With different types of signs, variable degree of distribution between white and pigmented. Colour members of the coat, even joining the hooves that accompany pigmentation.
Horn shape size and comments: Symmetrical, laterally set, slightly drooping, thick, well developed, strong, fully or partially pigmented. Its insertion is perpendicular to the line of the eye. Mochos animals are presented.
Other specific visible traits: Horns: 2 or may not have horns
Description of origin: Born of two main components, without ruling out the possible influence of another. The basic component is given by the Creole cattle, of multiracial formation of Iberian origin, with more than 300 years of formation; while the crossbreeding component was given by British cattle, which several literary references mention that at the regional level of South America in chronological order they are given by the Shorthorn, Hereford and Devon breeds that at that time, although there were important mobilizations towards Paraguay, especially from Argentina, they were made stumbling, so the process was gradual and not immediate at the beginning of the 20th century. With the arrival of improvements in travel communications among other new technologies, at the end of the 20th century, the introduction of the Hereford and Polled Hereford was mainly quite important, producing in a short time the absorption of Creole cattle. It is at this time that the initiative arises to preserve the Creole genetic material, even in its mestizo shape , and it is at the beginning of the 21st century that the complete isolation of the population in Creole remnants is achieved and thanks to the public-private organization initiates the backcrossing process in order to increase the proportion of the Creole genetic material. The result of this process is the Pampa Chaqueño.
Management conditions performance measur: Yield data were measured under very extensive stationary conditions without housing or browsing in the semi -arid Chaco.
Comments management conditions: There is an acute lack of water during cold and dry winters.
Additional performance parameters: The breed has been selected for its fertility and growth. The main selection objective is meat production.

Adaptability to specific environment: They resist extreme temperatures.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Because they have thick leather , they resist bites from horseflies, mosquitoes, ticks, etc. Hard hooves ; because of this ability there are fewer problems with concrete floors. They resist extreme temperatures.
Specific reproductive characteristic: Easy deliveries. Very good pregnancy rate.
Color comments: Its coat is of a single brown-gray colour , which varies in tone, finding animals of light creamy gray tones and very tan animals, especially on the sides. The lighter colour areas are located on the eyes, muzzle, ears and on the lower parts of the legs. The hair is short, fine and soft; pigmented fur sample black on the exposed part such as the muzzle.
Horn shape size and comments: The horns, medium or small, are white with black tips, directed outward and upward, curving at the tips.
Description of origin: The Brown Swiss breed , notable for its strength and yield, is called Schwyz in German, in honor of Canton (province of Switzerland) where the effort to improve the breed began for the first time. Its origin is confined to what is the eastern middle part of the Helvetic country.  As it was developed in a rustic shape , its size was not increased until, in the early nineteenth century, it was mixed with large -size German cattle, although the levels of crossbreeding and changes from the original type are unknown.  This breed is famous throughout the world and is the second for its milk yield , without displacing the Holstein in any country. In Switzerland it competes with the Simmental in the supply of milk and meat for the small Swiss market.

Description: The Santa Gertrudis has characteristics that distinguish it as a breed that meets the needs of breeders and greenhouses, providing them with rusticity and maximum meat production.
Additional information: The Santa Gertrudis breed produces meat of excellent quality with an acceptable amount of fat, with a higher yield in the hind quarter
Color comments: The coat is red, covered cherry
Horn shape size and comments: Cushioned or with horns. The horns will close up and back
Other specific visible traits: Loose, red pigmented fur with skin folds (dewlap, wide navel) and pink mucous membranes. The bulls have a slight hump on the cross. His colour is an attractive covered cherry red hair and his short hair and soft.
Herdbook established: Asociación Paraguaya de Criadores de Santa Gertrudis

Description: Designed to perform well and tolerate sweltering climates, Senepol's bullfighting ingredient also offers carcass quality .
Adaptability to specific environment: The extreme meekness is reflected in better feed conversion and ease of handling. This in turn implies a lower amount of physical and human resources , as well as lower losses due to blows in pens and during transport.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Heat tolerance: The key to the Senepol breed lies in the presence of a gene of simple, dominant inheritance, responsible for the type of short hair and smooth hair (slick hair), which allows it to tolerate heat stress and, consequently, graze during the hottest hours of the year. day
Color comments: "ColorComments": "The short and colour red"
Horn shape size and comments: Mocho character: The fact that the breed does not have horns is another point that facilitates handling. In addition to transmitting this feature in 90% to their offspring.
Other specific visible traits: The extreme meekness is reflected in better feed conversion and ease of handling. This in turn implies a lower amount of physical and human resources , as well as lower losses due to blows in pens and during transport.
Herdbook established: Asociación Paraguaya de Criadores de Senepol

Description: The Tabapúa breed originated in Brazil, in the municipality of the same name located in the state of Sao Paulo, in the \ "Fazenda Agua Milagrosa \", owned by the Ortenblad family, in the early 1940s. This animal was created from a natural mocho bull of an intermediate type between the Nelore and the Guzerá, from whose offspring perfect mochos were also achieved "
Additional information: She has shown good fertility and good maternal ability in the wombs, which after several calvings did not show problems in the nipples.
Adaptability to specific environment: This animal has achieved a very good adaptability in terms of climate, since ours is very similar to that of Brazil. In the natural fields and low or steral fields, it has not suffered either, because its good height and strength give it an advantage over other races.
Color comments: white varying with gray
Herdbook established: Oficina de registros Zootecnicos de la Asociación Rural del Paraguay

Color comments: 90 % are black fur and 10 % red.
Description of origin: The Wagyu is a bovine breed originating in Japan, from the city of Kobe. Its meat is highly valued for its texture and flavor. It is also known as Japanese Black.

Provision Uses: Horns, Milk, Production of offspring for slaughter as young animals, Skin/hides
Regulation and Maintenance Uses: Habitat provision and biodiversity, Pest control, Regulation and control of animal/human diseases, Waste recycling of non-human edible feed, Water quality and flows regulation/purification
Description Of Specific Uses: No

Specific reproductive characteristic: This breed is known for high fertility.
Color comments: multi coloured: black, white
Description of origin: composite of Rosie Dobrogeana, Bruna de Maramures and Sura de Stepa
Import: since 1950 from Holstein-Friesian (USA, Netherlands, Denmark). Holstein-Friesian is continually imported, especially frozen semen.

Special characteristic of product: This breed produces a good quality meat.
Color comments: multi coloured: yellow with white head, tail and feet
Description of origin: continually imported from Switzerland and Germany; composite of Sura de Stepa, Simmental and Fleckvieh

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to the local environment (mountains).
Color comments: uni coloured: brown
Description of origin: continually imported from Switzerland, Austria, Germany; composite of Sura de Stepa, Mocanita and Braunvieh

Other specific visible traits: similar to Moldavian but darker and smaller

Description of origin: former variety of Romanian Steppe. Moldavian x Transylvanian

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to the local environment (mountains).
Color comments: multi coloured: red sided with broad white back
Description of origin: composite of Pinzgau and Sura de Stepa

Other name: Moldavian, Romanian Grey Steppe, Romanian Steppe, Moldovenesca, Romanian Steppe
Additional information: In 2003, this breed is at risk.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The animals are reported to be resistant to tuberculosis and leucosis.
Other special qualities: The animals are known for staying power.
Color comments: uni coloured: grey with black muzzle and tail-tip

Other name: Grey Transylvanian, Siebenburgisch, Transylvanian Steppe, Transylvanian
Other specific visible traits: huge horns

Description of origin: German Brown (Allgäuer) x local cattle; original (with Miskov and crossed with Swiss Brown) of Kostroma

Additional information: Data before independence refer to Former USSR.
Color comments: multi coloured: white with black ears

Additional information: The first group of Brown Swiss animals was imported to Russia from Switzerland in 1861 to a farm of Moscow agricultural academy. This breed soon became very popular in Moscow, Smolensk, Tula and other regions of Russia. Delivery of imported genetic resources to Russia were made in the twentiesthirties of the last century (Switzerland), and in 1958-1972 from Austria, Switzerland, Hungary and USA. Later, semen and sires were imported from USA and Canada.
Data before independence refer to Former USSR.
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to a hot climate.
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is reported to be resistant to blood parasites.
Special characteristic of product: A high milk fat content is reported for this breed.
Color comments: uni coloured: white with black ears and black spectacles around eyes
Other specific visible traits: small hump in male
Description of origin: composite of Friesian, Swiss Brown, local zebu and Simmental
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 5 months per year and fed on grazing, concentrates and fodder.

Additional information: Data before independence refer to Former USSR (excluding the Baltic Republics). Although Mason distinguishes Central Russian, Russian, Ural and Siberian Black Pied breeds, there does not seem to be any clear distinction between these. Small regional variations do exist e.g.. European Black Pied animals are high milk producers and have a strong constitution, Ural Black Pieds have a lighter constitution, are long legged, have high milk yield and good milk fat, Siberian Black Pieds are smaller and inferior with regards milk and milk fat production. All Black Pieds are specialised in milk production. They were the second most numerous breed in the Former USSR in 1980.
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is a high producer in the difficult climate that it encounters and is improving every year.
Color comments: multi coloured: black and white pied
Description of origin: composite of East Friesian, Dutch Black, Local Russian, Ural, Siberian and other breeds
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 7 months per year and fed on grazing, fodder and concentrates.

Description of origin: variety of Russian Black Pied; composite of East Friesian and local Siberian
originated from Swiss Brown x Dagestan Mountain & Carparthian Brown blood, absorbed by Caucasian Brown

Additional information: Data before independence refer to Former USSR. The decline has been precipitated by the lack of competitiveness of this breed compared to other dairy breeds.
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is well adapted to the local conditions.
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is reported to be resistant to infectious diseases. Cases of Leucosis among these animals are 20 times less than for Black Pied breeds.
Color comments: uni coloured: black, red multi coloured: black pied, red pied
Description of origin: composite of Kholmogory, Swiss Brown, East Friesian and Great Russian
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 7 months per year and fed on grazing, fodder and concentrates.

Additional information: Data before independence refer to Former USSR.
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is highly adapted to grazing on poor vegetation and surviving harsh changes in climate. The body temperature of these animals is fairly stable under harsh winter conditions or very hot sunny conditions.
Other special qualities: The animals are known for their high viability.
Efabis adaptability to marginal land: able to graze on poor vegetation
Color comments: uni coloured: red often with white on head, belly and feet
Description of origin: Taurino-Mongolian type from Asian Bos primigenius, composite of Simmental, Shorthorn and local cattle This breed was formed about 300 years ago in the mountain and steppe regions of China, Western Mongolia and Southern Altai. The Kalmyik cattle appeared in the South-Eastern regions of Russia in the first quarter of the XVII century.
Location within country: Low Volga region (Kalmykia, Volgograd, Astrakhan), as well as Rostov on Don, Stavropol krai, Chita region, Byryatia and Tuva
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 6-7 months per year and fed on grazinig, fodder and concentrates.
Comments management conditions: This breed is known for its ability to graze on poor vegetation like Sagebush pasture.

Description of origin: Its equivalent to the East Finnish Breed

Color comments: uni coloured: two coloured varieties:1. small and black 2. large and red
Location within country: Greater and Lesser Caucasus, Transcaucasian Lowlands

Description of origin: Siberian crossed with Simmental, Kholmogory, Ukrainian Red, East Friesian (1930's); absorbed by Black Pied

Additional information: Data before independence refer to Former USSR.
Data before independence refer to Former USSR.
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is also quite versatile and can adapt to various climatic conditions.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Cases of leucosis are lower than for Black Pieds.
Color comments: uni coloured: also black or red multi coloured: usually black pied, also red pied
Description of origin: composite of local cattle and Friesian Kholmogorskaya breed was established by using the cattle that was brought by the settlers to Arkhangelsk region from Novgorod (X-XII centuries) and Upper Volga regions (XIII century). The subsequent imports of Dutch cattle (XVIII-XIX centuries) had a certain impact to forming Kholmogorskaya breed
Location within country: mainly Arkhangelsk and Kirov regions, as well as in the Republics of Udmurtia, Tatarstan and Komi
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 7 months per year and fed on grazing, fodder and concentrates.
Additional performance parameters: This breed is second only to the Black Pied breeds in milk production.

Additional information: Data before independence refer to Former USSR.
Other special qualities: This breed is known for longevity, strong constitution and hardiness. This breed is characterised by a strong constitution, hardiness and high milk production over a long lifetime.
Color comments: uni coloured: light grey with yellow or pale yellow top line (similar to Brown Swiss)
Description of origin: composite of Swiss Brown and improved local (Babaev and Miskov)
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for seven months per year and fed on grazing, fodder and concentrates.

Other name: Krasnaya nemetskaua, Red Colonist, Red German, Red Ukrainian, Red Steppe
Additional information: Data before independence refer to Former USSR.
Adaptability to specific environment: This breed is well adapted to continental climate.
Color comments: uni coloured: red of various shades
Other specific visible traits: dairy type conformation
Description of origin: composite of Red East Friesian, Angeln and Ukranian Grey, later also Swiss Brown and East Friesian
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected form animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 5-6 months per year and fed on grazing, fodder and concentrates.
Additional performance parameters: There are 3 main zonal types, Zaporozhye (high milk production), Crimean (combine high mily yields with high fat content) and Donetsk (high milk production with high live weight).

Additional information: Data before independence refer to Former USSR. After 1976 the breed was not included in the zoning plan for Gorki and Vladimir regions and has consequently gone into decline. There are 2 breeding centres: Bogordoski in Gorki region and Zimenki in Vladimir region. There are 12 000 doses of semen under storage.
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is reported to be resistant to leucosis, tuberculosis and brucellosis.
Special characteristic of product: The breed is a high producer of butterfat and considered one of the best national breeds. It is a dual purpose breed.
Color comments: uni coloured: red, sometimes with white markings on udder and abdomen and pink muzzle
Horn shape size and comments: horns are white with black tips
Description of origin: composite of Tyrolean and Prioksky created in the 19th century
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for seven months per year and fed on grazing, fodder and concentrates.

Additional information: Data before independence refer to Former USSR. This breed was recognized in 1948. It is considered a vanishing breed.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The most valuable characteristics of the breed are a strong constitution and resistance to some diseases.
Other special qualities: The animals are known for their strong constitution.
Color comments: uni coloured: red occasional with white markings on abdomen, chest and legs
Description of origin: composite of Tyrolean, Devon, Simmental and local breeds
Location within country: mainly Kirsanov District, Tambov and Voronesh Region
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 6.5 months per year and fed on grazing, fodder and concentrates.

Color comments: uni coloured: grey, brown, yellow
Description of origin: Brown Swiss & Simmental x Ukrainian Grey in 19th century

Additional information: Data before independence refer to Former USSR.
Color comments: uni coloured: red, brown multi coloured: red, white
Other specific visible traits: well developed dewlap
Description of origin: composite of Shorthorn, Simmental, Dutch, Bestuzhev, Tagil, Red Steppe and local cattle
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 7 months per year and fed on grazing, fodder and concentrates.
Additional performance parameters: In pedigree herds most cattle produce over 4% butterfat.

Description of origin: originated from East Prussian Black Pied Lowland (late 1700s, early 1800s)
local cattle with Yaroslovl, Kholmogory & Ayrshire blood

Additional information: Data before independence refer to Former USSR.
Color comments: multi coloured: black and white, red and white
Description of origin: descended from Zyryanka 16-20th century, improved by Kholmogory 1930-1947,
from East Friesian or Kholmogory x Simmental, Swiss Brown & Jersey; absorbed by Black Pied

Additional information: Data before independence refer to Former USSR.
Color comments: uni coloured: brown of various shades
Description of origin: imported from Switzerland and Germany in early 19th century
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 6 - 6.5 months per year and fed on grazing, fodder and concentrates.
Additional performance parameters: The crossing of Swiss Brown with indigenous breeds throughout the former USSR has led to the development of many regional breeds including Ala-Tau, Lebedin, Caucausian Brown and Carpathian Brown.

Additional information: Data before independence refer to Former USSR. The number of animals in 1980 excluded Sychevka. This breed accounted for 25.6% of all cattle in Former USSR in 1980 and was therefore the most common breed. The breed may be divided into 6 types: Steppe Simmental (Russian cattle X Simmental bulls) Ukrainian Simmental (Grey Steppe cattle X Simmental bulls (good beef animals)) Volga Simmental (Central Russian Kalmyk and Kazakh X Simmental bulls) Ural Simmental (Siberian and Kazakh cattle X Simmental) Siberian Simmental (Siberian and Buryat X Simmental) Far Eastern Simmental (Transbaikal and Yakut X Simmental (formed under harsh continental climatic conditions)
Color comments: multi coloured: red, yellow, white
Description of origin: composite of Shorthorn, Simmental, Dutch, Bestuzhev, Tagil, Red Steppe and local cattle
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected form animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 6 - 6.5 months per year and fed on grazing, fodder and concentrates.
Additional performance parameters: Three basic types can be distinguished based on productivity: dairy (5 000 kg milk per year); dairy-beef (4 640 kg of milk per year); beef (3 850 kg of milk per year);

Other name: Black Pied, Chernopestraya, Tsentralnaya, Central Russian Black Pied
Additional information: The Black pied breeds may be divided into regional groups or varieties, such as Estonian, Central Russian and Siberian (Mason 1988). However, only one breed is officially recognised in the former USSR, the Russian Black Pied. This is distinct from the Baltic Black Pied which may be subdivided into Lithuanian and Estonian varieties. According to Mason (1988) Ural, Central Russian and Siberian were separate varieties with established herd-books. Data before independence refer to Former USSR.
Color comments: multi coloured: black and white pied
Description of origin: composite of Great Russian, Siberian, Trans-Ural, Central Asian and East Friesian: variety of Russian Black Pied

Additional information: Data before independence refer to Former USSR.
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to live under the severe climatic conditions in central Ural.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The animals are reported to show resistance to leucosis and tuberculosis.
Color comments: uni coloured: red
Other specific visible traits: compact conformation
Description of origin: composite of Danish Red, local cattle, Angeln, Red Steppe, Estonian Red and Latvian Brown
Location within country: mainly in the Suksun District, Perm Region
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 7 months per year and fed on grazing, fodder and concentrates.

Other name: Sychevka Simmental, Western Simmental, Sychevka, Sychevka
Additional information: Data before independence refer to Former USSR. The Sychevskaya breed was officially registered in 1950.
Color comments: multi coloured: red, yellow, white with white head
Description of origin: variety of Russian Simmental: composite of Simmental and West Russian: In 1950 the ""Simmentalised"" cattle in the Smolensk and Kalinin regions were distinguished as the Sychevka breed.
Location within country: Tver, Bryansk, Kaluga, Kursk regions, as well as in Mordovia and Siberian regions
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 6.5 months per year and fed on grazing, fodder and concentrates.

Additional information: Data before independence refer to Former USSR. The number of animals has decreased 13% from 1970 - 1980. There are essentially 3 types of Tagil; Tagil-Dutch (mainly black and white), Starotagil (influence of Swiss Brown and Tyrolean) and the standard Tagil (uninfluenced be Dutch Black Pieds).
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to mountain climate.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The breed is resistant to diseases.
Special characteristic of product: The animals are known for good beef quality, high butterfat content and high milk yields.
Color comments: uni coloured: also black, red multi coloured: usually black pied, also red pied
Description of origin: composite of Friesian, Kholmogory, Swiss Brown, Tyrolean and local cattle
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 7 months per year and fed on grazing, fodder and concentrates.

Description of origin: variety of Russian Black Pied; composite of East Friesian and Tagil

Color comments: uni coloured: black
comments: black (28%), black pied (20%) or red pied (47%)

Other specific visible traits: similar to Kalmuk

Additional information: Data before independence refer to Former USSR.
Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to live under extreme cold northern climatic conditions and highly adapted to very difficult feeding conditions. The udder and body are covered with thick hair to protect them from the cold and midges.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The animals are reported to show resistance to tuberculosis, leucosis and brucellosis.
Other special qualities: The animals are able to thrive on poor feeding.
Color comments: multi coloured: black, red or spotted with white back-line
Other specific visible traits: thick hair with numerous guard hairs
Description of origin: last remaining variety of Siberian, indigenous breed local breed
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 8-8.5 months per year and fed on grazing, fodder and concentrates.

Additional information: Data before independence refer to Former USSR.
Adaptability to specific environment: The most valuable characteristics of the breed are it's high rich milk yields, resistance to Tuberculosis, Leucosis and Brucellosis and high response to improved feeding and management conditions.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The animals are reported to show resistance to tuberculosis, leucosis and brucellosis.
Color comments: uni coloured: usually black occasionally red with white head and feet
Description of origin: indigenous local breed developed in the late 19th century Yaroslavskaya breed was selected in the XIX century in the Central zone of Russia by using the local Northern forest cattle. Kholmogorski cattle to a significant extent had influenced on the formation of the existing population of Yaroslavski cattle, and to a less extent there was an impact of Black and White Dutch cattle
Location within country: Yaroslavl, Ivanovo, Vologda and Tver regions of the Russian Federation
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 7 months per year and fed on grazing, fodder and concentrates.

Additional information: Data before independence refer to Former USSR. In 1989 the breed was vanishing rapidly due to the upgrading with sires of other breeds.
Specific resistance or tolerance: The animals are reported to show resistance to tuberculosis, leucosis and brucellosis.
Color comments: uni coloured: red, brow occasionally with white markings on lower barrel
Other specific visible traits: large dewlap
Description of origin: composite of Gorbatov Red, Tyrolean, Swiss Brown, Chuvash Mari and Simmental
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from animals kept under stationary conditions, housed for 6-7 months per year and fed on grazing, fodder and concentrates.

Description of origin: indigenous breed originated in Ankolé regions, South of Uganda.
Composite breed developed in the Republic of South Africa.

Color comments: uni coloured: red or grey multi coloured: a gradual mixture of red and grey
Other specific visible traits: Their face is broad and flat.

Description of origin: imported from mountainous areas of Eastern and Central Switzerland

Color comments: multi coloured: magpie-black or magpie-red
Location within country: Urban zones and périurbaines; the town of Kigali and in the area between Kigali and Kayonza.

Other specific visible traits: Giant-lyrehorned owned by kings and chiefs as distinct from common Inkuku

Adaptability to specific environment: The Jersey breed counts among the European bovine races most tolerant to the heat of tropical countries.
Color comments: uni coloured: brown
Other specific visible traits: Large and exorbitant eyes.
Comments management conditions: The Jersey breed is kept in small numbers (1 or 2) per rural household.

Adaptability to specific environment: Adapted to hot climates.
Color comments: uni coloured: brown
Other specific visible traits: Thick skin.
Comments management conditions: Dual-purpose breed.

Other name: Hawazma, Reziegat, ecotypes include: Esseriya, Western Baggara
Other special qualities: This breed is adapted to a lack of water and poor nutrition.
Color comments: uni coloured: often white with red or black markings, also grey, red, black, yellow or dun
Other specific visible traits: North Sudan Zebu group, small in size
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were collected from animals kept under transhumant conditions, not housed, and fed on total grazing with an inadequate water supply.
Additional performance parameters: Performance under dry feed lot conditions yields a 0.8-0.9 kg body weight gain with a finishing body weight of about 400 kg. The breed is characterized as a beef breed. Baggara are compact in size, are poor milk producers and perform only modestly under feedlot conditions. This breed as well as the others in the North Sudan Shorthorn group, namely Kenana and Butana, are productive under conditions of poor nutrition and indifferent management. Milk production by Baggara cattle is not as good as for the other two breeds, since they have been selected to produce meat from the very variable rangeland feed supply of Darfur and Kordofan. Baggara cattle are very hardy and strong for packing and transport.

Adaptability to specific environment: The breed is adapted to frequent droughts.
Color comments: multi coloured: white with black spots all over
Other specific visible traits: compact size
Description of origin: possible variety of North Sudan Zebu
Location within country: North-eastern Sudan, Red Mountains (continuation of the Ethiopian Plateau)
Comments management conditions: The breed usually suffers from inadequate water supply and frequent droughts.
Additional performance parameters: low milk production;

Other name: Dongola, North Sudan Zebu, Shendi, Sudanese Shorthorned Zebu, Red Butana
Special characteristic of product: Butana are raised as a dual purpose breed but are known for their good milk production.
Color comments: uni coloured: red
Horn shape size and comments: Females have 15-20 cm long horns and males 35 cm long horns.
Other specific visible traits: dewlap prominent in both sexes, large hump
Description of origin: related to Bambawa, Dongola and Shendi which belong to the group of Red Desert Cattle. Large east African Zebu.
Import: since 1956 extensive cross-breeding with European cattle
Location within country: originated in the Butana plain, east of the Blue Nile, now spread to Gizera in central Sudan and along the river Nile in the northern region
Performance data reference: N2-37 W67-49 FAO Breed Survey R-1992
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data was collected from animals kept under all management conditions, although transhumance was the most commonly encountered. Cattle were fed on total grazing, grazing and concentrates or grazing and crop residues.
Comments management conditions: The breed is mostly kept by settled or semi-settled farmers. In the dry season the animals suffer from a lack of water and inadequate feed supply.

Special characteristic of product: The animals show an excellent response to fattening.
Other special qualities: This breed is adapted to a lack of water and food.
Color comments: uni coloured: white
Other specific visible traits: large body weight at maturity
Description of origin: They may have originated from the Central African Republic and could be related to the Kuri or Gudali of West Africa. This breed is distinct from the Baggara cattle - the dominant breed in southern Darfur.
Location within country: south-west Darfur, towards the boarder with the Central African Republic
Comments management conditions: They often have to cope with water sortages and lack of food supply.
Additional performance parameters: These are large deep bodied animals, highly responsive to finishing in feedlots. Experiments at an institute have demonstrated that they can gain as much as 1.5-2 kgs per day. The breed is preferred by commercial feedlot exporters for beef export.

Other special qualities: The animals are very well adapted to poor water supply.
Color comments: uni coloured: usually dark brown but other colours also occur
Other specific visible traits: Zebu, short compact animals
Description of origin: similar to Abyssinian Shorthorned Zebu, with some Kenana influence
Location within country: south Blue Nile and Gizera Provinces
Comments management conditions: Water is lacking most of the year for these animals.
Additional performance parameters: These animals are poor milkers and are used mainly for beef.

Other name: Fung, North Sudan Zebu, Rufa'ai, Sudanese Shorthorned Zebu, White Nile, Blue Nile
Special characteristic of product: This breed is considered one of the best milkers in Africa.
Color comments: multi coloured: light blue to grey with black points
Other specific visible traits: muscular hump, larger in males
Location within country: southern-central plains of the Sudan, between the Blue and the White Nile
Management conditions performance measur: Performance data were measured on animals kept on total grazing, grazing and fodder and grazing and concentrates.
Comments management conditions: The breed encounters inadequate feed supply as a result of the encroachment of mechanized farming on the traditional grazing areas.
Additional performance parameters: This is a dual purpose breed and is considered one of the best milkers in Africa. There appears to be great genetic variability in dairy merit which allows room for selection.The best Kenana cows at Um Banein Research Station yield more than 4 500 kg of milk per lactation, for comparison well managed herds in Great Britain average 5 000 kg. The breeds of the Northern Sudan Shorthorned group produce milk and meat and are also used to provide farm power and as transport animals

Color comments: uni coloured: predominantly white
Other specific visible traits: Zebu, similar to Toposa but smaller
Description of origin: possibly descended from Abyssinian Shorthorned Zebu
Location within country: area north of Juba, owned by the Murle tribe, South-eastern Sudan
Comments management conditions: The animals are exposed to infectious and parasitic diseases; many animals are lost due to the war in the region.
Additional performance parameters: These are medium sized cattle with poor milking abilities.

Other name: Aliab Dinka, Aweil Dinka, Dinka, East Nuer, Nuer, Sudanese Longhorn, Wadai, Southern Sudanese
Color comments: uni coloured: usually off-white or cream, also red, black, pied
Other specific visible traits: Sanga type
Description of origin: According to Mason (1988) it is a Sanga breed. The FAO Breed Survey contact classified Nilotic as a Longhorn Zebu. As the hump is on the chest rather than on the neck, the breed is considered as Longhorn Zebu rather than a Sanga breed.
Location within country: Up Nile, Equatoria and Bahr el Gazal, southern Sudan provinces
Comments management conditions: Nilotic are subjected to many infectious agents and parasitic diseases and lack security. Many animals were lost due to the war and infections and parasitic diseases. Nilotic are kept mainly by the nomadic and semi-nomadic ethnic group called Nilotic.
Additional performance parameters: This breed is characterized as a milk producer with low milking potential.

Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is locally known as trypanotolerant.
Other special qualities: There has been a research station at Dallami town (now closed) to assay levels of trypanotolerance in this breed.
Color comments: uni coloured: dark brown
Other specific visible traits: Zebu, dwarf, variable hump
Description of origin: possibly composite of Baggara and Dwarf Humpless
Location within country: Koalib tribe in the North-western part of the Nuba mountains, south Kordofan
Comments management conditions: There is a lack of security in this region, many animals were lost due to the war in the region.
Additional performance parameters: These animals are relitively poor milkers and attain relatively low mature body weight.

Other name: Djafoun, Fellata, Gabassae, Gadehe, Hanagamba, Kreda, Mbororo, Ogha, Rahaza, Red Fulani, Brahaza
Color comments: uni coloured: mahogany, sometimes white
Horn shape size and comments: very long (up to 63 cm) lyre shaped horns
Other specific visible traits: slender body with long legs
Description of origin: West African Long-lyrehorned Zebu type: introduced by migrating Mbororo from northern Nigeria in 1940's and 1950's
Location within country: scattered over a wide area of the country from west to east
Additional performance parameters: These may be considered as beef animals and are generally low milk producers.

Other special qualities: This is a good meat animal which fattens easily.
Color comments: uni coloured: light grey
uni coloured: mainly red, also other colours
Other specific visible traits: Shorthorn Zebu, similar to Murle but smaller
Description of origin: East African Zebu, similar to Karamajong and Turkana
Comments management conditions: A lack of water and security was reported.
Additional performance parameters: This breed is classified as a beef breed. They are moderate milkers.

Description of origin: variety of Kenana with Baggara blood

Color comments: uni coloured: grey, yellow, white
Other specific visible traits: large animals
Description of origin: composite of Gobra (Zebu) and N'Dama: It is not a very well defined breed in terms of the percentages of Gobra and N'Dama blood.
Location within country: In the arachidier Basin and in Eastern Senegal.

Other name: Senegal Zebu, Zebu Peul Senegalais, Senegal Fulani
Color comments: uni coloured: white
Horn shape size and comments: long (70-80 cm), big, lyre shaped horns
Other specific visible traits: dewlap, hump (smaller in females)
Performance data reference: Data forwarded from EAAP in 1980 SODESP (1984) Etude de consolidation du projet de developpement de l'Elevage en Z.S.R. CRZ Dakar Rapport annuels 1965. Sow R.S. et al (1984): Evaluation of the productivity of zebu-Gobra at the CRZ, Dakar (Rapport non public). Diop D. (1987): Etude du system d'elevage dans le zone d'emprise du CRZ, Dakar. Memoir de Titularisation ISRA, 1987. There are very few studies on this breed in Mauritania. The information provided comes from some thesis written by veterinarians.
Comments management conditions: There is a lack of water during the dry season.

Additional information comments: semen is imported from Brazil for AI
Location within country: Dakar; few animal inside the contry

Other specific visible traits: Large sized cattle with distinct black, sometimes red markings.

Description of origin: composite of N'Dama (13/16) and Gobra Zebu (3/16) of Djakore type
Composite of dairy breeds of temperate regions (Holstein, Montbeliard, Brown Swiss) and local breeds.
Year of origin: National AI program starting in 1999/2000, with 3000-5000 local cows inseminated each year.
Location within country: In all country, but particularly in the groundnut basin around big cities.

Adaptability to specific environment: Well adapted to humid climate conditions.
Specific resistance or tolerance: Trypanotolerant.
Other specific visible traits: Small sized animal.

Color comments: uni coloured: fawn, white, blond (lighter than Guinean N'Dama)
Other specific visible traits: slightly taller than typical Guinean type
Performance data reference: FAO Breed Survey F20(1) -23 W50-11 CRZ-Kolda Rapports Annuels (1974) FALL A. et al (1982) Evaluation of the productivities of Djallonke sheep and N'Dama cattle at the CRZ-Kolda, Senegal. ILCA Research report No. 3 Sept. 1982.
Management conditions performance measur: Performance was measured on animals kept under stationary conditions and fed on total grazing with no housing.
Comments management conditions: There is a lack of water during the dry season from November to June.

Color comments: multi coloured: white with black points

Description: Zébu with red coat

Adaptability to specific environment: Can cope with new changes. Adapted very well to the climatic conditions of the Solomons, they do not seek water and shade so often.
Description of origin: imported from Australia, locally adapted breed

Adaptability to specific environment: Can cope with new changes.
Can cope with new changes.

Description of origin: imported from Australia; exotic; The latest cattle importation was made in 1997 by Russell Islands Plantation Limited (RIPEL) of 800 head from Breeders in Australia, including Limousine breed.

Adaptability to specific environment: Can cope with new changes. Adapted very well to the climatic conditions of the Solomons, they do not seek water and shade so often.

Adaptability to specific environment: Can cope with new changes.

Description of origin: imported from Australia; exotic; The latest cattle importation was made in 1997 by Russell Islands Plantation Limited (RIPEL) of 800 head from Breeders in Australia, including Simmental breed.

Adaptability to specific environment: Can cope with new changes.
Other special qualities: This breed has a quiet temperament.
Description of origin: composite of Brahman, Santa Gertrudis, Hereford, Shorthorn and Droughtmaster (Australia)

Other name: Boyenca, Fouta Jallon, Fouta Longhorn, Futa, Malinke, Mandingo, N'dama Peti, Outa Malinke, Boenca
Adaptability to specific environment: The animals can survive under very humid conditions.
Specific resistance or tolerance: This breed is reported to be trypanotolerant.
Other special qualities: The animals are well known for their hardiness.
Color comments: uni coloured: usually fawn, red or brown, occasionally or black multi coloured: occasionally pied
Other specific visible traits: small animals

Other name: Lola, Montgomery, Multani, Teli, Lambi Bar
Specific resistance or tolerance: The animals are reported to show resistance to tick borne diseases.
Special characteristic of product: This is an excellent dairy breed.
Color comments: uni coloured: rarely white multi coloured: usually reddish-dun usually with white markings
Other specific visible traits: Zebu

Adaptability to specific environment: Well adapted to tropical conditions.
Comments management conditions: Used in different production systems: Commercial sector and subsistence farming systems.

Other special qualities: The animals often have to walk long distances in search of water.
Color comments: uni coloured: usually white or grey, also red multi coloured: also pied
Other specific visible traits: East African Shorthorned Zebu type
Location within country: Gedo, Lower Jubba, Middle Jubba, North-western and Eastern
Comments management conditions: There is inadequate water supply.

Color comments: uni coloured: often red multi coloured: also red pied or black pied
Other specific visible traits: Zebu
Location within country: central Somalia: Middle Shabelle, Awdal, Hargeisa and Benadir
